webTitle: Punch thrown at cup final captured on television

fields.headline: Punch thrown at cup final captured on television
fields.trailText: A Tottenham Hotspur football fan was captured on closed circuit television attacking a rival fan during last year's Worthington Cup final, Harrow crown court, in north London, heard yesterday.
fields.body:
A Tottenham Hotspur football fan was captured on closed circuit television attacking a rival fan during last year's Worthington Cup final, Harrow crown court, in north London, heard yesterday.

Ruth Lelacheur, 30, suffered bruising to the back of her ear and a damaged tooth as a result of the alleged attack by Jonathan Edmonds at Wembley stadium in March last year.

Edmonds, 31, of Slough, Berkshire, denied charges of affray and actual bodily harm.

Michael Latham, prosecuting, said Miss Lelacheur, a Leicester City fan, was in a family enclosure with her partner and her daughter, Megan, three, when a dispute arose about the presence of Spurs fans. He said Megan fell and Miss Lelacheur felt blows to the ear and to her jaw.

After the pictures were shown on Crimewatch, Mr Edmonds went to a police station and denied assault.

Mr Latham said Mr Edmonds claimed he was pushed over and hit out in self defence. "He is saying the blows were not directed at Miss Lelacheur."

Miss Lelacheur told the court there had been a carnival atmosphere before the incident. "But then we heard a group of about five to seven Tottenham fans sitting just behind us shouting: 'We are Tottenham'.

"A lot of Leicester fans then started shouting that the Spurs fans shouldn't have been in that part of the ground."

Cross-examining, Gavin Meerylees said he did not dispute that Miss Lelacheur had been hit by his client.

He said: "One reason those fans got into that part of the ground was that tickets had been sold by some of the Leicester players and had been bought by some of the Spurs fans. Fines were imposed by the FA on those players."

The trial continues today.

webTitle: TUC says law review fails to prise open corporate doors

fields.headline: TUC says law review fails to prise open corporate doors
fields.trailText: The TUC yesterday called for a dilution of shareholder power as it accused the government's company law review of caving in to corporate interests.
fields.body:
The TUC yesterday called for a dilution of shareholder power as it accused the government's company law review of caving in to corporate interests.

John Monks, the TUC general secretary, said the latest revelations of unbridled boardroom pay rises showed the need for new laws to rein in "unaccountable corporate power".

He added: "Top directors have shown that they are more than prepared to suffer a few days' bad publicity in return for mega salary and bonus packages."

Mr Monks was presenting the unions' response to the government's review of company law, which will introduce the biggest shake-up in more than a century. The review has rejected calls for a "stakeholder" approach which would broaden directors' duties.

Mr Monks described the review team's report as a "cop-out" because it urged better behaviour without backing the legal changes necessary to make that happen.

"The report seems simply to have given in to vested interests."

The TUC argues that directors should have to balance the interests of all stakeholders rather than answering only to shareholders. It says that could be done by allowing British companies to have two-tier boards, as in Germany, with independent directors safeguarding the interests of workers, customers and other interest groups.

The unions also call for a "public interest" requirement in takeovers, arguing that employees should be consulted.

The review will be finalised next spring.

Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, has backed calls for greater disclosure of how companies affect the environment and the community, but dismissed calls for more radical change.

Mr Monks welcomed the prospect of companies paying more attention to relations with employees and other stakeholders but insisted that disclosure was not enough. "It is naive to think it will change a great deal on its own."

webTitle: Holding the fort

fields.headline: Holding the fort
fields.standfirst:
Spending August in the office may have its perks. Diane Taylor on the upside of being at work while most of your colleagues are on holiday

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Spending August in the office may have its perks. Diane Taylor on the upside of being at work while most of your colleagues are on holiday.
fields.body:
The sky is blue, the sun has come out at last, but from inside a sweltering office, the rays can seem malevolent. This is August, the month of holidays and, for those stuck in the office, the month of resentment.

If it's pouring with rain, we curse the typical British summer; if the sun shines, we curse the fact that we can't get out to enjoy it. If the workload takes a dramatic nosedive, we curse again because the days become interminably long - but even worse is when one employee ends up buckling under the weight of three people's jobs and coping with crises that normally go unnoticed because someone else deals with them.

But August in the office doesn't have to be depressing. Cristina Odone has been moved up a notch from her job as deputy editor of the New Statesman to acting editor while the editor, Peter Wilby, follows the politicians into summer recess. She says she has discovered all sorts of unexpected pleasures in being office-bound while all around are not. While she admits "there are climactic difficulties associated with working through August and a little bit of martyrdom when everyone else is away", her solution is to take long, lingering breaks in the middle of the day. "A three-hour lunch is a good antidote," she suggests.

She believes getting the opportunity to stretch yourself beyond your job description is something everyone should have a shot at. "I'm enjoying proving to Peter that I can do it without him. For 11 months of the year the buck stops with him, but suddenly it's stopping with me. Instead of him leaving the office at midnight on deadline day, I'm doing that, so there's a sense of complicity with him. I understand much better what his job involves and it's nice to know I'm capable of it."

But in case Wilby is reading this, she assures him no coup is planned. "While in the abstract I suppose August is the month in which employees can plot a takeover while the boss is out of the way, I'm not sure that works in practice. To pull off such a coup you need to be able to show off to proprietors or board members. But they'll probably be away sunning themselves under coconut palms, too, and there's not much point putting on a show in the office if you're playing to an audience of one."

One of the biggest joys of August is undoubtedly the under-crowded commute. It is the only time of the year when it's possible to sit on the bus or tube and fling open a newspaper without shoving your elbow into the mouth of the unfortunate soul squashed up next to you. And the office environment becomes almost benign with no queues for the coffee machine and more oxygen per person.

Ben Williams, a chartered corporate psychologist, believes these temporarily spacious arrangements have a positive impact on workplace performance. "When too many people are crowded together, you get a behavioural sink. People feel they can get away with more because there are too many people around for them to be closely observed. When experiments were carried out cramming rats into a confined space, a rise in delinquency was noted among them. When there are fewer people and everyone is more closely observed, they take more responsibility for their actions."

Perhaps one of the most salutary lessons about August work patterns is that while the pace is slower, things still get done. John Hildebrand, of the City firm Investec Asset Management, says: "Everything is so much more relaxed in August. Dress codes are easier, with more chinos than pinstripes, and people are more likely to go for a drink after work, but things still happen. Traditionally the financial markets are weaker in August and there's a feeling that nothing's going on. But actually big mergers and takeovers don't always stop during the summer break - we've just had all the excitement with Barclays taking over the Woolwich."

The public sector can have particular problems finding enough staff to cover frontline hospital and residential care home services in August - managers see this month as a "mini-millennium" in terms of juggling essential services with staff's desire to head off on holiday.

Mike Boyle, project team leader for asylum seekers and refugees at the Local Government Association, has to deal with emergencies all year round. But he says that even though the numbers of asylum seekers don't reduce in August, he loves this month. "It's great. The services for asylum seekers still get provided but all the Home Office officials I liaise with are away and I can catch up on reading and writing reports. Usually if I arrive at the office after a meeting, I'll have 40 emails and 15 phone messages waiting for me. When I get in today I'll be surprised if I have two phone messages and any emails."

John Wilson, professor of occupational ergonomics at Nottingham University, believes August isn't quite what it used to be in terms of a slump in workload. "I've noticed that more and more colleagues take their lap-tops and mobile phones away on holiday with them and send and receive emails on the beach."

Even universities, which were once deserts during the summer, now buzz with life. "The car park here used to empty in August," Wilson says, "but at the moment it's almost full. Academics can't just go off to summer schools any more. The pressure on research is so great that they're all here.

"Everyone is in some sort of supply chain, whether they're in a service industry, health or education, so people have less to do to keep running round the hamster wheel."

Nevertheless, Wilson believes it is hard to know whether we are just doing too much wasteful work the rest of the year. "There are certainly more internal audits and more managers than there were 15 years ago. Some say they don't improve services but things may well be worse without them."

But Boyle is convinced that a more streamlined approach is the way to workplace salvation. "The rest of the year, I end up coming into work before 9am and not leaving until 9pm. During August I arrive at a normal time and leave at a normal time. I think this is the only month in which we've got our working practices right. It's the other 11 months we've got real problems with."

webTitle: Maternity laws 'an obstacle for women in work'

fields.headline: Maternity laws 'an obstacle for women in work'
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Women will suffer even more discrimination at work if the government goes ahead with plans to extend maternity leave without offering equivalent fathers' rights, the Industrial Society warns today in an outspoken attack on ministers' attempts to promote family-friendly policies.
fields.body:
Women will suffer even more discrimination at work if the government goes ahead with plans to extend maternity leave without offering equivalent fathers' rights, the Industrial Society warns today in an outspoken attack on ministers' attempts to promote family-friendly policies.

It would be "entirely rational" for employers to recruit men instead of women if they took the cost of the government's proposals for improved maternity rights into account, the society says. Its intervention comes as ministers are beginning preparations on Labour's next election manifesto, which is expected to make an eight-week extension of maternity leave the centrepiece of a strategy to woo women voters.

"Every extension of maternity rights that is not matched by an equivalent extension of paternity rights is a step in the wrong direction.

"Every such move gives employers a rational reason to choose Bob over Mary and seals half the workforce into the 'woman-equals-mother-equals-carer' trap," the society says, in the first report of a series entitled Future Provocations.

Unlike many previous criticisms of equal opportunities policies, which have come from a rightwing free market perspective, it was written by Richard Reeves, a former adviser to Labour ministers and left-leaning journalist.

He said last night: "For the first time in the 49 year history of A-levels, girls have gained a higher proportion of the top three grades than boys. But that success is not going to translate into workplace success unless we break down the roles attached to motherhood and fatherhood.

"The government, the equal opportunities commission, the TUC and most groups campaigning for parents all make the same mistake of thinking that the pay gap between men and women is irrational and some stern talking will do the trick. In fact, given the current policies and gender roles, it is entirely rational - and no amount of talking will do the trick."

The report includes the results of a survey of parents showing that 68% of mothers were usually called first if a child was ill, compared to 13% of fathers.

The society is calling for parental leave to be paid at 90% of wages for six weeks, arguing that if the government were to offer a flat rate of around £150 a week, high income fathers would not be encouraged to take time off to look after their children.

"By and large, it is better-off men who run businesses and therefore set the tone for organisations in terms of the acceptability of time off for childcare. There is little hope of attitudes changing if the men dictating workplace cultures are not taking time off," the report says.

Last night the government denied its policies were biased towards protecting women at work.

A Cabinet Office spokeswoman said: "This government has done more than any other government to ensure that both mothers and fathers can effectively balance their work and home lives."

"It is nonsense to suggest that women's role as mothers makes them less attractive to employers."

"More women are working than ever before, making up nearly half the workforce - double the number 25 years ago. Since 1980 the proportion of mothers with children under five who are in paid work has increased from 28% to 53%."

She added: "Women's skills are vital to the success of UK plc. Businesses recognise that it is in the interests of their bottom line to ensure that women reach their full potential.

"Good, successful companies recognise that if they offer flexible working practices they will get a more loyal and motivated workforce - this will increase their productivity and give them a competitive edge.

"Both women and men are demanding a better balance between work and home life. That is why the government has started a review looking at how working parents - both men and women - can be given more choice to help them balance their work and family life."

webTitle: Film: Life Doesn't Scare Me

fields.headline: Life Doesn't Scare Me
fields.standfirst:
Lumière ****
Special report: the Edinburgh festival 2000
fields.trailText: Lumière ****
fields.body:
There's a strong 70s flavour about Noémie Lvovsky's female coming-of-age film - and not just because its four young heroines grow up wearing flares and cheesecloth. Continuing the adventures of the characters from her earlier movie Petites, Lvovsky has made a ragged scrapbook of a film - an assemblage of snapshots from the lives of four teenage girls, whom it follows from the age of 13 through school and into early adulthood.

Rather than a continuous story line, Lvovsky gives us vignettes. We follow the girls through the agonies of first crushes and bad hairdos, through the fine art of fending off advances from holiday Romeos, and in one girl's case, through the trauma of having a disturbed mother (played with typically edgy brio by face-to-watch Valeria Bruni-Tedeschi).

No sequence outstays its welcome, and Lvovsky never denies herself any idea, no matter how off-the-wall. Some of her tricks, such as the odd burst of animation, are awkward, but mostly the humour is insightful and infectious, and the school sequences, like Grange Hill done à la Feydeau, are recklessly funny. Lvovsky's four young stars - Magali Woch, Ingrid Molinier, Julie-Marie Parmentier and Camille Rousselet - create their characters with gusto. Dazzling stuff - to be continued?

Ends tonight. Box office: 0131-623 8030.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable
** Mediocre * Terrible

webTitle: US rates kept on hold

fields.headline: US rates kept on hold
fields.standfirst: Fed maintains close watch on booming economy
fields.trailText: The US central bank kept the cost of borrowing unchanged yesterday but continued to warn about inflationary dangers in a fast-growing economy.
fields.body:
The US central bank kept the cost of borrowing unchanged yesterday but continued to warn about inflationary dangers in a fast-growing economy.

The Federal Reserve Board left the main interest rate unchanged at 6.5%, its highest level since 1991. The Fed, which last lifted rates in May, increased them six times in 14 months to rein back inflation.

Yesterday's statement maintained that intent by warning of "heightened inflationary pressures in the foreseeable future".

The widely expected statement left Wall Street largely unmoved. Although the Dow Jones index of blue-chip stocks and the technology-driven Nasdaq Composite wavered for minutes after the announcement, they rallied rapidly. The Dow was up more than 80 points by mid-afternoon in New York and the Nasdaq was up about 40 points at just under the psychologically important 4,000 barrier.

The Fed meets one more time before the US presidential elections in November. Analysts are divided about whether it will increase the cost of borrowing so close to such an important political event. Yesterday's statement left the option open if consumers continue to spend and prices go up.

The Fed said productivity gains had continued to hold back prices in spite of signs of wage increases and higher oil prices. Productivity grew by an annualised 5.3% in the second quarter.

The euro fell to a two-week low against the dollar yesterday after new figures cast doubt on the strength of the Germany economy. The country's closely watched Ifo business sentiment index fell to 99.1 in July from 100.4 in June, confounding predictions of a rise.

Analysts said the unexpected weakness of the index was unlikely to deter the European Central Bank from raising interest rates further to damp inflationary pressures but did make the market question the size of future moves.

"The undershooting of the Ifo just pulled the rug out from under the euro," said Stacey Seltzer, foreign exchange economist at Brown Brothers Harriman in New York.

In early morning trading, the euro slipped to 89.56 cents, its lowest level since May 22.

The euro also came under pressure against sterling, which hit a one-week high of 60.30p.

webTitle: Get your pay level into line

fields.headline: Tricks of the trade
fields.standfirst:
The best time to get your pay level into line

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: The best time to get your pay level into line
fields.body:
Michael Laing, 32 sales director

The best way to get your salary in line is to collect as much evidence as possible that you're doing a good job. I've got testimonials from clients and congratulatory letters from senior members of staff, and they give credibility to any arguments about pay levels. It means you can discuss the situation with your boss in a positive way. Rather than just saying look at all these marvellous things people have said about me, ask your boss to help you understand why other people are earning more. I did that recently in my job and got my pay level to where it should be.

Jane Caillon, 28 area manager

A new boss came into my organisation when I was on maternity leave and after three months back, I found out I was on less money than new recruits. I was furious and confronted my boss who calmly explained that the company didn't have enough money to bring everyone's salaries into line immediately but that I would get two increases a year to bring my salary up. I found out later that other long-serving members of staff were still on the same level as me. Next time I'm going to do some research before I talk to my boss and try to see the organisation's point of view.

Sharon Price, 37 IT account manager

The best time to get your pay level into line is when you're joining a company. It's important to start from a position of strength. The job I applied for offered £40,000 a year but I ended up negotiating £52,000. I asked how the salary was made up and 50% of it was a bonus based on sales. As the bonus wasn't guaranteed, I was taking a basic pay drop. I told the company at interview that if they couldn't provide me with that bonus, I would be disadvantaged. They said the magic words: everything is negotiable and I got the starting salary I wanted. You have to push for more pay at the start.

Alison Parker, 39 chief executive

In a former job I found out that somebody on the same level as me had a higher salary. I'd only just joined the company and I found out that this man had been in the job for a lot longer than me and was at the top of the salary scale for that level. He had a lot more experience and was basically more valuable to the company. My advice is to be patient. I was at the bottom of my pay level but I knew I would be moving fast through the company. As I proved my worth, my pay levels increased so that I was on the right money for my position in the organisation.

Simon Bates, 30 financial executive

A good time to discuss pay levels is during annual reviews. If people get a rise, they are more likely to mention it then. It's dangerous to snoop because if you get found out, it won't do you any favours. It's dangerous to make comparisons too, because companies often tailor pay to the individual - some might go for benefits, others for more basic pay. Don't make assumptions either. I used to work with a man who drove a Mercedes, so I was sure he was paid more than me. Later I heard he'd bought it with redundancy money from a previous job.

webTitle: Classical: Philharmonia/Ashkenazy

fields.headline: A battle played out
fields.standfirst:
Philharmonia/Ashkenazy
Royal Festival Hall, London ***
fields.trailText:
Philharmonia/Ashkenazy
Royal Festival Hall, London ***
fields.body:
The combination of Evgeny Kissin and Vladimir Ashkenazy in Beethoven's Third Piano Concerto could have proved fairly unbeatable. They are Beethovenians of stature: Ashkenazy has recorded the work three times, as soloist and conductor, while the composer is similarly central to the mercurial Kissin's repertoire. You feel the pair of them should have got it right - yet the performance took ages to cohere, and at times there was a colossal disparity in approach.

Ashkenazy's drive towards elegance and restraint sits uneasily with Kissin's fiery intensity. Ashkenazy favours large orchestral forces, but keeps the voltage down during the long introduction. We seem to be heading towards an inherently classical interpretation, but from the moment Kissin enters, his opening phrases lurching upwards with fiercely stroppy hauteur, we're jolted into very different territory. Thereafter, pianist and conductor seem almost in opposition, rendering the tone of the whole uncertain. Kissin's cadenza, dazzlingly flamboyant and weighty, pushes us into dark Romanticism.

When we get to the slow movement, it all mercifully comes together. Kissin is wonderfully moody and rhapsodic, sometimes approaching a well-nigh perfect limpidity of utterance. Ashkenazy finally broadens the orchestral sound into genuine lushness, with some gorgeous string playing and caressing woodwind solos. The finale, bracing and exhilarating, dazzles from the start to finish. Kissin's starry status is such that the audience went wild the moment it was over and wouldn't let him go until he'd given us an encore, one of Brahms's Hungarian Dances, flung out with boyish exuberance.

After the interval, Ashkenazy essayed Mahler's Ninth Symphony, another performance that roused mixed feelings. He pitches the emotional level extremely high - this is not so much a painful farewell to life as a desperate clinging to a fading existence. The approach is, of course, valid, and one that many other conductors have adopted. The problem, however, is a certain sameness of tone, an unremitting hysteria throughout. The whole needs more variegation of mood, more moments of respite and lyricism, if its full tragic stature is to be felt.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable
** Mediocre * Terrible

webTitle: Film: Hamlet

fields.headline: Hamlet
fields.standfirst:
UGC Megaplex ****
Special report: the Edinburgh festival 2000
fields.trailText: UGC Megaplex ****
fields.body:
For the film festival's surprise movie, this really was a surprise - not the usual blockbuster, but a classy experiment from one of the more wayward US independent directors. Until now, Michael Almereyda has been a marginal figure. Shakespeare is the last thing you'd expect from him, especially in a version as polished and elegant as this.

This is what screen Shakespeare should be - an imaginative reworking of a familiar story, and a brisk new dialogue brokered between text and visuals. It is set in modern Manhattan and Elsinore has become the Denmark Corporation. Heir to the throne, or rather the chair, is Ethan Hawke's bohemian slacker prince, who never delivers a soliloquy without his camcorder to hand. Polonius, played by Bill Murray in his driest turn yet, is an old hand who doesn't have the killer boardroom instinct to survive.

Almereyda's reading is a crisp commentary on our over-familiarity with the Hamlet myth - hence a narcissistic prince playing back his dry run for "To be or not to be" on his DVD machine before he delivers the speech for real.

Hawke's cool urbanite prince is the film's weak link. More impressive is Julia Stiles as a smart college-girl Ophelia. This suave, concise Hamlet is an impressive achievement. And the corporate Elsinore is so boldly conceived that it feels churlish to point out that Finnish maverick Aki Kaurismaki got here first with Hamlet Goes Business, set in the boardroom of a rubber-duck factory.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable
** Mediocre * Terrible

webTitle: Revealed: the management millionaires made in Britain.

fields.headline: Lea defends 'pay madness'
fields.standfirst: Revealed: the management millionaires made in Britain. Day two of our exclusive survey
fields.trailText: The spiralling pay of top executives was a "bit mad" one top industry representative admitted yesterday, amid speculation that the government is about to water down plans to give shareholders greater powers to regulate boardroom pay.
fields.body:
The spiralling pay of top executives was a "bit mad" one top industry representative admitted yesterday, amid speculation that the government is about to water down plans to give shareholders greater powers to regulate boardroom pay.

Ruth Lea, head of the policy unit at the Institute of Directors, responding to the Guardian-Inbucon survey of boardroom rewards, said that while the pay rises were "a bit mad" that was how "markets worked."

"Markets are not moral things," she said. "It is like what's happening in the football league. It's the way the international markets work these days."

The way the survey highlighted salaries of directors of FTSE 100 companies rising four times faster than the average increase for other employees prompted angry reactions from trade unions, who called for similar rises for public sector workers.

Sir Ken Jackson, general secretary of the AEEU engineering union, said: "As always, there is no clear correlation between pay and performance (in the boardroom)."

News that more than 110 executives in the FTSE earned £1m last year, prompted John Edmonds, general secretary of the GMB, to call for "lottery win" rises for nurses, doctors and teachers.

Mr Edmonds is expected to reiterate his comments at the annual Trades Union Congress next month in the presence of the chancellor, Gordon Brown. He said: "If company directors are to be rewarded annual lottery wins to ensure Britain's boardrooms retain the best then so be it. But presumably we will now see the government extend that to the public sector so we can also retain the best nurses, the best policemen and the best teachers."

The survey of 85 companies in the FTSE 100 stirred fresh controversy about the Department of Trade and Industry's plans to give shareholders a new opportunity to vote on the remuneration policies of companies, which many senior industry sources had expected to be announced before now.

A new surge in investor activism, particularly the furore caused at the £10m bonus received by Vodafone's chief executive, Chris Gent, is expected to persuade the trade secretary, Stephen Byers, that further powers for shareholders are unnecessary when he makes a statement on the issue in the coming weeks.

Ms Lea noted the importance of share options in remuneration packages, one of the main features in the deals of those executives in this year's league who received more than £1m last year.

She pointed out that top executives from leading companies had been recruited from abroad, including Matt Barrett from Canada to run Barclays and Rod Eddington from Australia at British Airways. "There is a shortage of these people. There has been quite a catastrophic turnover. It's like a transfer list in football," she said.

The Guardian-Inbucon survey is based on information contained in the annual reports of companies in the FTSE at the end of June this year. NatWest's last annual report before its takeover by Royal Bank of Scotland is included.

The pay of executive directors from 85 companies has been analysed by professional consultants who needed to make their own interpretation of some data in the reports and accounts. The calculations of compensation for the financial year include base salary, termination payments, deferred bonus scheme payments in cash or shares, the release of awards from long-term incentive plans and gains on options exercised. Options or share awards granted during the year are not included.

webTitle: Employers not impressed

fields.headline: Employers not impressed
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Office staff who work long hours, invite the boss to their parties and steal workmates' ideas are damaging their chances of promotion.
fields.body:
Office staff who work long hours, invite the boss to their parties and steal workmates' ideas are damaging their chances of promotion.

So too are employees who get involved in all the office gossip while at the same time trying to be on everyone's side.

Employers, it was revealed yesterday, are most suspicious of the workers who are first in and last out of the office.

These staff might be trying to impress with such public displays of dedication but it seems they would not succeed. Indeed, eight in 10 employers in a staffing agency's survey thought such commitment was simply a sign of someone who could not do their job quickly enough or was being mismanaged and given too much to do.

Getting one's employer to come round for dinner or taking them to a football match or party was also unlikely to work, said the report by Office Angels. One in 10 executives did not trust social invitations from the staff, the survey of 1,500 employers by the recruitment firm found.

Two-thirds of employers liked a competitive atmosphere, wanted "team players" and preferred those who stayed away from the gossip. Underhand tactics might be admired by some employers but were seen by most as part of a "me" instead of "us" culture, which did not work in most workplaces.

About three in four employers believed that most attempts to impress them, such as trying to present someone else's idea as one's own, were misguided.

But ambitious staff still thought working long hours was the key to success and did not realise that their employers saw it rather differently. More than seven in 10 employees believed they would be rewarded for working longer than their colleagues.

Office Angels said that executives were looking for other qualities, such as a considerate and positive attitude, and fixing rather than causing problems. They also preferred those who steered well away from office gossip, the report said.

Paul Jacobs, Office Angels' corporate communications director, said that management preferred the team players to the solo stars.

"People want to be seen as individuals and so they are constantly thinking of new ways to stand out from the crowd, though they would be naive to think that underhand tactics go unnoticed," he said. "But taking positive action can be healthy and aid productivity, and should in the long-run aid promotion."

webTitle: Classical: Budapest Festival Orchestra/Fischer - Edinburgh festival

fields.headline: Budapest Festival Orchestra/Fischer
fields.standfirst:
Usher Hall *****
Special report: the Edinburgh festival 2000
fields.trailText: Usher Hall *****
fields.body:
This was the highlight of the international festival's orchestral series so far. Ivan Fischer's Budapest Festival Orchestra played Bruckner's Symphony No 0 with all the sweep and passion that Bruckner thought the piece lacked. (Bruckner half rejected the symphony, hence its apparently nonsensical title.) In Fischer's performance, the first movement, from inchoate D minor murk to strident chorale, had all the power of later Bruckner symphonies.

The Budapest players' enthusiasm and finesse were enough to make Symphony No 0 convince on its own terms. The slow movement had some of the intensity of Bruckner's great adagios, while Fischer's finale hinted at the monumentality of future works.

Fischer's interpretation of Mahler's Todtenfeier, a version of the first movement of his Second Symphony, was no less searing. The conductor took his players up to, and sometimes beyond, their limits of technical endurance in revealing Mahler's terrifying vision of mortality. But the Budapest orchestra surpassed themselves in the third scene of the third act of Wagner's Die Walküre. With Bryn Terfel compelling as the emotionally tortured Wotan, and Anne Evans a radiant Brünnhilde, this was a magnificent performance.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable

webTitle: Classical: Schuman Chamber Music III

fields.headline: Schuman Chamber Music III
fields.standfirst:
Queens Hall/ Radio 3 *****
Special report: the Edinburgh festival 2000
fields.trailText: Queens Hall/ Radio 3 *****
fields.body:
In the third of a series of Schumann concerts given by Andras Schiff and colleagues, the soprano Juliane Banse tackled the cycle Frauenliebe und -leben in a joyously musical way, making no apologies for the unsubtle emotional world of the texts but polishing every phrase until it gleamed. She sang the rarely heard Poems of Mary Stuart too - these are late, almost suffocatingly internalised settings that inhabit a touchingly tragic world.

Schiff is a Lieder accompanist of rare distinction and a chamber player who leads by example: always watchful, always responsive to what his partners are doing. He supported the cellist Miklos Perenyi in the Five Pieces in Folk Style, and took charge of a wonderfully revealing account of the strange G minor Piano Trio. The violinist Yuuko Shiokawa has no pungent musical personality to match her colleagues' - a few passages in the trio were awfully plain - but her rapport with them was sufficient to lift this performance well above the routine.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable
** Mediocre * Terrible

fields.headline: Deeper limelight
fields.standfirst:
Valparaiso
The Crypt, Dublin Castle ***
fields.trailText: No doubt inspired by being interviewed to death every time he publishes another Great American Novel, Don De Lillo's third play, which premiered in the US last year, is a satire of multichannel media familiar to science-fiction fans, in which live TV and capitalism engulf us completely, right down to our "shitmost selves".
fields.body:
No doubt inspired by being interviewed to death every time he publishes another Great American Novel, Don De Lillo's third play, which premiered in the US last year, is a satire of multichannel media familiar to science-fiction fans, in which live TV and capitalism engulf us completely, right down to our "shitmost selves".

The premise is absurdist: a businessman, Michael Majeski, intends to travel to Valparaiso, Florida, but mistakenly flies to Chicago. Somehow, this propels him into an avalanche of media interviews, all trying to get inside his airborne moment of realisation, each all but replicating the last. Each scene is an interview. Majeski quits his job and devotes himself to the limelight, enduring the bruising cynicism of his interviewers, or flirting with a young female journalist. Like something out of a JG Ballard novel, his life has suddenly become "luminous" in quality; pain is more intense, every thought charged with significance.

The scenario spirals in intensity in the second act: one long final scene, when Majeski and his wife Livia appear on the global daytime talk show hosted by the odious Delfina Treadwell (played with reptilian allure by Emma Lowe), and her co-presenter, the demoniacal Teddy Hoddell - a part made for Niall O Sioradain.

From here on De Lillo's colourless, odourless dialogue deliquesces into manic lyricism as Majeski's mind melts down: grinding through the miserable "sex stripped of culture" with his wife, his suicidal episode on the airplane, and worse. The language is extraordinary, even if it's not the most easily staged in the world, and the Greek chorus device is awkward and anachronistic.

As Majeski, Gerry O'Brien puts across an interesting mix of anonymity and bewilderment, while Niamh O'Shaughnessy gives a chilly performance as Livia. Under John O'Brien's direction, the veteran Iomha Ildanach company somehow crack the profound alienation of the piece, although the last scene lacks rhythm at times, and could have been pared back. For all that, this is a solid, head-on rendering of a contemporary paranoid nightmare.

Until August 26. Box office: 003531-6713387

** Mediocre * Terrible
fields.bodyText: No doubt inspired by being interviewed to death every time he publishes another Great American Novel, Don De Lillo's third play, which premiered in the US last year, is a satire of multichannel media familiar to science-fiction fans, in which live TV and capitalism engulf us completely, right down to our "shitmost selves". The premise is absurdist: a businessman, Michael Majeski, intends to travel to Valparaiso, Florida, but mistakenly flies to Chicago. Somehow, this propels him into an avalanche of media interviews, all trying to get inside his airborne moment of realisation, each all but replicating the last. Each scene is an interview. Majeski quits his job and devotes himself to the limelight, enduring the bruising cynicism of his interviewers, or flirting with a young female journalist. Like something out of a JG Ballard novel, his life has suddenly become "luminous" in quality; pain is more intense, every thought charged with significance. The scenario spirals in intensity in the second act: one long final scene, when Majeski and his wife Livia appear on the global daytime talk show hosted by the odious Delfina Treadwell (played with reptilian allure by Emma Lowe), and her co-presenter, the demoniacal Teddy Hoddell - a part made for Niall O Sioradain. From here on De Lillo's colourless, odourless dialogue deliquesces into manic lyricism as Majeski's mind melts down: grinding through the miserable "sex stripped of culture" with his wife, his suicidal episode on the airplane, and worse. The language is extraordinary, even if it's not the most easily staged in the world, and the Greek chorus device is awkward and anachronistic. As Majeski, Gerry O'Brien puts across an interesting mix of anonymity and bewilderment, while Niamh O'Shaughnessy gives a chilly performance as Livia. Under John O'Brien's direction, the veteran Iomha Ildanach company somehow crack the profound alienation of the piece, although the last scene lacks rhythm at times, and could have been pared back. For all that, this is a solid, head-on rendering of a contemporary paranoid nightmare. Until August 26. webTitle: Comedy: The Slacker's Opera - Edinburgh festival

fields.headline: The Slacker's Opera
fields.standfirst:
Pleasance Upstairs ***
Special report: the Edinburgh festival 2000
fields.trailText: Pleasance Upstairs ***
fields.body:
Julian Fox is the Royal Shakespeare Company's stage-door keeper but here he gets his 15 minutes of fame by musing on the exorbitant price of tuna sandwiches and showing us his holiday snaps - taken on the Jubilee Line extension. Fox would like to be Madonna, but he has hardly got the energy to get up in the morning, let alone sing. This quarter of an hour is wafer thin and not everyone will fall for its surreal, quirky charm. Not everyone will even find it funny. But I did. Fox delivers his lines with a deadpan charm and there is something engagingly honest about a show that is about a man who does not know what to do with his life and is prepared to admit it in a world where everyone is busy, busy, busy.

Till Sunday. Box office: 0131-226 2428.

webTitle: Art: Shirin Neshat

fields.headline: Shirin Neshat
fields.standfirst:
Fruitmarket Gallery ****
Special report: the Edinburgh festival 2000
fields.trailText: Fruitmarket Gallery ****
fields.body:
Iranian artist Shirin Neshat's Soliloquy, a new double-screen colour film, and Turbulent, her trilogy of double-screen films also showing at London's Serpentine Gallery, form the best contemporary art show in Edinburgh.

Soliloquy, with Neshat as the protagonist, presents a kind of abstracted view of the artist's own position as an Iranian living in the US. She is not, she has said, an exile so much as "distanced" from her homeland. Yet exile she is. Two screens, two cultures: Soliloquy finds the artist in both the ancient town of Mardin in southern Turkey (itself a place of political and cultural dispute) and a generic American cityscape. She appears to belong in neither place; Soliloquy dramatises her position. Neshat stands at a window, overlooking American rail tracks and urban highways; and she appears at a window in Mardin, overlooking a courtyard. She flees across a barren Turkish landscape, and runs along a bleak, deserted American sidewalk. Compared with the brevity, power and formal complexities of Turbulent, Soliloquy's metaphors are a little obvious, the poetry strained.

Till September 23. Details: 0131-225 2383.

** Mediocre * Terrible

webTitle: AltaVista climbs down over unmetered access

fields.headline: AltaVista climbs down
fields.standfirst:
Americans abandon unmetered net access for 274,000 and blame BT for fiasco

Net news

Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: Internet portal AltaVista was forced into an embarrassing climbdown yesterday when the company announced it would not launch its much-vaunted unmetered internet access package, blaming rival BT for its failure.
fields.body:
Internet portal AltaVista was forced into an embarrassing climbdown yesterday when the company announced it would not launch its much-vaunted unmetered internet access package, blaming rival BT for its failure.

AltaVista and BT traded blows after the American group decided to pull its service that had signed up 274,000 customers. AltaVista's unmetered service was to be at an initial annual fee of £60.

The American company said it could not risk subsidising a free, unmetered package for customers while BT charged it by the minute.

"The whole industry is a fiasco. A lot of people are dependent on BT for this service. Altavista alongside other companies are the symptom of, not the cause of, the problem," Andy Mitchell, Altavista's managing director in Britain said.

Mr Mitchell admitted he was "absolutely remiss" in not telling people sooner about the problems.

BT denied that its charging structure was to blame, saying that it offered a deal which was compliant with the law.

Altavista's package, which appeared to offer unlimited surfing time, was endorsed by the prime minister when it was first announced in March and many experts predicted a rash of similar offers from rival internet companies.

Unmetered access packages have proved a problem for many, though. Lineone, and Callnet0800 have scrapped their unmetered packages, while Virgin.net's has been delayed. "It is very difficult to plan a business, with the delaying tactics of BT," said Mr Mitchell.

Freeserve and World Online are both currently offering unmetered packages, however. World Online UK chief executive Simon Preston said: "I think they [AltaVista] have been a little disingenuous. We are all waiting for a flat rate that's unmetered."

AltaVista is advising the thousands of people who signed up for the service to opt for one of its other offers. These either restrict how long users can stay online, or ask them to pay their telephone charges.

The portal has also called for a meeting with Oftel, the industry regulator, next week to complain about BT's behaviour. Their view found some support from the Consumers' Association who said BT's pricing regime made it difficult for ISPs to offer customers the best deal.

A BT spokesman dismissed AltaVista's claims. "We believe that it is absolute nonsense. BT has had a flat rate whole sale package on the table since June 1 which is fully Oftel compliant."

Analysts suggested that AltaVista's withdrawal was prompted by its realisation that unmetered access would not make them money.

CMGI, the parent of AltaVista, also said earlier this month that it wanted to acquire ISPs in Europe which could include Britain. This may also have influenced AltaVista's decision, said some observers.

Telecommunications regulator Oftel said it had was surprised at Alta Vista's grievance with BT.

It said that the American group had made no official complaint. AltaVista said it would be seeking discussions with the regulator shortly.

David Edmonds, Oftel's director general, said: "It is disappointing to see AltaVista withdraw from the market. But competition is rapidly developing and other companies are already offering unmetered services to consumers."

webTitle: Sainsbury 'seeking £1bn for DIY chain'

fields.headline: Sainsbury 'seeking £1bn for DIY chain'
fields.trailText: Sainsbury, the supermarket group, is sounding out potential buyers for its home improvements business Homebase, which it believes should net more than £1bn, according the Financial Times last night.
fields.body:
Sainsbury, the supermarket group, is sounding out potential buyers for its home improvements business Homebase, which it believes should net more than £1bn, according the Financial Times last night.

The company has sent out documents listing details of the Britain's second largest do-it-yourself retailer to potentially interested parties around the world.

The US's Home Depot and LeRoy Merlin, Europe's third biggest home improvements group, are said to be potential bidders.

Sir Peter Davis, the ailing retailer's new chief executive, is understood to have asked for expressions of interest by the end of next month as part of his strategy of realising shareholder value in the chain that has been consistently outpaced by sector leader Tesco.

Sainsbury also announced yesterday that it planned a £350m expansion of its stores and distribution activities in the West Midlands.

A company spokeswoman said £250m would be allocated to new stores, while the balance would be invested in distribution.

She said it was not possible yet to calculate the number of stores to be opened but all of the outlets would be built on so-called brownfield sites, which had been used for industrial or commercial purposes.

Sainsbury said the expansion would create 2,000 jobs in the stores and 1,000 distribution posts over three years.

The company plans a 700,000 sq ft distribution depot on a 68-acre site bought from regional development agency Advantage West Midlands at Hams Hall, near Coleshill, Warwickshire.

Chris Fenner, director of property, said: "The West Midlands has been earmarked by Sainsbury's for a considerable proportion of the group's total investment in new stores and support facilities.

webTitle: Jazz: McCoy Tyner

fields.headline: Exhausting soulmates
fields.standfirst:
McCoy Tyner
Jazz Cafe, London ****
fields.trailText:
McCoy Tyner
Jazz Cafe, London ****
fields.body:
McCoy Tyner is back in London for a 10th summer at the Jazz Cafe, and if you haven't seen him yet, grab the chance. You've got a treat coming. This man is not just full of musical ideas; he's bursting at the seams. "Listen to the great players, pick up some licks," say teachers of jazz. A pianist like McCoy Tyner can impart enough in three bars to last a year.

Bassist Avery Sharpe and drummer Aaron Scott were both back for another year. The threesome strode down to the stage, immaculately dressed, and launched into the show with a number Tyner wrote for John Coltrane, his inspiration and employer in the 60s. The piece was crashing, chromatic, mercurial, racy - all characteristic of Tyner's mode of attack. He has worked with some great drummers in his time, including Elvin Jones, who is in London next week, but he and Scott seem close musical soulmates, sharing such an intense musical sensibility that when the pianist played tricky solo passages the drummer would trace the notes in reverie.

Next, he pulled out Will You Be Mine? to demonstrate his ability for quick mood changes: from tea dance waltz to Rottweiler bark to music hall gaiety in the slip of a second. In The Tradition, a tune from Tyner's newest CD, had a Latin feel, with Scott in the background weaving quietly perplexing rhythms with his brushes and Sharpe taking his cue from Tyner to wind in growlier ideas on bass guitar.

It can't be easy for Sharpe to stand out, sandwiched between Scott and Tyner, but his double-bass solo in the middle of the set was a class act. He handled it like a guitar, strimming up and down, thwock-thwocking to get a beat going then reverting to banjo-style motion, not just for effect but as a new mode of expression. The only drawback was that to appreciate the music fully you needed to possess nearly as much energy as the band. The venue, with its vaulting acoustic, is fine in every regard except one: it needs more seats for the exhausted.

Until August 26. Box office: 020 7916 6060

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable

webTitle: Dance: Les Lieux De Là - Edinburgh festival

fields.headline: Les Lieux De Là
fields.standfirst:
Edinburgh Playhouse
Special report: the Edinburgh festival 2000
fields.trailText: Edinburgh Playhouse
fields.body:
The curtain goes up on a big black space. There's the sound of a dripping tap and a moaning guitar; dancers play around. All much as you might expect from a night out seeing contemporary dance. But these dancers are powerful. They can put their heads through a cardboard box and the next moment have all the grace of a prima ballerina.

This kind of performance has no hope of filling a 3,000-seat theatre like the Playhouse. It is demanding and long. The choreography, by Mathilde Monnier of the Centre Choréographique National de Montpellier, is harsh, fragmented and brutal. One insect-like dancer hoists her leg up in the air for an unshaking, pregnant three minutes. Another head-bangs the mike and makes music. At times Monnier allows four or five mini-scenarios to play together on stage: monkey-crawling threesomes, elegant solos, aggressive, screaming duos. Then she brings the group together in wonderful huddles or a dark chorus line. Monnier and composer Heiner Goebbels have certainly gone for the hard stuff. How fortunate that the festival sometimes sees fit to show us the other side of popular.

Ends tonight. Box office: 0131-473 2000.

webTitle: Four days into the season and ready for a breather

fields.headline: Four days into the season and ready for a breather
fields.trailText: End-of-season fixture clutter is one thing, first-week-of-the-season congestion is a different kettle of crackpot contrivance.
fields.body:
Come next spring and a desperately close-run thing for the Premiership title, might the losers at Highbury last night roundly and shrilly curse distant August 21 as the day they lost the prize?

But Sky needed a big one to launch its "Monday Match" and to blazes with fairness, tiredness and anything else? End-of-season fixture clutter is one thing, first-week-of-the-season congestion is a different kettle of crackpot contrivance.

Just over 48 hours after tough opening matches on Saturday, Arsenal and Liverpool were matched against each other. The latter's manager Gérard Houllier got his excuses in first: "Players need rest between big matches. It isn't right to play two games so close together, especially as our away fixture at Arsenal is obviously one of our key games of the whole winter."

He has a point. So do spectators. Likewise a knackered performer in August could, for all we know, already have settled who wins rugby union's oval Premiership in the springtime.

With what venom of hindsight then, if the title race is close, might Wasps supporters rue their management's gentlemanly decision to allow their captain and apparently worn-out totem Lawrence Dallaglio to miss the opening weeks of the season.

He watched Saturday's crucial "six-pointer" against the champions Leicester from the Sky production caravan. Just to rub it in for Wasps' followers, four minutes into injury-time - when the London side had the game in the bag - Leicester were wantonly presented with the softest of close-quarter tries to win the match, a score which they are unlikely to have made once in a thousand attempts had the mighty Dallaglio been defending in, and organising, the Wasps back-row.

The same goes for cricket. I happened to be home and able to catch Leicester's injury-time steal on Saturday only because of Headingley's clamorous early wrap-up the evening before in the Test match. As the dust settled on that voluptuously dotty denouement, England's captain Nasser Hussain tossed in the wearily pessimistic throwaway line, suggesting every silver lining has an attendant cloud: "I suppose our counties will now expect us to play for them on Sunday."

At which two answers sprang to mind - certainly they should expect them to, particularly in Essex's case for Hussain, quite lamentably, has not laid bat on ball with the remotest conviction for month upon month while presuming himself a shoo-in permanency in the Test team. And secondly, you bet they do, for the counties are their employers, aren't they?

Well, actually they are not any more. When the England and Wales Cricket Board issued contracts to the alleged top 12 Test players in the spring, it effectively became their employers. The move was generally hallelujahed at the time by those reckoned to be in the know, but the jury is still out on its effectiveness.

We must wait to see how the England Test team fares against Pakistan, Sri Lanka, and Australia in the next 12 months. Victories against the comparative weeds of Zimbabwe and West Indies are scarcely true measure, but one thing is sure: in the next few weeks the contract system is going to be seen to make a ludicrous mockery of English domestic cricket.

With the England management demanding a September holiday for their "over-tired" players, the introduction of promotion and relegation with two divisions in the County Championship is, at its very first time of asking, fast on the way to being written off as wretchedly unfair and laughably worthless.

No, however much Hussain needs practice in the middle, he did not turn out for Essex on Sunday. But Yorkshire's three England heroes did, as did Somerset's Marcus Trescothick and Worcestershire's Graeme Hick - all five playing crucial Sabbath title matches.

But that will be it, just about, for them with their counties - even though the championship and Sunday league matches continue past mid-September. The most crucial championship game of the summer could well be Yorkshire's top-of-the-table 40-pointer against Surrey at Scarborough next week. But neither side's Test men will be playing and after that, of course, they will be "resting" for the final two rounds of matches.

It makes a sham and a fantasy of fair competition. As Warwickshire's coach Bob Woolmer says: "Two divisions, relegation and promotion, but teams bereft of their best players? It makes the whole exercise almost pointless."

webTitle: A Eurocrat to force Fifa's hand

fields.headline: A Eurocrat to force Fifa's hand
fields.standfirst: Race to head off transfer doomsday
fields.trailText: Andrew Osborn in Brussels on the man who will ultimately make the decision.
fields.body:
The future of the European transfer system will ultimately be decided by a softly spoken Italian economist living in Belgium, and the signs are that he is running out of patience.

Mario Monti, the European Union's competition commissioner, threatened earlier this month to pull the plug on the current transfer rules of Fifa, football's world governing body, unless they are changed soon.

His opinion seems uncompromisingly clear when he says: "International transfer fees based on arbitrarily calculated fees should be prohibited." But aides say the silver-haired Eurocrat does not want to see the transfer market turned into a free-for-all, where players can break existing contracts without any consequences.

Monti is known for his willingness to take tough decisions and has proved in the past he is not afraid of taking unpopular ones.

He killed off duty-free shopping in the face of fierce opposition from ferry operators and airports, and has more recently held up the European red card to a big American telecoms merger which he believed would have reduced competition. He is Europe's most powerful deal-breaker and his threats must be taken seriously.

Officials close to the transfer case say that if Fifa does not draft a new set of rules "in the coming months", Monti will act.

webTitle: Race to head off transfer doomsday

fields.headline: Race to head off transfer doomsday
fields.standfirst: The man who will make the decision
fields.trailText: The football authorities are racing against time to save the professional game from chaos. That may sound an exaggeration but it is not. By the end of next month their tormentors' patience will have run out.
fields.body:
The football authorities are racing against time to save the professional game from chaos. That may sound an exaggeration but it is not. By the end of next month their tormentors' patience will have run out.

The villain of the piece is the European Union. About a year ago they made it known that they were unhappy with players being sold in mid-contract for huge transfer fees.

The Treaty of Rome guarantees workers free movement within the European Union. Footballers are workers, the EU argues. High transfer fees are an obstacle to that free movement. So they asked Fifa, the world game's governing bidy, to change the system.

Fifa dallied, appearing contemptuous of EU law. But the more it dallied the more the EU lost patience until recently they threatened simply to rule the current transfer system illegal. That would see clubs legally refusing to pay any transfer fee for players joining them.

With such a doomsday scenario in sight, it took football's European governing body, Uefa, with the Premier League, Football Association and Football League in the vanguard, to spot the seriousness of the situation.

Someone needed to head off the EU at the pass with an alternative proposal. So the three domestic bodies and others set up a working party which, by the middle of next month, is confident of coming up with a counter-proposal.

It will first go to Uefa, then to Fifa, which is expected to be only too happy to have some ideas to put forward to the EU by next month's deadline.

Actually Fifa, belatedly, has also been working on its own proposals including, it is understood, a contingency plan to cope with the expected knock-on effect of an end to transfer fees: even higher salaries for players.

According to Christophe Forax, spokesman for the EU commissioner for sport Vivian Reding: "I think Fifa is thinking about a system of salary caps. That would be another bombshell.

Fifa was unavailable for comment yesterday. However, Michael Kennedy, the agent of £52,000-a-week Roy Keane, acknowledges that higher salaries are on the cards: "If the changes go through, it is going to result in players' earnings increasing substantially. So it will be good for the players. But, as for football as a whole, I think it could lead to disruption."

Exactly what kind, is spelled out by the Leeds chairman Peter Ridsdale: "If the threat from the EU to the present transfer system is not stopped, the game will be thrown into chaos. The abolition of the transfer system will undermine the financial viability of every club which has historically developed its own young talent."

It would also remove vital transfer income from smaller clubs. The prospects of many going under as a result is just one reason why the football authorities are working overtime to come up with their damage-limitation plan.

"We are aware the system is under serious threat and of the need for urgent action," says the Premier League spokesman Philip French. "Everyone in England is working together on a solution and we all share the same objectives and are co-operating fully with Uefa and Fifa.

"We are looking to create a dialogue with the [European] Commission giving them a clear understanding of the strengths of the current system and implications of it disappearing without a sensible replacement, while positively examining alternatives to any areas of weakness."

Basically they hope to persuade the EU that footballers' contracts should not be the same as other workers'. For instance, most workers need normally to give only one month's notice to leave. No football competition can be run on that basis.

The football authorities will suggest a year's notice period and hope they can rescue some element of the transfer fee by arguing that money generated from the transfer system goes into community infrastructures such as youth academies.

They also plan a compensation fee based on how long is left on a player's contract and the size of his salary, plus any costs involved in training the player. For example, compensation for Michael Owen would work out at: four years at £35,000 a week = £7.28m.

The EU is willing to make concessions. "We are ready to speak about the specificity of sport," said Forax. "We are not fully considering professional players as normal workers," adding that the EU is "ready to discuss an indemnity for the training for players" and "a transitional period" before any changes are introduced, preventing millions being wiped off players' value overnight.

The EC is also understood to have agreed that one month's notice on a player's contract is unworkable.

webTitle: Leicester reassure Guppy about future

fields.headline: Leicester reassure Guppy about future
fields.trailText: Leicester City's manager Peter Taylor has reassured Steve Guppy he has a future at the club, even though the England winger failed to make it into his 16 for Saturday's visit of Aston Villa.
fields.body:
Leicester City's manager Peter Taylor has reassured Steve Guppy he has a future at the club, even though the England winger failed to make it into his 16 for Saturday's visit of Aston Villa.

Guppy, who immediately hinted that he could be on his way, had talks with the manager yesterday and was told he still has a part to play this season. "This sort of thing is going to happen more and more often now we have a bigger squad," Taylor said.

The 31-year-old, who was picked in England's problem position on the left for last season's friendly with Belgium, said he would knuckle down but made it clear he does not intend to be a squad player.

Roberto Baggio, 33, out of contract and training alone at Internazionale, is still looking for a new club after the French First Division leaders Lens denied an interest. "I can't sell myself for pocket change," he said. "But it's not for economic reasons that I don't have a team. Foreign teams have sought me out with serious offers but I prefer to remain in Italy. It's a life choice."

The Scotland defender Paul Ritchie, 25, has completed a £500,000 move to Manchester City from Rangers, where he failed to play a game after his Bosman move from Hearts. "Paul has signed a four-year contract," said Chris Bird, City's chief operating officer.

Norwich have signed Arsenal's Dublin-born defender Brian McGovern, 20, for £50,000 though the fee will rise to £250 000 when he has played 80 games. And Reading have confirmed the signing of Jamie Cureton, 24, from Bristol Rovers for £250,000. The former Norwich striker scored 22 league goals last season.

Kevin Kyle, the Sunderland forward who impressed in the recent Under-19 Milk Cup, has been named in the Scotland Under-21 squad to face Latvia in Riga on Friday week.

webTitle: King Ferguson's Ruud offer 'too mad for words'

fields.headline: King Ferguson's Ruud offer 'too mad for words'
fields.trailText: In an outburst which possibly served to underscore the pre-eminence of Sir Alex Ferguson in his profession, the Manchester United manager was yesterday accused of behaving like "the king of football".
fields.body:
In an outburst which possibly served to underscore the pre-eminence of Sir Alex Ferguson in his profession, the Manchester United manager was yesterday accused of behaving like "the king of football".

However, any joy Ferguson may have felt at being elevated to his sport's royal family will have been tempered by claims that he was disrespectful and that he had gone beyond accepted standards.

Ferguson's accusers are from the leading Dutch club, PSV Eindhoven. They were incensed by his weekend announcement that he not only intended to resurrect the aborted £18.5m transfer of Ruud van Nistelrooy but that he had invited the striker to spend a month at Old Trafford as part of his rehabilitation.

Van Nistelrooy's move to the Premiership champions was put on hold in April after he failed a medical due to concerns about his knee. Given three weeks to prove his fitness, he sustained a serious injury in training with PSV days later.

Ferguson's invitation to a player he obviously still covets was not well received in Holland where the Eindhoven chairman Harry van Raaij was in a particularly dismissive mood.

"I can hardly believe that Ferguson has made this offer to Ruud," said Van Raaij. "If it is indeed the case, then he has crossed the line of decency. He must be thinking he is the king of football. We have Ruud under contract. We have paid for his operation and we are also continuing to pay his salary.

"It is nonsense that someone who has a contract with us can go to Manchester United for a month and take risks. I cannot imagine how a man with his job - and who is even called a Sir - can say such stupid things." He added that the offer was "too mad for words".

Eindhoven's official spokesman Pedro Salazar-Hewitt also weighed in with some meaty criticism.

"Just who does he think he is?" he thundered. "What is wrong with our training and rehabilitation methods? We think this is all very disrespectful."

On Sunday Ferguson outlined how a spell in the north of England might help Van Nistelrooy's recovery from a ligament injury that had threatened to end his career.

"We invited Ruud to join us in October just because it will be a break from what is going to be a long, hard road back for him," he explained.

Van Nistelrooy's agent Rodger Linse last night insisted that the Scot's offer represented welcome "mental support" for his client. "It's more like a gesture than anything else," he said. "Manchester United have done nothing behind anyone's back."

webTitle: Shock treatment

fields.headline: Shock treatment
fields.standfirst: If your GCSE results are worse, or better, than expected look no further.  Katherine Speed explains what's on offer, whatever your grades
fields.trailText: If your GCSE results are worse, or better, than expected look no further. Katherine Speed explains what's on offer, whatever your grades
fields.body:
Results are out on Thursday and you've probably already made your plans, but what if you don't get the grades you need?

If you haven't applied to college or sixth form yet, it's probably not too late - ring them today for advice, look at prospectuses and check out their websites. If you've already got a place, don't panic if you don't get the grades you need - depending on what grades you end up with, there are plenty of alternatives.

Mainly As and Bs

Maybe you've done better than you expected. If you got mainly As and Bs the choice is yours. If you stay on in the sixth form or go to college you could do AS-levels. From September, most schools and colleges are offering the new Advanced Subsidiary or AS-levels. A bridge between GCSEs and A-levels, you'll take up to five AS-levels in year 12 before carrying two to four of your subjects onto A-level (or A2) in year 13. Entry requirements vary but you'll probably need at least four Cs and some places will ask for Bs.

Choose subjects you will enjoy and do well at and which work together. Because you can do more subjects now, it's easier to combine arts and sciences, which can make you more attractive to universities and employers. Put English, history and philosophy with a biology AS-level or do sciences with one year of an essay-based subject.

If your grades are better than you thought they'd be, talk to your college/sixth form about changing courses, but whatever they offer you, make sure it's something you'll enjoy and which will lead you where you want to go. If you'd been planning to find work, you can still apply to college/sixth form - contact them now, but make sure it's definitely what you want.

Mostly Cs

If you do get mainly Cs, you've done really well and could probably do AS-levels. But think carefully - you might do better on a more practical, vocational course and could do an AS-level as well. Don't forget, Advanced level vocational courses can still lead to university.

Vocational courses are related to career areas so they're practical and give you vital work skills. GNVQ Advanced is being replaced by the Advanced Vocational Certificate of Education (VCE), or Vocational A-level. VCEs will probably ask for at least four Cs and are available in subjects such as business, health and social care, art and science and technology. Equivalent to A-levels, VCEs can lead to university or work.

It's now easier to combine vocational and academic courses - perhaps VCE health and social care with psychology AS-level or engineering with maths. There'll be a range of options available at your school or college and you'll also take key skills such as maths, communications and IT, which will help make you more employable in the future.

Mostly Ds

If you got mainly D grades, look at the GNVQ intermediate. This is a one-year course and afterwards you could go on to do the same subject at a higher level or find a Modern Apprenticeship (see Should I stay or go, below). Or some colleges do full time NVQs - NVQ level 2 is equivalent to four Cs at GCSE.

You could retake GCSEs but think carefully about this - would you be motivated enough to start again and would you really do any better second time around? You'd probably be better off retaking key subjects such as maths, English or science and doing a vocational course as well.

Mostly Es and Fs

Think about a foundation GNVQ or NVQ level 1, which could lead to a job or intermediate course/NVQ 2 next year. Again, beware of doing GCSE resits - most people only improve by one grade and the foundation GNVQ is equivalent to D/E GCSEs anyway.

(In Scotland you'll take Highers or a National Certificate - contact local colleges for more information).

There will also be courses available if you've got special needs or didn't take exams.

Should I stay or go?

If you are disappointed on Thursday, stay calm and talk to school, colleges and careers advisers and you'll find the option that's right for you. The government is encouraging you, too, to stay on at school - its Don't Quit Now programme, managed by the DfEE, aims to help more youngsters stay in full-time education.

However, if you want to find work, look for a Modern Apprenticeship. Available at advanced or foundation level, a Modern Apprenticeship is a job with training where you work and take S/NVQs, practical qualifications that train you for the job you're doing. Advanced apprenticeships may ask for C grades and you might have to sit a test.

They are available in more than 80 different sectors, including accountancy, air transport, insurance and electronic systems. They are advertised through careers centres, where you can also get advice on training schemes if you have special needs or need extra help finding work. For more information, contact the learndirect helpline (0800 100900).

Useful websites

bubl.ac.uk Use this site to find all the colleges and school sixth forms in your area and links to their websites, which will tell you what they offer and how to contact them and apply.

springboard.hobsons.com Use this to find information on careers, courses, options and advice on how to choose.

dfee.gov.uk/iyc It's Your Choice - published by the Department for Education, this explains all the choices available to you at 16, where the different options could lead, what they involve and the grades you'll need.

dfee.gov.uk/dqn.htm This site is easy to use and gives options of earn and learn, foundation modern apprenticeships, NVQ info and numerous options for life after GCSEs.

careers-uk.com This site lists all the careers services in the country. Find your local service and link into their website - you'll find out how to get help and advice and about local opportunities - colleges, school sixth forms, Modern Apprenticeships and jobs.

bbc.co.uk Advice for young people on everything -work, study, travel, money and personal issues.

 Katherine Speed is a careers adviser working for CareerLink, the Careers Service for the West of Lancashire.
