webTitle: Firsts among equals

fields.headline: Firsts among equals
fields.standfirst: The dons are baffled - why do so few women at Oxford get firsts?  Esther Addley (who did) examines the evidence
fields.trailText: The dons are baffled - why do so few women at Oxford get firsts? Esther Addley (who did) examines the evidence
fields.body:
You have to feel a little sorry for the powers that be at Oxford. University bosses must be wondering if they will ever manage to put a foot right. Last week the university had yet another high-profile clobbering in the press, this time over a report examining why women get fewer first-class degrees than men. The reason for the imbalance, the study suggested, was a structural bias in the way exams are marked that favours male candidates.

Particularly unfortunate for the university is the timing of the report, which was published in the same week as girls achieved sparkling results at A-level. Girls now outperform boys at every stage from reception to year 13, but for some reason this trend suddenly reverses if they go to Oxford. While 22% of male candidates at the university got first-class degrees last year, only 17% of women achieved the same result.

It's hardly a new story - the university's failure to achieve gender parity at finals level is reported almost annually. What remains unclear is exactly why the gender gap is still, depressingly, in place. The tentative conclusion of the new study, published in the British Journal of Psychology, is that the way exams are marked at Oxford may favour men since they are perceived to be better at "flair" arguments, which the marking system often explicitly rewards. According to Dr Jane Mellanby, a psychology don at the university and co-author of the report, everything may come down to a man's highly-developed facility for writing "elegant bullshit".

As a woman who left Oxford in the mid-90s with a first in English, I don't feel I experienced prejudice or barriers to academic success at any stage in my university career - or perhaps I, too, am just an elegant bullshitter. The thing that most surprised me about Oxford, in fact, was that, once inside, it was one of the most meritocratic societies I had ever encountered. This is because the system operates at every level on the basis of fierce academic competition.

Teaching groups are markedly smaller than in other universities, so everyone is aware of where they come in the pecking order. If you could succeed within those terms of reference it didn't matter if you were male, female, a rugby lad or a complete misfit.

The colleges are also competing with each other, and I found tutors prepared to offer extraordinary amounts of support to candidates they believed to be borderline firsts. One might choose to see this as cynical self-interest, but it undoubtedly helped me to do well.

It should be manifestly obvious, however, that distilling everything to the point where intelligence - or rather, academic facility - is the only currency of importance creates a pretty brutal environment. If it is true that women are, in general, less well suited to an environment explicitly geared around competition, they may be justified in feeling discriminated against, on this level at least.

Jane Blumer, the sabbatical women's officer at the university's student union, believes women may feel that the collegiate environment, refined over centuries to suit the way male students have worked, is less nurturing to women. "Possibly women feel that they don't belong here, that their place is less assured," she says. "In some colleges, women have only been admitted for 25 years, so you have a lot of catching up to do on the 500 years that the men have been there. If you start off feeling like the new girl it's difficult to adjust the balance over three years."

This impression is backed up by Mellanby's research, which found similar levels of "intelligence" (based on IQ tests) in male and female candidates, but vastly differing levels of confidence. Men expected to do better in their finals, and were prepared to take more risks in the way they revised and responded to exam questions. Women worked harder, but experienced considerably more depression and anxiety.

"Some women feel very at home here," says Blumer, "but others don't. They wonder if their tutor got their name wrong in the admissions procedure, and they haven't got over that by the time finals come along."

In October the university will launch a four-year study into the impact of gender and social factors on admissions and results, which should provide further concrete information and dispense with the need to rely on persuasive, but still often quite anecdotal, impressions as to where Oxford may need to improve its performance.

In the meantime, last week's A-level results may provide a significant clue. The gradual improvement in young women's exam performances at 16 and 18 appears to be loosely tied to the changes to exams over the past 15 years - it is widely accepted that the introduction of GCSEs, which rely more heavily on coursework, has favoured the way girls work - or perhaps disadvantaged boys.

The development of A-levels along similar lines has arguably helped girls at 18 as well. If it is true that women do better when continually assessed, this may explain why the gender gap is particularly pronounced at Oxford, where students are judged almost entirely on their performance in an intensive week of highly pressurised exams.

There is no doubt that Oxford takes the problem seriously - Birmingham University announced last week that it planned to introduce a system where candidates sit their finals anonymously, something that has been standard practice at Oxford for some time.

But the university may be forced to take uncomfortable decisions if the gradual improvement of women's performances up the age-scale does not extend to its own final exams. While the distinction between getting a first and a 2:1 may seem unimportant for most jobs a few years after graduating, the fact that research funding is almost exclusively given to candidates with firsts makes Oxford's gender gap particularly dangerous. Fewer women getting firsts means fewer women becoming academics; the masculine "bias" that comes from having a predominantly male teaching staff will not change unless more women make the top flight.

webTitle: Boffin's break

fields.headline: Boffin's break
fields.standfirst: It's summer, but do top academics know how to relax?
fields.trailText: It's summer, but do top academics know how to relax?
fields.body:
Where does a vice chancellor go on holiday? What does a university principal read on the beach? Do our academic leaders know the meaning of relaxation? In a bid to map out the topography of scholarly detumescence, we have conducted a highly selective and unscientific survey.

Sir Stewart Sutherland, Edinburgh University, vice chancellor

Spent the last weeks of July slashing and burning in his walled garden in the Borders. Hard physical labour at the beginning of the summer, he says, helps him to work off aggression. He then spent a week in Hong Kong (university business) and went to see friends at Princeton.

Summer reading The Way of Death, by Paul Johnson. A crime thriller set in Edinburgh, 2025. Also in his suitcase are volume 2 of Richard Holmes' biography of Coleridge. He is also re-reading Dependent Rational Animals, the philosopher, Alaistair MacIntyre's study of morality and virtue.

Professor Drummond Bone, University of London, principal

The second half of July was spent at his manse in Fife (he's got a walled garden, too) with his wife Vivian and their airedale, Clarissa.

Summer reading Includes a Royal Society study of sustainable development in Europe, and The Man without Qualities, vol 4, by Robert Musil.

Professor Sir John Daniels, Open University, vice chancellor

Spent two weeks cruising the Kennet and Avon Canal. "It is very relaxing and active," he said. "I spend so much time travelling for my job that heading off in a plane doesn't appeal." Afterwards, he took a "semi-holiday" visiting the Open University's first residential school in Spain at Santiago de Compostela.

Summer reading The Social Life of Information by John Seely Brown and Paul Duguid, "partly to review it and partly because it's a very good book". Also, Giles Milton's Nathaniel's Nutmeg, "because all his family are nuts about it".

Professor Phillip Love, Liverpool University, vice chancellor

Currently soaking up the sun in Singapore with his wife, Isobel, then to Bali.

Summer reading A selection of medical and legal novels by authors such as David Baldacci, Patricia Cornwell and John Grisham.

Professor Adrian Smith, Queen Mary and Westfield College, principal

He's off to Cephalonia, the Ionian island made famous by Captain Corelli's Mandolin.

Summer reading Michael Ignatieff's biography of Isaiah Berlin, David Cannadine's Class in Britain, and Gillian Shephard's political memoirs, Shephard's Watch: Illusions of power in British Politics. "It's catch-up time," he explains.

Anthony Giddens, London School of Economics, director

The most hardworking of our sample, Giddens doesn't intend to take a holiday this summer: "I will take some time off to do some reading if I can, but you know what these jobs are like, a bit enveloping," he explains. "I might try to write a book instead - I'd like to write one about Britain, the position of the country at the moment and its likely prospects."

Summer reading It Didn't Happen Here by Seymour Martin Lipset and Gary Marks, about the non-development of socialism in the US.

Professor Rick Trainor, Glasgow University, vice principal (becomes vice chancellor of Greenwich University this autumn)

Three weeks on Squirrel Island with his family. This car-less island off the Maine coast can only be reached by ferry. So Professor Trainor reckons he should have decompressed by the time he gets there.

Summer reading John Campbell's biography of Margaret Thatcher, which he hopes will be "useful for decoding the past and musing about the future".

webTitle: Women outstrip men as victims of smoking

fields.headline: Women outstrip men as victims of smoking
fields.standfirst: Special report: smoking
fields.trailText: Chronic lung disease among women nearly doubled between 1990 and 1997, according to a survey of 500 GPs' surgeries in England and Wales published today.
fields.body:
Chronic lung disease among women nearly doubled between 1990 and 1997, according to a survey of 500 GPs' surgeries in England and Wales published today.

The information, based on analysis of the General Practice Research Database, found there had been a "substantial increase" in the incurable disease in women aged more than 65, with rates in women aged 45 to 65 becoming equivalent to those in older men by 1996.

Alarmingly for the medical profession, rates in women under 45 exceeded those for men under 45 by the mid-1990s - when male rates peaked.

Joan Soriano and Will Maieer, of Glaxo Wellcome Research whose research is published in the journal Thorax, found almost half of 50,000 new cases diagnosed over the seven years were in women.

Although men had the highest prevalence and mortality rates for the disease, overall women experienced the greatest increase in cases.

The researchers said the full effects for women had yet to be seen, as shown by the steady rise in lung cancer. Lung disease is believed to be the fifth most common cause of death worldwide. Dr Soriano said: "Because of the ageing of the population and the cumulative effect of smoking by women, the already evident burden of chronic lung disease in public health is likely to increase in the future.

"Physicians and health care providers need to prepare for this growing burden by ensuring that adequate resources are available to care for these patients.

"Additional education about the effects of tobacco smoking also appears to be needed to promote smoking cessation, especially in younger women." The anti-smoking campaign group ASH warned that the findings highlighted a dangerous trend: "While smoking among men has fortunately been reduced, it has risen in women and this is borne out by these figures.

"Some studies can be just statistical blips, but this seems to be over a long period of time and obviously shows a worrying trend."

Coinciding with publication of this research was a separate survey highlighting the health risks of passive smoking.

A study of 10,000 police officers in Hong Kong found passive smoking greatly increased the amount of time that non-smokers took off work.

Victims of secondhand smoke were also more likely to take medicines and make more visits to the doctor.

Non-smoking men exposed to passive smoking at work for more than a year were twice as likely to take time off, and 30% more likely to have treatment for respiratory symptoms than colleagues in a smoke-free environment.

The results held true even after accounting for levels of passive smoking at home, said researchers writing in the Journal of Epidemiology and Community Health.

Sarah McGhee, of the University of Hong Kong, called for a ban on workplace smoking. "We must take steps to protect not only children but also adults from passive smoking, by ensuring effective bans on smoking in all workplaces and other sites where involuntary exposure occurs."

ASH said: "This study reaffirms the dangers of passive smoking - the only people who doubt it are the tobacco industry.

"With the TUC last year we worked out there are 3m non-smokers in the UK who are subjected to other workers' cigarette smoke."

webTitle: Games officials race to stop pirates showing Olympics on internet

fields.headline: Games officials race to stop pirates showing Olympics on internet
fields.standfirst:
Net news

Special report: Sydney Olympics
fields.trailText: The International Olympic Committee (IOC) has announced that it is to prosecute nearly 2,000 unauthorised Olympic websites and scour the internet for further sites said to be infringing its "property rights" during the Sydney Games.
fields.body:
The International Olympic Committee (IOC) has announced that it is to prosecute nearly 2,000 unauthorised Olympic websites and scour the internet for further sites said to be infringing its "property rights" during the Sydney Games.

The IOC yesterday confirmed that it had filed a lawsuit in the US federal court against more than 1,800 registered internet domain names, but denied the crackdown was motivated by a desire to protect its lucrative TV contract with official US broadcaster NBC.

"The lawsuit is not necessarily linked to the Sydney Games," said an IOC spokeswoman. "We are not trying to punish internet users. But we want to take the names back. The name 'Olympic' should only be used by the IOC." NBC paid $4bn (£2.5bn) for the exclusive rights to televise the Games in the US from 1998 until 2008.

Because of the time difference between Sydney and the US, the NBC coverage will be taped. Prime-time American audiences will watch the Olympics as if live several hours later.

NBC's official website, www.NBCOlympics.com, will also stream footage from the competition with a time delay. Access to its site is restricted to the 4m Americans who have high-speed internet access.

Renegade internet sites broadcasting pirate coverage of the Games could undermine this deal. Mainstream internet broadcasters outside the US, such as the BBC, will be precluded from showing competition footage on their sites because of the IOC-NBC arrangement.

Backed by the United States Olympic Committee (USOC), and the Salt Lake Organising Committee for the Olympic Winter Games of 2002 (SLOC), the IOC said it was pursuing its joint action through the US courts to "take advantage" of US law, where the Anti-cybersquatting Consumer Protection Act (ACPA) was brought in last year.

Sites using the words "Olympic" or "Olympiad" - and foreign equivalents of such names - will be instructed to shut down. Of the 1,800 unauthorised domains named in the IOC's suit, 168 are said to falsely represent an association with the 2000, 2002, 2004 and 2006 Olympic Games, 69 claim to sell tickets or other Games-related services for profit, 43 relate to gambling, and 15 are associated with pornographic material or services.

Richard Pound, IOC's first vice-president and chairman of the IOC marketing commission, said: "These cybersquatters are out there using Olympic properties for their own benefit with no return to the Olympic movement and are damaging the value of those properties. Before the ACPA, we, like so many other organisations, had little recourse."

The move to sue sites registered by individuals who reside in countries outside the US echoes the ongoing attempt by French activists to prosecute Yahoo! for allowing the sale of Nazi memorabilia on its site in France. In both cases prosecutors in one country are attempting to control content held on websites registered in another.

The IOC has hired a special team of "software developers" to search the internet for sites containing content that is infringing what they claim is their "property rights". Once found, the manager of the site will be told to shut the site down.

Amateur athletic enthusiasts and anti-Olympic protest groups could also be targeted under the IOC's action.

People who attend an Olympic event, take an amateur photograph, and upload it to their personal web page could technically face prosecution. However, sources close to the anti-Olympic protest movement - who believe they are threatened by the lawsuit - suggest that the IOC's proposals might be technically unworkable.

It is relatively easy to search for text on the internet using computer software, called "spiders", that is programmed to hunt for key words. But searching for moving images is a different matter. One activist, calling themselves "Predator" and claiming to represent the Sydney Independent Media Centre - who plan to show footage of the planned anti-Olympic protests - said: "The Corporate Games is certainly not about sharing the spirit, it's about getting paid, moving units, market share.

"What they'll do is target their efforts on 'likely competitors' - independent media centres and dot.orgs like it. I will be surprised if people can't block them [IOC]. We see regular search engine spiders in the logs all the time." Nevertheless, sites backing the anti-Olympic protests will be taking few chances. Sources close to the Sydney Independent Media Centre claim that their site is hosted outside Australia and can be moved around the globe at regular intervals.

Sites using the words "Olympic" or "Olympiad" - and foreign equivalents of such names - will be instructed to shut down. Of the 1,800 unauthorised domains named in the IOC's suit, 168 are said to falsely represent an association with the 2000, 2002, 2004 and 2006 Olympic Games, 69 claim to sell tickets or other Games-related services for profit, 43 relate to gambling, and 15 are associated with pornographic material or services. Richard Pound, IOC's first vice-president and chairman of the IOC marketing commission, said: "These cybersquatters are out there using Olympic properties for their own benefit with no return to the Olympic movement and are damaging the value of those properties. Before the ACPA, we, like so many other organisations, had little recourse." The move to sue sites registered by individuals who reside in countries outside the US echoes the ongoing attempt by French activists to prosecute Yahoo! for allowing the sale of Nazi memorabilia on its site in France. In both cases prosecutors in one country are attempting to control content held on websites registered in another. The IOC has hired a special team of "software developers" to search the internet for sites containing content that is infringing what they claim is their "property rights". Once found, the manager of the site will be told to shut the site down. Amateur athletic enthusiasts and anti-Olympic protest groups could also be targeted under the IOC's action. People who attend an Olympic event, take an amateur photograph, and upload it to their personal web page could technically face prosecution. However, sources close to the anti-Olympic protest movement - who believe they are threatened by the lawsuit - suggest that the IOC's proposals might be technically unworkable. It is relatively easy to search for text on the internet using computer software, called "spiders", that is programmed to hunt for key words. But searching for moving images is a different matter. One activist, calling themselves "Predator" and claiming to represent the Sydney Independent Media Centre - who plan to show footage of the planned anti-Olympic protests - said: "The Corporate Games is certainly not about sharing the spirit, it's about getting paid, moving units, market share. "What they'll do is target their efforts on 'likely competitors' - independent media centres and dot.orgs like it. I will be surprised if people can't block them [IOC]. We see regular search engine spiders in the logs all the time." Nevertheless, sites backing the anti-Olympic protests will be taking few chances. Sources close to the Sydney Independent Media Centre claim that their site is hosted outside Australia and can be moved around the globe at regular intervals. webTitle: Sporting 'crown jewels' must stay free to air, EU rules

fields.headline: Sporting 'crown jewels' must stay free to air, EU rules
fields.standfirst: Football Unlimited
fields.trailText: After months of wrangling, European officials have finally approved Britain's list of protected sporting events. The decision means that armchair sporting fans can continue to watch the Wimbledon tennis tournament and the FA Cup final free, without fearing they may be snapped up by subscription channels.
fields.body:
After months of wrangling, European officials have finally approved Britain's list of protected sporting events. The decision means that armchair sporting fans can continue to watch the Wimbledon tennis tournament and the FA Cup final free, without fearing they may be snapped up by subscription channels.

The European Union rejected objections from several other states that Britain's schedule of "listed" events was so long that it was anti-competitive and illegal. In accepting the list - thought to be the longest in Europe - the EU has dismissed the objections of the Kirch media group in Germany, which is partly owned by Rupert Murdoch, Sky's proprieter. The group could challenge the decision in the courts.

Chris Smith, the culture secretary, said: "This agreement means other European community member states are obliged to respect the UK list and ensure that, if their broadcasters buy the exclusive rights to televise these events in the UK, they must give UK free to air channels the opportunity to show them.

"The European commission has made a landmark decision. It has acknowledged it is for each individual member state to decide which events are of major importance.

"It has also accepted that the UK's list of protected events should include the complete finals tournaments for both the soccer World Cup and European Championships."

He added that, while Italy, Germany and Denmark did not include the two international soccer championships in their entirety in their lists, "clear evidence" showed that UK viewers were committed to watching entire tournaments. "The average audience for group matches not involving UK teams in the 2000 European championships was around 4.7m, and in the 1998 World Cup finals about 7m," he said.

Despite the guarantees now offered for what ministers refer to as "crown jewel" events, certain high profile live rights will remain potentially available to subscription broadcasters. These include cover age of Test matches played in England, non-finals played in the Wimbledon tournament, the world athletics championship, cricket World Cup and the Open golf championship.

The list of protected sporting events, maintained under the 1996 Broadcasting Act, is: Olympic Games, Fifa World Cup finals, FA Cup final, Scottish FA Cup final, Grand National, the Derby, Wimbledon tennis finals, European football championships finals, rugby league Challenge Cup final, rugby World Cup final.

Among those where live coverage might still be shown exclusively (provided secondary rights are available to a generally free to air broadcaster) are: Test cricket matches played in England, rounds played at Wimbledon, all other matches in the rugby World Cup finals tournament, Six Nations rugby tournament matches involving home countries, Commonwealth Games, world athletics championship, cricket World Cup (final, semi-finals and matches involving home nations' teams), Ryder Cup golf and the Open golf championship.

webTitle: Vieira off again as three see red

fields.headline: Vieira off again as three see red
fields.standfirst:
Three sent off as Lauren and Henry put Arsenal back on track
Minute-by-minute match report
Wenger defends 'target' man
fields.trailText: Three sent off as Lauren and Thierry Henry put Arsenal back on track.
fields.body:
Patrick Vieira's inability to stay on the field for the duration continues to be a crimson embarrassment for Arsenal. Last night the Frenchman was sent off for the second time in 72 hours to spoil an impressive performance by Arsène Wenger's side as they beat Liverpool in the Premiership for the first time since March 1994.

On Saturday Vieira had been dismissed at Sunderland by Steve Dunn for catching Darren Williams with a retaliatory arm after the midfielder pulled him back by his shirt. Last night the Arsenal player was shown two yellow cards, plus a red, by Graham Poll in the space of four minutes as a game which up to then had been fast and entertaining became fractious and mean.

Vieira has now been sent off six times in his four seasons at Highbury; only Vinnie Jones, now retired, has a worse record. Last night's dismissal, moreover, brought the number of red cards Arsenal players have received under Wenger to 31.

The fact that Poll had earlier reduced Liverpool to 10 men by showing Gary McAllister the red card for a two-footed late tackle on Vieira, and later to nine with his dismissal of Dietmar Hamann for a second bookable offence, was of no consolation to Wenger, who yet again insisted that his fellow countryman had been harshly treated.

Vieira's first caution came in the 70th minute after an incident with Jamie Carragher in which the Liverpool player appeared to catch him with a flailing arm similar to that which led to his departure at the Stadium of Light. On seeing Carragher shown the yellow card, Vieira clearly raised a point of order with Poll but Wenger said his player had been booked for a foul, not dissent.

In the 74th minute Vieira, having already committed another foul, lunged towards Hamann with both feet. The fact that he reached the ball as well as making contact with his opponent did not change Poll's mind about his original intent. Just as McAllister had gone in the 38th minute for a two-footed challenge on Vieira, so Arsenal's troubled French talent followed for what the referee considered a reckless tackle.

Wenger continues to defend Vieira with a loyalty both touching and stubborn. "I would not want to repeat what he said when he came down the tunnel. We are all human and after Saturday's sending-off this was hard to take."

If anything Gérard Houllier, Liverpool's French manager, was more upset about losing McAllister than Wenger was about Vieira. "Watch the TV film and see if you think he should be banned for three games for that," he said. But Poll, without the benefit of hindsight, saw no more innocence in McAllister's challenge than he did in the fouls on Lauren and Robert Pires which led to Hamann's dismissal.

With six cards Liverpool will now be fined £25,000 under the new system which punishes any team getting five cards or more in the course of one match. This will concern Houllier less than a defeat which exposed shortcomings in the side he revived so dramatically last season.

The arguments and counter-arguments about last night's dismissals should not be allowed to obscure the fact that Arsenal's victory quickly confirmed their ability to reorganise after the departures of Emmanuel Petit and Marc Overmars to Barcelona.

From the outset the speed, persistence and swift changes of direction by Lauren, the Cameroon winger signed from Real Mallorca, had an unsettling effect on Liverpool's defence.

In the eighth minute Silvinho's short cross from the left-hand byline found Lauren failing to score with two attempts. But from the subsequent corner, taken by Silvinho, a crowded Sander Westerveld was unable to clear the ball and this time Lauren scored from short range.

Although reduced to 10 men Liverpool, for whom Michael Owen appeared for only the last 20 minutes because of Houllier's tactical reconstruction, achieved more co-ordinated attacks but until Hamann unleashed a swerving drive from 25 yards which David Seaman managed to turn wide the Arsenal goalkeeper had not been seriously disturbed.

Arsenal's second goal arrived in the dying seconds when Pires found Henry in space with a raking crossfield pass. Henry calmly outmanoeuvred a clutch of defenders before scoring at the second attempt after Westerveld had blocked his first shot.

webTitle: Lockerbie man dies on rail line

fields.headline: Lockerbie man dies on rail line
fields.standfirst: Special report: Lockerbie
fields.trailText: Fresh tragedy touched the Scottish town of Lockerbie yesterday when it emerged that a man who lost his parents and sister in the 1988 aircraft disaster, died in hospital after being hit by a works train.
fields.body:
Fresh tragedy touched the Scottish town of Lockerbie yesterday when it emerged that a man who lost his parents and sister in the 1988 aircraft disaster, died in hospital after being hit by a works train.

British transport police are treating the death of Steven Flannigan, which happened near his new home in Heywood, near Trowbridge, Wiltshire, as a suspected suicide.

Mr Flannigan was 14 when falling debris from the exploded Pan Am flight 103 demolished his family home in Sherwood Crescent, killing his parents Tom and Kathleen and his sister Joanne. He survived because he had been visiting a friend's house at the time.

His older brother David, with whom he shared £2.1m compensation, died in mysterious circumstances in Thailand in 1993.

Disaster struck early Friday as Mr Flannigan, returning from a drink with friends near his home, was hit by a slow-moving maintenance train. He was taken to the Royal United hospital in Bath with severe head injuries, but never recovered. He died on Sunday, on his 26th birthday.

Andy Cousins, a British transport police inspector, said Mr Flannigan was thought to have jumped on to the line from a bridge. "There are no suspicious circumstances and it appears to be a suicide."

Mr Flannigan, who moved to Wiltshire four years ago, had just returned from a party in Scotland held for his three-year-old son, Luke.

In a joint statement, his uncle, Lawrence Doolan, and business partner and friend John Boyce, said: "Steve's family and friends are devastated by this tragic accident. A celebration of his own 26th birthday was planned for the weekend. This is the most appaling tragedy. He will be dreadfully missed by his many friends."

Marjory McQueen, a Lockerbie councillor, said: "The town will be absolutely stunned by this news that this family, who have gone through so much, have suffered another death."

His funeral will take place in Lockerbie on Monday.

webTitle: Our debt to Big Brother

fields.headline: Our debt to Big Brother
fields.standfirst:
On how Channel 4's hit show has given us a reason to talk to each other

Special report: Big Brother
fields.trailText: On how Channel 4's hit show has given us a reason to talk to each other.
fields.body:
Someone rang me on Saturday to tell me that they'd heard that the new contestant on Big Brother was taken from a house in Glasgow where Channel 4 kept 10 substitutes in conditions similar to those on the TV show. With no access to TV or newspapers the new housemate would therefore be unaware of information that might give them an unfair advantage - like the fact that Anna is favourite at the bookies to be the winner, or the way the public warmed to Craig when he took on Nasty Nick. You wouldn't have to be Peter Mandelson to extrapolate a game plan from this knowledge of the show's reception.

It sounded very convincing. The fact that it wasn't true is incidental to the thought-provoking questions it raises about the whole substitution process. No one, it seems, is happy about the idea of a "stranger" coming into the house when the whole point of the show is that all its contestants go through the process together. At least, that's my mother's view. It's also the firmly held opinion of a bloke I met at a party on Friday, my newsagent and the man who came to do my bathroom tiles. Never mind what Claire is like - she's probably a very nice girl, he said - it's just that at this vital stage the last thing you want to do is disrupt the group dynamic.

The last time he came - to fix my taps - this chap was as quiet as you like. He came in, did the job, had a cup of tea and talked briefly about the state of my building's plumbing. Now he appears to have found a subject that gives him the option of yabbering on as long as you let him. For someone who found small-talk rather trying, the show is clearly manna from heaven. No more does he have to stand there with both hands on his cuppa, trying to find some common ground with clients who might not read the Sun.

No one can disgrace themselves on the subject of Big Brother. Since anyone's opinion is as valid as everyone else's, you are sure to acquit yourself well unless you make a ghastly error such as declaring a secret passion for Nichola or indifference to the fate of Marjorie the hen.

These two faux pas aside, the democracy of this national conversation is such that everyone is fluent within half an hour of watching the show, making it ideal for people who, for whatever reason, struggled to make contact with each other in the old lingua franca. In offices across the nation, colleagues who never passed the time of day are shouting to each other across the room about the latest developments on the web.

Gauche managers who weren't in on other water-cooler conversations are now, at last, able to wow the ladies with a full diagnosis of Marjorie's stomach complaints. Suddenly, boring people don't seem boring anymore. No wonder the whole of Britain is en fête. For a limited period only, you no longer have to fear the bus queue, the work get-together or those difficult conversations with your dad. Every social gulf is bridged. Embarrassing pauses are banished. Handshakes are somehow firmer as we know that we've got something to put between "hello" and the matter in hand.

For the legions whose lives have been altered by the experience of finding themselves with one foot in common ground, the social and professional benefits are far more important than the pleasure of engaging with the programme. Entranced as they are with the idea that liking Big Brother makes them look more human, they are using it, more than consuming it, for leverage. What may look like a genuine obsession is therefore exposed as a pose in people who sneer at soap operas and whose grasp of the drama inherent in the human situation is reflected in their social ineptitude. Someone who is interested in people will communicate with their fellows well beyond the current six-week run. People who need the Big Brother crutch would be more convincing if their passion for the minutiae of human interaction had revealed itself before last month.

Before Big Brother, on a smaller scale, it was Who Wants to Be a Millionaire that got the pop cultural dilettante going. For several weeks, no one would surrender information without the hilarious detours "can I phone a friend?" or "that's my final answer Chris".

Then there was Pokémon. People liked saying Pikatchu, in the same way as they like saying Scary Spice. The use of pop cultural vernacular is not an Ali G attempt to speak to da kids in their language. Nor is it quite ironic. Certainly, there's irony there but the primary motivation of the middle-class professional who affects an acquaintance with certain pop cultural phenomena is to make himself look better rounded. It's a sad fact, but these days intellectual posturing has been replaced by its obverse. People pretend to like things to make themselves seem less disconnected, more apt. Football is a good example of something that lends itself well to this kind of willed fanaticism. Believing, probably correctly, that a taste for the beautiful game makes you look like someone ruled by your passions, many men and some women have affected an "obsession" neither character nor culture can explain.

The annoying thing about all of this for those of us who stick with popular culture in the lean times as well as the good, is that dilettantish tendency to gather up all the glory without putting in the hours. If you haven't sat through six months of crap EastEnders, I don't see what gives you the right to come in for the Christmas episode and talk about Tiffany's death as if you cared as much as we did. Nor do I really approve when grown women flaunt an attraction to Robbie Williams when they don't know what he went through to get to where he is today. How can you be as pleased with his triumph if you didn't know how close he came to obesity and obscurity?

I don't want to sound like a snob, but it takes a lot of time and energy to understand popular culture - you can't just come in for the good bits any more than you could stand outside a concert hall until you hear the aria you know from your Classic FM compilation.

webTitle: Smoking at work makes others ill

fields.headline: Smoking at work makes others ill
fields.standfirst: Special report: smoking
fields.trailText: Workplace smoking should be banned as exposure to cigarette fumes greatly increases sick leave among non-smokers, according to research published today.
fields.body:
Workplace smoking should be banned as exposure to cigarette fumes greatly increases sick leave among non-smokers, according to research published today.

A study of 10,000 police officers in Hong Kong found that non-smoking men exposed to passive smoking for more than a year were twice as likely to take time off.

They were also 30% more likely to have needed treatment for respiratory symptoms in the preceding 14 days than colleagues working in a smoke-free environment. The results held true even after passive smoking at home was taken into account.

Sarah McGhee of the University of Hong Kong, who led the team of researchers, said their study showed that workplace smoking should be banned.

"In many countries a high proportion of working environments are not yet smoke free and non-smoking employees are regularly exposed to secondhand smoke. In addition many leisure environments are a regular source of exposure," she said.

The US environmental protection agency has estimated that a ban on workplace smoking in the US would save up to $50bn.

webTitle: Junk food blamed for rise in asthma cases

fields.headline: Junk food blamed for rise in asthma cases
fields.standfirst: Scientists find evidence in rural Saudi communities that a diet of fresh fruit and vegetables can protect children against lung diseases
fields.trailText: Asthma - the single most important cause of illness in children in Europe - could be blamed on a diet of junk food and not enough fresh fruit and vegetables.
fields.body:
Asthma - the single most important cause of illness in children in Europe - could be blamed on a diet of junk food and not enough fresh fruit and vegetables.

Anthony Seaton, head of environmental and occupational medicine at Aberdeen University, led a study of children in Saudi Arabia where rural communities live in stark contrast to those in westernised Jeddah.

"What we were able to demonstrate is that, after taking into account social factors and any family history of allergies, a diet relatively poor in vegetables and the nutrients contained in them, increased the risk of asthma some two to threefold in Saudi children," he said.

This matched an earlier study among adults in Grampian. Prof Seaton and Saudi colleagues looked at communities with clearly different lifestyles and rates of allergies. They report in the journal Thorax today that they compared 100 children, with an average age of 12, and with wheezing or asthmatic symptoms, with 200 non-asthmatic children.

"There is now consistent evidence that diet is an important factor in determining whether or not a genetically predisposed individual actually develops the disease," he said. "Diet may be particularly important during pregnancy in protecting against allergy since it may influence the development of the immune system."

The scientists are to follow up their findings with a study of mothers' diets during pregnancy, with backing from the UK National Asthma Campaign.

The Saudi village children still ate a traditional diet based on milk, rice, vegetables, lamb, chicken, dates and local fruits. "However, with increasing prosperity and commercial exposure, there has been an influx over some three decades of western-type frozen and prepared foods in supermarkets and restaurants," the researchers said.

Martyn Partridge, the chief medical adviser of the asthma campaign, said: "This is an interesting study and one that is consistent with other studies that suggest that taking fresh fruit and a balanced diet protects against asthma and some other lung diseases. It is yet another point towards lifestyle as the cause of the increase in prevalence of asthma."

The study also confirms asthma as the notorious "disease of affluence". Although classic afflictions - from polio to plague, from diphtheria to dysentery - have been on the retreat for decades everywhere in the developed world, the incidence of asthma has steadily risen. Cases have more than doubled in the past 25 years.

In Britain, it afflicts more than 3m people - half of them children. The use of asthma drugs by young children rose 80% between 1990 and 1998. In one study, 39% of children were found to have been unable to join in sports at one time or another because of asthma.

One adult sufferer in 10 is disabled by asthma. It is thought to cost the British economy millions of working days a year. More than a third of those with severe asthma are unemployed. And researchers have now listed more than 200 triggers - from flour to pollen, from dust mites to cat fur, from isocyanates in paint to sawdust and rats' urine - which can precipitate a crippling attack of breathlessness.

The Saudi study has been matched by research in North America. Canadian scientists recently confirmed a lower prevalence of asthma among adolescents raised on farms rather than in cities.

The US National Institute of Health has launched a study of children in seven US cities to find ways to reduce attacks. Asthma afflicts 15m Americans, puts 500,000 in hospital every year and kills 5,000. The hope is to reduce indoor cigarette smoking, exterminate insect pests, sheathe pillows with plastic casings to reduce dust mite hazards, and educate people about the dangers from household cats and dogs.

But such steps merely reduce the stress of the disease. What researchers hope to find are the conditions that make a person vulnerable to attacks in the first place.

Diet may not be the only factor. But it must play a role. "We have now shown that dietary factors are associated with a two to threefold risk of having such symptoms," said Prof Seaton.

"The finding is of considerable public health importance. The findings are consistent with previous studies in adults and with the hypothesis that change in diet has been a determinant of the worldwide increases in asthma and allergies."

Rising toll 2,000 deaths a year

 Asthma is one of the commonest long-term medical conditions in the developed world.

 It costs the NHS £500m in drugs, doctor consultations and hospital treatments every year.

 In Britain 2,000 people a year die as a result of asthma.

 It affects people of all ages. Between 10% and 20% of children and between 5% and 10% of adults are sufferers.

 The number of people with asthma has shown a dramatic rise in countries with a westernised, urban lifestyle. In the UK the number has increased fourfold in the past 30 years.

 Between 30% and 50% of children with asthma will continue to have it as adults.

 Other possible reasons for the increase are:

- increased exposure to dust mite and animal fur and skin;

- air pollution and smog containing sulphur dioxide and nitrogen dioxide;

- indoor air pollution such as nitrogen dioxide, which is emitted from gas cookers and fires;

- changes in diet;

- an increase in smoking by women during pregnancy and children's exposure to passive smoking;

- a decrease in childhood infections, leading the immune system to target other organs.

 Approximately 5m days are lost from work as a result of asthma.

 Although treatment has improved, no completely new classes of anti-asthmatic drugs have been developed in the past 20 years.

webTitle: Big Brother gets peak-time slot

fields.headline: Big Brother gets peak-time slot
fields.standfirst: Special report: Big Brother
fields.trailText: Channel 4 is to capitalise on the popularity of its surveillance TV game show, Big Brother, by bringing forward the nightly programme to peak viewing time.
fields.body:
Channel 4 is to capitalise on the popularity of its surveillance TV game show, Big Brother, by bringing forward the nightly programme to peak viewing time.

The Tuesday to Thursday editions, aired after 11pm, have been commanding viewing figures of up to 4.5m. Last Thursday's show, when the housemates confronted "nasty" Nick with his scheming ways, topped 6m.

From next week the show will start at 10pm, maximising ratings and advertising revenue. Matt Baker, Channel 4's chief spokesman, said the rescheduling was "an acknowledgment of the level of interest there has been in the programme. We want to make it easier to view for as many people as possible."

Big Brother is one of Channel 4's most popular programmes, second only to the first showing in 1996 of the film Four Weddings and a Funeral. While the game show's viewing figures are far below the 12m-15m averaged by ITV's Who Wants to Be a Millionaire?, it is watched by a high proportion of the youth audience so popular with advertisers.

One advertising executive said Big Brother was a commercial TV channel's dream. "Millionaire was middle of the road; this is delivering the young audience that is usually so elusive. It's a superb product. The loss of "nasty" Nick shouldn't have too much of an impact - the arrival of a new contestant should provide enough intrigue to keep it going."

The level of press interest has taken Bazal, the show's producers, by surprise. The tabloid bidding war over Nick Bateman, the former insurance broker ejected from the show last week for cheating, descended into acrimony because the agent handling the deal was swamped.

The Sun agreed to pay Mr Bateman £70,000 - matching the sum to be pocketed by the show's winner - and it is thought that the deal gave him the final say on the published articles and headlines.

Keith Woodhams, the agent hired by Bazal to act for the contestants, sealed the deal with the Sun without referring back to rival newspaper bidders, who were furious at losing the chance to top the Sun's offer.

Now Bazal has called in John Noel, who represents Davina McCall, presenter of Big Brother's weekly "eviction" show, to provide support. Mr Noel is known in the TV industry as a tough operator.

In the first instalment of his Sun story yesterday, Mr Bateman said he feared recriminations after becoming a hate figure on the show. He was also worried that he might never get a girlfriend because women "think they can't trust me".

He was thrown out after he was caught flouting rules on tactical voting by showing notes to other contestants. Each week the remaining contestants put up two of their number for eviction, and votes from the viewers decide which one should leave the game.

Mr Bateman has been replaced by Claire Strutton, a florist from Gerrards Cross, Buckinghamshire.

webTitle: Business: City briefing

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.body:
House prices falling

House prices fell in the three months to the end of July and are expected to fall again in the next three months, according to the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors.

The fall is the first recorded by the RICS since the 1998 economic crisis in the far east, with London and the south-east the worst hit. Steep falls in the south were offset by continued rises in Wales and the north of England.

Botts steps up Wolves battle

Botts & Co, the private equity firm, is likely to issue a direct appeal today, asking shareholders in Wolverhampton & Dudley Breweries to force management to consider a £470m takeover proposal.

Hopes that Wolves would reconsider the 500p-a-share proposal were dashed following a meeting of the regional beer company's senior executives yesterday.

Investors sue banks

German law firm Rotter-Rechtsanwaelte said yesterday that it had filed a lawsuit on behalf of investors seeking damages from Credit Suisse First Boston and Dresdner Bank over two defaulted bond issues they managed. The bond lead-managed by Dresdner was called Synthetic Ecuador Bond, while Credit Suisse managed the Ecuador Synthetic Sovereign Investments Bond. They were issued in 1996 and 1997 by investment vehicles in Jersey and went into default in autumn 1999, the firm said.

The investors want the DM272,000 (£84,375) they invested plus annual interest of 8.25%; their lawyers said the total issue volume of the bonds was DM375m (£117m).

Funds on the rebound

Gross sales of British investment funds rose in July to their highest level since April and were well ahead of levels a year earlier, according to data from Autif, the Association of Unit Trusts and Investment Funds, which showed investment funds under management edging up to a record £265.3bn in July.

Gross sales of funds rose to £4.48bn in July from £4.27bn in June - well below March's £7.57bn in March, the best month for sales in the past year, but ahead of the £3.71bn achieved in July 1999.

Swissair denies plans for BA

Swissair's parent, SAirGroup, yesterday denied it had done a study on the benefits of a tie-up with British Airways, itself now in talks with KLM, and said it had no plans for partnerships with either airline.

SAirGroup spokesman Hans Klaus said a report in the Mail on Sunday suggesting a study had been done was wrong. He said SAirGroup's main priority for its airlines business was to build up the Qualiflyer group of airlines.

Ebner dumps Roche stake

Pharma Vision, the pharmaceutical investment company owned by Swiss banker Martin Ebner, said it sold its entire stake in Roche Holding, or 21.6% of its portfolio. In May Roche's board rejected a request by Mr Ebner to become a board member.

webTitle: Crew found dead in stricken sub

fields.headline: Crew found dead in stricken sub
fields.standfirst:
Rescue called off after crew found dead in stricken sub
Special report: Russia's stricken submarine
fields.trailText: Ten days of drama in the Arctic reached a grim climax last night when all 118 Russian crew who went down with the Kursk nuclear submarine in the Barents Sea on August 12 were declared dead in the country's worst naval disaster.
fields.body:
Ten days of drama in the Arctic reached a grim climax last night when all 118 Russian crew who went down with the Kursk nuclear submarine in the Barents Sea on August 12 were declared dead in the country's worst naval disaster.

Norwegian rescue divers who opened two escape hatches on the stern of the 500ft vessel found the rear section of the submarine flooded and the first of the dozens of dead sailors.

In a terse statement last night, Russia's northern fleet offered condolences to the families of the 118 men as the defence minister, Igor Sergeyev, went on national television to declare that the crew was lost and to defend the top brass against public charges of incompetence and callousness.

All national television programmes broadcast sombre obituaries for the crewmen, screening a roll call of the names and ranks of the dead mariners against a backdrop of stormy sea. Scores of grieving relatives continued to arrive in Murmansk.

"There's no doubt the crew has perished," the chief of staff of the northern fleet, vice-admiral Mikhail Motsak, pronounced on television.

Last night the rescue attempt gave way to recovery and recrimination - the attempt to recover the corpses, grief at a tragedy that has struck a chord throughout Russia and anger at the authorities who displayed contempt in crisis, misinforming the public, delaying and bungling the rescue effort and agreeing to accept foreign help only when it was too late.

For days, the Russians tried and failed to open the escape hatch at the rear of the vessel, reporting that it was severely damaged by the unexplained explosion that caused the sinking. On Sunday, the Russians said the Norwegian divers would also be unable to open the hatch. That was promptly rejected by the Norwegians and within 24 hours they had opened the upper and lower hatches on the 9th section, the focus of hopes of finding any survivors.

"We found that the whole submarine is full of water," said Norway's armed forces spokesman, Lt Col John Espen Lien. "We believe there is no chance of finding any survivors in the submarine."

Following consultations between senior Russian and Norwegian navy officers on board the cruiser, Peter the Great, at the disaster site, the rescue mission was called off.

The British LR5 mini-submarine, taken by plane and boat from Glasgow to the Barents Sea to attempt its first deep-sea crew rescue set off for Norway last night without ever taking to the water.

Moscow asked the Norwegian experts to continue helping in the hazardous operation to bring out the dead. Vice-admiral Motsak said the two governments had reached agreement on the participation of the Norwegian divers in the corpse recovery effort. But the divers have not yet entered what is now a huge steel tomb on the seabed and are believed to be against the idea.

Last night remote video equipment was being lowered into the submarine to survey the interior of section nine and remote control manipulators were to be used to try to retrieve the sole unidentified corpse discovered.

Given the perils for divers trying to enter the stricken submarine, the recovery effort is expected to focus on raising the vessel, a daunting challenge since the flooded weight of the Kursk is estimated at 25,000 tonnes.

Despite government claims last week that only the Russians and the Americans have the technical wherewithal to mount such an undertaking, the Russians do not have the money, the expertise, or the equipment to raise the Kursk and any such attempt will take months.

"There isn't a single country that can handle such an operation on its own," said Ilya Klebanov, the deputy prime minister who heads the government inquiry into the disaster. He said Moscow was launching an international appeal to raise funds for the effort.

The cause of the explosions which wrecked the bow of the submarine, precipitating the sinking and the total flooding, remain unclear.

Captain Vladimir Navrotsky, spokesman for the northern fleet, stressed yesterday that the initial explanation offered by the admirals - a collision with another, probably foreign, vessel - was gaining credibility.

In the latest of several leaks to the Russian media, unnamed military sources said fragments of a foreign submarine, probably British, were found 1,000 feet from the Kursk. Captain Navrotsky denied any such fragments had been found, as did the Ministry of Defence in London.

webTitle: Troops on streets as two die in Ulster feud

fields.headline: Troops on streets as two die in Ulster feud
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Troops were ordered back onto the streets of Belfast last night after a loyalist feud erupted into full-scale violence when a gunman from the Ulster Volunteer Force shot dead two men, one of whom was linked to the rival Ulster Defence Association.
fields.byline: Nicholas Watt  and Jamie Wilson  in Belfast
fields.body:
Troops were ordered back onto the streets of Belfast last night after a loyalist feud erupted into full-scale violence when a gunman from the Ulster Volunteer Force shot dead two men, one of whom was linked to the rival Ulster Defence Association.

Amid fears that the six-year-old loyalist ceasefire could unravel, up to 100 soldiers from the Royal Green Jackets started round-the-clock patrols of the Shankill area of the city in an attempt to stamp out the feud between Northern Ireland's two main loyalist paramilitary groups. Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary, denounced the violence as "nothing more or less than squalid, murderous gang warfare".

Security sources described the operation as a "surgical deployment" to frighten off rival loyalist gangs who have terrorised the Shankill area of the city over the past few days. "This is the sort of operation the army is good at - go in, transform the atmosphere and get out," one source said.

Troops, which have not mounted regular patrols in Belfast since September 1998, were ordered out of their base after the UVF gunman struck on the Crumlin Road shortly after midday.

Jackie Coulter, a UDA welfare worker, and Bobby Mahood, whose brother has survived a number of assassination attempts, were hit by the gunman as they sat in their Range Rover after leaving a bookmaker's. The gunman fired eight shots through a passenger side window, killing Mr Coulter instantly and critically wounding Mr Mahood in the stomach. He died a few hours later in the nearby Mater hospital, bringing to eight the number of murders in Northern Ireland this year linked to paramilitary violence.

Within minutes of the shooting, the UDA retaliated. Supporters charged up the nearby Shankill Road and set fire to the offices of the Progressive Unionist Party, the UVF's political wing. As armed men roamed the Shankill area looking for revenge, a house was attacked and a car parked outside attacked.

RUC officers fired two shots during the disturbances. Two men were later arrested and a number of weapons were seized. Last night a police spotter helicopter buzzed overhead as cars going in and out of the Shankill estate were searched by RUC officers who had regained control of the area.

Mr Mandelson last night demanded an immediate halt to the feud and said he would be having early discussions with the political representatives of the loyalist groups.

"This violence has got to end and end now," he said on his return to Belfast from his holiday. "We have got to restore sanity to this situation."

Mr Mandelson held intensive talks throughout the day with his security advisers, which led to the RUC's "reluctant" request to the army to resume its patrols.

Assistant chief constable Bill Stewart said last night: "This is planned as a short-term measure and is an indication of the determination of the police to pursue vigorously the criminals who are preying on local communities."

The deployment of troops underlined the concern among ministers and the RUC that the loyalist feud is in danger of spiralling out of control. The convicted terrorist, Johnny "Mad Dog" Adair, is being blamed for whipping up the feud as he attempts to reassert control over the UDA in Belfast after his recent early release under the terms of the Good Friday agreement.

Adair, who has been goading republicans over recent weeks, stoked tensions at the week end when he organised a "cultural festival" at which UDA gunmen brandished weapons. When members of the UVF tried to seize flags, Adair's supporters struck back and attacked the Rex bar on the Shankill Road, which is popular among UVF supporters. Gunmen fired into the bar, injuring three people. The home of Gusty Spence, the founder of the modern UVF in the 1960s, was also attacked.

webTitle: Shayler escapes vital charges

fields.headline: Shayler escapes vital charges
fields.standfirst:
Renegade spy bailed after orchestrated return home
Special report: David Shayler
fields.trailText: David Shayler, the renegade MI5 officer, was charged yesterday with disclosing information about the activities of the Security Service but crucially not with his most serious and embarrassing allegation, namely the involvement by British agents in a plot to assassinate the Libyan leader, Colonel Gadafy.
fields.body:
David Shayler, the renegade MI5 officer, was charged yesterday with disclosing information about the activities of the Security Service but crucially not with his most serious and embarrassing allegation, namely the involvement by British agents in a plot to assassinate the Libyan leader, Colonel Gadafy.

In a move which appears to strike a blow to the heart of the Official Secrets Act, the charges are limited to the allegations he made to a Sunday newspaper three years ago before he fled to the continent.

These include MI5's practice of holding files on prominent Labour politicians, radical pop stars such as John Lennon, and what he called the "incompetence and bureaucracy" of MI5 - notably over its surveillance of suspected Libyan intelligence officers in London.

The charges laid against him at a London police station yesterday also include documents he allegedly took from MI5's headquarters at Millbank, Westminster. However, they do not cover a spate of allegations he subsequently made in exile.

Mr Shayler has alleged that the 1994 bombing of the Israeli embassy in London could have been avoided as could the IRA bombing of Bishopsgate in the City in 1993 - the subject of a recent article he wrote for Punch for which the magazine's editor faces contempt of court charges.

The most glaring omission from the charge sheet is the plot to kill Col Gadafy. It is possible the police have insufficient direct evidence against Mr Shayler - their attempt to seize any notes the Guardian and Observer newspapers may have relating to the alleged 1996 plot was dismissed by the appeal court last month.

Mr Shayler yesterday said he had no doubt why the Gadafy plot was not included in the charges. "The government has backed off, they don't want to fight," he said. "I wonder whether this is an attempt to prevent the jury from hearing the whole story", he added.

He was speaking outside Charing Cross police station - where he was released on bail - at the end of an extraordinary, well-planned day which began in Calais and was briefly interrupted by his arrest at Dover by Sergeant Tim Jones of the metropolitan police special branch.

He was accompanied on the ferry by his girlfriend Annie Machon, also a former MI5 officer, his brothers, Philip and Jeremy, and his parents, Anne and Ron. Bemused tourists and a small army of photographers and television cameramen also made the trip.

He betrayed a certain nervousness. "I return with a feeling of fear and trepidation," he said. "But I have nothing to hide."

"I return", he said, "on my own terms".

Not entirely. "Mr Shayler," said Sgt Jones at the Dover dockside, "I'm a police officer. Will you come this way."

At Charing Cross police station he posed for yet another photograph - this time for the official record - a DNA sample was taken, his fingerprints were taken, and he surrendered his passport.

John Wadham, Mr Shayler's lawyer and director of Liberty, the civil rights group, said his client had not been interviewed by the police and the police were not investigating any other offences.

He also said that the Human Rights Act, which comes into force on October 2, will mean that the Official Secrets Act will have to comply with article 10 of the European convention on human rights which guarantees the right to freedom of expression.

Many government lawyers believe that the secrets act is incompatible with the European human rights convention by making it an absolute offence for any member or former member of the security and intelligence services to say anything about their work without authority.

Mr Wadham said that Mr Shayler will argue in court that he made his disclosures in the public interest. They caused no damage, he will argue in a case which will almost certainly involve MI5 officers having to take the stand.

The Official Secrets Act's compatibility with the Human Rights Act could be tested before Mr Shayler puts his case. In November Nigel Wylde a former senior Army officer, is due to appear on secrets charges relating to information about computer surveillance systems he is alleged to have given to the journalist, Tony Geraghty.

Mr Shayler, who will appear at Bow Street magistrates court on Thursday where he will enter a not guilty plea, came out fighting yesterday. saying he could make further allegations about MI5. Meanwhile, he said, "I am going to get pissed".

webTitle: Leader: Spies and public interest - let the court decide

fields.headline: Spies and public interest
fields.standfirst:
The court is the right place to decide

Special report: David Shayler
Special report: freedom of information
fields.trailText: In returning to Britain yesterday, David Shayler may have inadvertently struck the greatest blow for openness by a member of the secret services since James Bond drove Q's jetboat through the windows of MI6's Thames-side headquarters. That may not be much comfort to him as he waits on bail poring over the two charges made against him yesterday. His main concern now will be whether or not those charges will ever be heard in a courtroom, or whether they - and he - will be quietly forgotten.
fields.body:
In returning to Britain yesterday, David Shayler may have inadvertently struck the greatest blow for openness by a member of the secret services since James Bond drove Q's jetboat through the windows of MI6's Thames-side headquarters. That may not be much comfort to him as he waits on bail poring over the two charges made against him yesterday. His main concern now will be whether or not those charges will ever be heard in a courtroom, or whether they - and he - will be quietly forgotten.

It is easy to see why some reformers might hope that the action against Mr Shayler is dropped: after all, that would surely be the kindest fate for a man who has already spent three years on the run, away from friends and family - including more than three months in a Paris prison cell. For all that, there is still a good - even liberal - case for prosecuting David Shayler.

In the first place, he does not deny breaking the law; he merely claims that a bad law forced him into illegality in the public interest. If this is true, it may be best to demonstrate that fact in court, against the test of the Human Rights Act and its right to freedom of expression. Secondly, there is the fate of the Official Secrets Act itself. Some campaigners believe that a do-nothing approach by the authorities would confirm that the act is effectively a dead letter. But what better way to drive a stake through its heart than to crush it in a courtroom, where its archaic and absurd nature might be exposed for all to see.

Furthermore, a fudge that lets Mr Shayler escape prosecution would leave untested his most serious claim, which he is bound to raise in court even though it is not on the charge-sheet. For Mr Shayler says that in 1995 two MI6 officers (known as PT16B and PT16) handed over £100,000 to a group of Libyan plotters who intended to kill Muammar Gadafy but ended up killing several innocent Libyans instead. No one doubts that an attack took place, but it is unclear if talk of British involvement, rather than knowledge, is, as the foreign secretary has said, "pure fantasy". Is Mr Shayler's claim credible? This, too, might best be discovered in court.

So where does the government stand? Mr Shayler's arrest and subsequent release on bail yesterday suggests it has not yet made up its mind. The decision may depend on the outcome of a separate action against Nigel Wylde, a former army officer who appears at the Old Bailey in November charged with passing information on surveillance systems to a journalist. Unlike with Mr Shayler, there is no question that Col Wylde was motivated by a belief that the public ought to know how they were being spied upon, but if the case against him falls apart, as looks likely, so may that against Mr Shayler.

The outcome of that would be to question the entire, clubby basis on which the security services operate. What should come in its place is a distinction between operational decisions, for which there is a justified case for limited secrecy, and institutional practice - the who, where, why and how much - for which the case for secrecy hardly holds.

Yesterday the former foreign secretary, Sir Malcolm Rifkind, said: "You cannot have a secret service, even in a democratic country, unless it is secret." This is outdated, and the Shayler and Wylde cases seem to make it impossible, too. The British public knows too little about their spies, not too much. Intelligence bosses would command more respect in their attempts to guard legitimate secrets if the water in which they swam was a good deal more transparent.

webTitle: End of an era as BBC closes Pebble Mill

fields.headline: End of an era as BBC closes Pebble Mill
fields.standfirst: Special report: the future of the BBC
fields.trailText: The BBC will announce today that it is closing its main television studios at Pebble Mill in Birmingham, ending decades of history at one of the best-known broadcasting centres in Britain.
fields.body:
The BBC will announce today that it is closing its main television studios at Pebble Mill in Birmingham, ending decades of history at one of the best-known broadcasting centres in Britain.

Almost as familiar to viewers as BBC Television Centre in London, the Birmingham centre was the base for the long-running chatshow Pebble Mill at One. But its two main TV studios there have been used less in recent years, and will close as part of a cost-cutting drive launched by the BBC's director general, Greg Dyke.

About 90 jobs are expected to be lost. Union leaders are demanding a meeting with Mr Dyke, and are threatening strike action to oppose the move. Midlands MPs are also likely to be furious at the decision, which will raise questions about the BBC's commitment to broadcast production centres in the regions. Staff fear for the long-term future of the BBC's base in Birmingham.

The BBC will retain the small studio where it makes the area's news programme, Midlands Today, and the radio facilities which produce The Archers for Radio 4.

Carlton moved its main Central TV production centre from Birmingham to its larger base in Nottingham in the mid-1990s, so the BBC's decision means Britain's second-biggest city will now have no major TV production centre.

Staff are to be told about the decision at meetings today. But the announcement could be delayed if local MPs are not available to be briefed about the plans.

Gerry Morrissey, the assistant general secretary of the broadcasting union Bectu, said last night: "If this is true, it's terrible news for television production in the Midlands. It's nonsensical, and sounds the death knell for Pebble Mill. We will fight this industrially and politically, and we will be seeking meetings at director general level. It also calls into question the BBC's stated commitment to regional broadcasting."

Job losses will fall mainly on staff employed by BBC Resources, the corporation's production support arm. Camera operators and sound and lighting engineers will be hardest hit.

The BBC is undertaking a wide-ranging review of its resources. It has announced the loss of 200 jobs and merged its production resources in the north-west of England with Granada Television.

The best-known show to come from Pebble Mill was the daytime series, Pebble Mill at One, which ran from 1973 to 1986. The daily diet of music, chat and information was long presented by Donny Macleod and Bob Langley. It formed the model for later daytime magazine programmes, and launched the TV career of the gardener Alan Titchmarsh.

Good Morning with Anne and Nick, the short-lived answer to ITV's This Morning with Richard and Judy, also came from the Birmingham studios.

webTitle: BBC drops Christie as drugs appeal fails

fields.headline: BBC drops Christie as drugs appeal fails
fields.standfirst: Special report: Sydney Olympics
fields.trailText: Linford Christie, the 1992 Olympic 100 metres champion and arguably Britain's greatest ever athlete, was yesterday dropped from the BBC team covering next month's Olympic Games after the sport's governing body upheld his ban for doping offences.
fields.body:
Linford Christie, the 1992 Olympic 100 metres champion and arguably Britain's greatest ever athlete, was yesterday dropped from the BBC team covering next month's Olympic Games after the sport's governing body upheld his ban for doping offences.

The International Amateur Athletic Federation's arbitration panel of the world governing body announced that Christie, the European 200m champion Dougie Walker and Britain's former No 1 400m hurdler, Gary Cadogan, were all guilty of using the banned anabolic steroid nandrolone, and have had two-year bans imposed.

Even though he is now retired, Christie has fought an 18-month battle to clear his name after testing positive at an indoor meeting in Dortmund last year. He was backed by the British federation UK Athletics following research by Aberdeen University.

"The arbitration panel believes that UK Athletics misdirected itself and reached an erroneous conclusion when clearing these athletes," an IAAF statement said yesterday.

The decision casts a long shadow over everything he has achieved during a brilliantly successful career which saw him win a record 31 international championship and cup gold medals, including the 1993 world title.

Yesterday he remained defiant: "I am very disappointed the tribunal did not feel able to accept the new scientific evidence presented to them. I have never intentionally taken any banned substance.

"I have always made it clear that I have no confidence in the IAAF's arbitration process, and this simply reaffirms this."

Within hours of the verdict, BBC Television announced that Christie had been dropped from its team of commentators for Sydney next month.

A BBC Sport spokesman said: "Last year when the accusations were laid, Linford withdrew himself because he thought it inappropriate he should be working as an athletics pundit. The BBC feels with today's announcement that the whole controversy surrounding nandrolone persists and it would be inappropriate for him to comment on the performance of other athletes."

However, Christie will continue working as presenter of the BBC show, Linford's Record Breakers.

The 40-year-old Christie, who now coaches some of Britain's biggest medal hopes in Sydney, including the 400m runner Katharine Merry, could now also find himself banned from the Olympic stadium.

The British Olympic Association has a rule which states that any person who has failed a drugs test is not eligible for accreditation, while the New South Wales government has a similar law preventing athletes who are serving drugs bans from using its facilities.

Yesterday's decision also casts serious doubt over the participation of Mark Richardson in the Sydney Games. The Windsor runner was cleared of taking nandrolone by UK Athletics in July, thanks to the Aberdeen study. But the IAAF announced yesterday that it was also sending his case to its arbitration panel. It hopes to reach a decision on September 15, the day of the Olympic opening ceremony.

The Windsor runner was cleared of taking nandrolone by UK Athletics in July, thanks to the Aberdeen study. But the IAAF announced yesterday that it was also sending his case to its arbitration panel. It hopes to reach a decision on September 15, the day of the Olympic opening ceremony.

webTitle: Top pay up 16.5%, four times average

fields.headline: Top pay up 16.5%, four times average
fields.trailText: The pay of Britain's top bosses rose by 16.5% last year, four times the average wage increase, according to a survey by pay consultants Inbucon for the Guardian.
fields.body:
The pay of Britain's top bosses rose by 16.5% last year, four times the average wage increase, according to a survey by pay consultants Inbucon for the Guardian.

More than 110 senior executives received £1m or more last year, the survey found, highlighting the wealth being created for directors in the boardrooms of the country's 100 largest companies. Only one woman, Marjorie Scardino, the chief executive of Pearson, appears in the league table.

Three top executives achieved millionaire status on basic salary alone. The remaining members of the "millionaire's club", the full list of which will be published tomorrow, were able to boost their compensation through gains on share options and other long-term incentive plans, intended to link pay with performance.

The survey highlights the changing nature of Britain's boardrooms - with executives from the United States dominating the top rungs of this year's league. Two Americans of Asian descent, little known in the UK and both employed by Vodafone during the 1999 financial year, top the table. Arun Sarin cashed in options and other share-based awards to take home £21m, while Mohan Gyani, who as a result of £14m on gains over options, achieved £16m.

The options over shares awarded to executives which are yet to be cashed in are not included in the survey, a factor which would propel another American, Paul Chisholm, the outgoing chief executive of Colt Telecom, higher up the table. He is sitting on options worth £113m, in addition to the gains of £14.7m he made on his options this year.

Nine senior executives received payoffs of more than £1m last year, the survey found, including Bob Ayling, the ousted chief executive of British Airways, who ranks among the top earners because of the £1.9m retirement package he was awarded on his departure this year. The largest "golden goodbye" - worth nearly £5m - went to Steven Kotler, an investment banker who ran the US operations of Schroders.

The 16.5% year-on-year rise in directors' pay is based on their total base salaries during the last financial year and takes no account of gains made on options or other performance-related pay deals. While directors' enjoyed large rises, the average wage in the country rose, according to government figures, by 4.1%.

The survey is published as big investor groups step up pressure on boardrooms to curb excesses, following the decision by National Association of Pensions Funds, whose members control a quarter of the stock market, to issue recommendations on how to vote at crucial annual meetings.

In an early example of its new activism, the association expressed dismay at this year's annual general meeting of Vodafone, after the company awarded a £10m bonus to Chris Gent, the chief executive. The payment falls outside of the scope of this year's survey.
