webTitle: 'Mad Dog' turf war threatens Ulster peace

fields.headline: 'Mad Dog' turf war threatens Ulster peace
fields.standfirst:
UDA chief blamed for orchestrating loyalist feud

Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: At the height of the troubles, the police and army in Northern Ireland used to sit back during paramilitary feuds and watch with glee as rival gangs blew each other to pieces.
fields.body:
At the height of the troubles, the police and army in Northern Ireland used to sit back during paramilitary feuds and watch with glee as rival gangs blew each other to pieces.

A decade later, however, security sources are deeply concerned that the present feud between the two main loyalist paramilitary groups could destabilise the entire province.

The double murder yesterday by the Ulster Volunteer Force of two men, one of whom was linked to the Ulster Defence Association presents the gravest challenge to the loyalist ceasefire since it was declared six years ago. The shootings, which were immediately followed by retaliatory attacks by the UDA on groups linked to the UVF, brought back memories of the worst days of the troubles, when parts of Northern Ireland were ungovernable.

On a political level, the sight of UDA members brandishing their weapons during a loyalist "cultural festival" at the weekend will undermine confidence among the wider public in the peace process. The Tories wasted no time yesterday in pointing out that Johnny Adair, the UDA commander who is orchestrating the present feud, is only on the streets because he was released early from prison under the Good Friday agreement.

Both sides blamed each other yesterday for starting the feud. There is little doubt, however, that "Mad Dog" Adair provoked the violence in a crude attempt to reassert his authority over loyalist areas of west and north Belfast which fell from his control when he was jailed in the mid 1990s.

Adair, who became Northern Ireland's most feared loyalist terrorist when he orchestrated a series of sectarian attacks on Catholics in the early 90s, has three aims. He wants to undermine loyalist support for the peace process, goad republicans into renewed sectarian violence and gain control of the lucrative drugs trade in loyalist areas.

It was no mistake over the weekend when his supporters attacked the home of Gusty Spence, the founder of the modern-day UVF, who was instrumental in brokering the loyalist ceasefire.

It was Mr Spence, who is highly respected in loyalist circles, who read out the ceasefire statement by the Combined Loyalist Military Command in 1994 in which the paramilitaries expressed their "abject remorse" for the violence they had inflicted on their opponents.

Adair's strategy - to provoke violence by attacking such a respected UVF figure - paid off yesterday when his opponents struck at the UDA.

A Presbyterian minister who had helped to broker the loyalist ceasefire after winning the respect of both the UDA and the UVF, underlined the severity of the violence when he said that the present feud was "tearing" his community apart. "It is tragic that the violence has reached this pitch," the Rev Roy Magee said. "I call on the leadership of all organisations to step back, because we are tearing our community apart."

Republicans, who will be monitoring the loyalist feud, will hardly mourn yesterday's murder of two loyalists. But Adair also hopes to goad them into violence. His gang has been blamed for a series of sectarian attacks on Catholic homes in the Cliftonville area of north Belfast in recent weeks, which has engendered panic among nationalists.

The heavily tatooed and muscular figure of Adair intimidates Catholics by cruising through their areas, in the way that he used to drive through Catholic areas of Belfast when he was responsible for a series of sectarian attacks in the early 1990s.

There is no sign yet that republicans are preparing to target Adair. The IRA tried to murder him in a disastrous attack on a Shankill Road fish shop in 1993 which killed nine innocent Protestants. However, the Irish National Liberation Army recently staged a series of armed foot patrols in the Ardoyne area of north Belfast.

The third pillar of Adair's strategy is to grab his share of the drugs trade in loyalist areas. Control of the supply of drugs has been traditionally used by loyalist paramilitaries to line their own pockets and to assert their authority over deeply deprived areas of Belfast.

When the Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Mandelson, returned to the province from his holiday last night he might have been forgiven for wondering whether it was on the verge of slipping back to its old ways.

Amid the gloom, however, there are a few signs that the peace process may again be able to withstand the challenge. Within hours of yesterday's shootings, Rev Magee offered to mediate between the rival loyalist groups. His quiet diplomacy, which played such a crucial role in persuading hardline loyalists to sign up to the original ceasefire, may again prove decisive in preserving the ceasefire.

Security sources also pointed out that the feud was concentrated in a relatively small area, with little sign of violence spreading across Northern Ireland.

"This is, of course, serious and cannot be tolerated," one source said. "But this is a fight between two sets of gangsters and we are a long way from the ceasefire being breached."

webTitle: Farmer to milk taste for water

fields.headline: Farmer to milk taste for water
fields.standfirst: Special report: the countryside in crisis
fields.trailText: A former dairy farmer, Richard Blomfield,  plans to cash in on the change in consumer tastes which has seen sales of bottled water soar as milk consumption has dropped.
fields.body:
A former dairy farmer, Richard Blomfield, plans to cash in on the change in consumer tastes which has seen sales of bottled water soar as milk consumption has dropped.

Within days, the first bottles will leave a newly installed plant at Springhill farm at Fylingthorpe, near Whitby, north Yorkshire. Most of the cattle have already left the 200 acre holding, the rest will be sold in the autumn. "The water is pure compared to the treated stuff that comes out of town taps" said Mr Blomfield, aged 52.

His decision to abandon dairy farming is partly due to a doctor's warning that his spine, on which he has had two operations, would no longer tolerate the daily grind of milking. But it also illustrates the trouble into which the once profitable dairy industry has plunged.

By late last year he was receiving 16p a litre for milk from his herd of almost 200 dairy cows, 3p less than it cost to produce.

Mr Blomfield, a dairy farmer for 30 years, moved to Springhill from his farm near Leeds four years ago. He was given permission to change his liquid assets by North York Moors national park authority and the Department of the Environment, although he cannot sell bottles directly from the farm. He said of his new venture: "We are looking to shops, pubs, restaurants, garages - even the North York Moors' visitors centre has expressed an interest." The new business had cost "tens of thousands of pounds to establish" but was not as costly as feeding, housing and caring for dairy cows, nor keeping within the milk quota.

Under the water licence, he will be able to bottle 4.5m litres a year, nearly three times the amount of milk produced by his herd. Mr Blomfield believes he will be able to expand production from the five natural springs that once provided for the needs of the surrounding area.

webTitle: Lords warned over right to roam

fields.headline: Lords warned over right to roam
fields.standfirst: Special report: the countryside in crisis
fields.trailText: The government yesterday vowed to fight attempts by country landowners to sabotage the commitment to enshrine the right to roam in law across thousands of acres of wild mountain moorland and heath.
fields.body:
The government yesterday vowed to fight attempts by country landowners to sabotage the commitment to enshrine the right to roam in law across thousands of acres of wild mountain moorland and heath.

Paddy Tipping, the deputy leader of the Commons, met ramblers and wildlife groups on Bodmin Moor, Cornwall, where he pledged that ministers were determined to get the controversial countryside and rights of way bill on to the statute book by the end of the year.

His claim that landowning interests would not be allowed to wreck the bill which is due to be debated in the Lords in the autumn followed speculation that ministers were considering dropping it to make way for the passage of five items of legislation before the end of this parliamentary session in November.

Mr Tipping, who is also vice-president of the Ramblers' Association, said the countryside bill had the personal support of the prime minister. "It will be a tough fight but this bill has gone through the democratically elected Commons and has the support of people who care for the countryside."

More than 300 amendments have already been tabled for debate when peers return from the summer recess on September 27.

It is understood that Damien Green, a Tory environment spokesman, has written to Michael Meacher, the environment minister, asking the government to drop the access provisions in return for Conservative support for the rest of the bill. Mr Meacher is understood to have rejected the deal.

Nicky Warden of the Ramblers' Association said: "This bill has the support of the vast majority of the British population, and it would have been a tremendous disappointment for millions of people to see it fall by the wayside."

A recent NOP poll commissioned by the Ramblers' Association found that eight out of 10 people wanted the bill to become law as soon as possible.

webTitle: Bomb linked to anti-hunt activists

fields.headline: Bomb linked to anti-hunt activists
fields.standfirst: Special report: the hunting debate
fields.trailText: A home-made bomb with the potential to kill or maim anyone within 100 yards could have been planted by anti-hunt activists, it was claimed yesterday.
fields.body:
A home-made bomb with the potential to kill or maim anyone within 100 yards could have been planted by anti-hunt activists, it was claimed yesterday.

The device was discovered at the weekend by a gamekeeper jammed into a stone wall on a farm at Syreford, near Cheltenham. The land is used by the Cotswold Hunt.

Explosives experts say the bomb consisted of a two litre plastic bottle filled with liquid and 5lb of brass nuts. They said the nuts would have shot out like shrapnel. A timer device attached to the bomb failed to go off.

Gloucestershire police sealed off the area and closed a nearby road while bomb disposal specialists made the device safe.

A spokeswoman for 721 Explosives Ordnance Depot at Ashchurch said police had indicated they could not rule out hunt saboteurs.

"The item was in such an open area it might have been a test," she said. "It was potentially dangerous. If children had got hold of it I don't know what would have happened."

webTitle: Britain snubs US over world court for crimes against humanity

fields.headline: Britain snubs US on world court
fields.trailText: The British government will formally break ranks with the US on Friday by supporting the creation of an international criminal court to prosecute those responsible for genocide and other crimes against humanity.
fields.body:
The British government will formally break ranks with the US on Friday by supporting the creation of an international criminal court to prosecute those responsible for genocide and other crimes against humanity.

Downing Street confirmed yesterday that the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, is to publish a consultation paper and a draft bill paving the way for British participation in the court. Britain would become a founder member.

The aim is to push the bill speedily through the next session of parliament in preparation for the setting up of the court in 2002. Opposition parties have been asked to cooperate in this.

The US is one of seven countries - including China, Saudi Arabia and Libya - opposed to the court. Washington claims that it cannot allow its soldiers or politicians to fall under the jurisdiction of an international court over which it might have little or no control.

Supporters of the court counter that most US international military intervention has been done under the banner of international law, whether the UN or Nato, and those involved in it could not be held accountable.

They hope it will prevent abuses of human rights on the scale of Rwanda, the Balkans and East Timor. It will be a permanent body, unlike the Hague tribunal trying Balkan war criminals.

Francis Maude, the shadow foreign affairs spokesman, signalled yesterday that the Conservatives will avoid delaying the bill. "In principle we are in favour. We are ready to co-operate," he said.

The impetus to establish the court came after the Balkan atrocities of the early 1990s. The UN security council asked an international law commission to draft a plan, which was agreed at an international conference in Rome in 1998.

The court will not be able to act retrospectively. Incidents in Chechnya, East Timor or elsewhere before 2002 will not fall within its remit.

Britain usually acts in tandem with US in foreign policy, but in the case of the court it has opted for solidarity with the rest of the EU, all of whose members support the idea.

webTitle: Dr Mark Turner on a submarine escape

fields.headline: Life on the line
fields.standfirst: Special report: Russia's stricken submarine
fields.trailText: Dr Mark Turner a former diving medical officer and submarine escape instructor in the Royal Navy escaped from a submarine 300ft down during an exercise in a Scottish loch.
fields.body:
Having escaped from a submarine 300ft down during an exercise in a Scottish loch, I can perhaps imagine the situation that was faced by the Norwegian divers working on the Kursk. The water would have been bitterly cold at around 3C to 4C and even if the sun is shining on the surface it is completely dark at 400ft. This is compounded by the knowledge that even a minor accident could be fatal at that depth.

The divers would not, however, have been concerned about the depth, the cold or the darkness. They spend most of their working lives in such inhospitable places. They will have spent time in a cramped saturation diving chamber on board their ship for up to 17 days. Their mother ship will keep itself positioned over the Kursk while they are diving. Even the diving bell that will lower the men to the bottom is kept at a constant height above the submarine.

To combat the cold the divers wear suits that keep them dry while hot water is pumped around pipes in the suit, from the surface, to maintain their body temperature. This enables them to spend up to six hours at a time working on the submarine. They wear hard diving helmets with powerful lights and remain attached to their diving bell by an umbilical that delivers a constant supply of breathing gas.

At 400ft down they will be breathing about 5% oxygen and 95% helium. If they were to breathe 20% oxygen, as on the surface, they would soon become unconscious as even oxygen is toxic at these depths. The nitrogen in the air would cause delirium and unconsciousness quickly and hence this is replaced by the inert gas helium. Usually the divers would work as a team of three with one remaining in the bell in case of emergency. All of this technology and expertise has resulted from the needs of the oil industry and thankfully enables these underwater capabilities to be available at times of need.

The real fear faced by these men was what they would find in the submarine. They are used to working on oil rigs and pipelines, not salvage operations and recovering bodies. Indeed these divers share many things with the submariners lying dead inside the Kursk. Both groups of men spend their working lives under the sea facing the ever-present hazards that this environment brings. They both live in confined spaces with their colleagues for many weeks at a time - one group protecting our security, the other helping to provide the oil that powers our western lifestyle. The camaraderie and mutual respect that comes from facing adversity as a team is similar among divers and submariners.

I escaped from a Royal Navy submarine in 1993 and recall the moments before my turn came to climb up into the escape tower. I was waiting with my colleagues in the escape compartment watching intently as each man was sent on his way to the surface. Despite it being an exercise I was still very anxious and sat in silence.

I climbed the steel ladder that leads up into the one-man escape tower. Despite only being 5ft 7in tall I could not fit my shoulders straight through the lower hatch and had to raise my left arm to squeeze into the tower. Once in the tower the lower hatch is shut and you are on your own. Then the water thundered in and soon went over the top of my head as I struggled to clear my ears and keep my lungs full of the hot compressed air, as the pressure rose. Eventually the lid opened and I was off to the surface.

The Norwegian divers would have had to squeeze themselves back down this narrow 6ft-high tower and through the tiny lower hatch with all of their bulky equipment - I was only wearing an immersion suit with a pair of overalls underneath and found it a tight squeeze.

After a six-hour dive they would return to the diving bell and return to the mother ship. The diving bell would be locked onto the accommodation chamber so they could remain at the same pressure, while other divers went down. Once the diving operations are over they will spend three to four days more in the chamber, to be decompressed back to the surface pressure and will have time to reflect on what they witnessed.

There may be one comforting thought to emerge from the news that the submarine rapidly flooded - any survivors caught in air pockets or breathing compressed air from the submarine's air supply would have been breathing air at the same pressure as the surrounding sea. They would have been oblivious to what was going on within a few minutes due to the effects of nitrogen narcosis that comes from breathing air (containing 80% nitrogen) at such great depths, so their suffering would have been shortlived.

Dr Mark Turner is a former diving medical officer and submarine escape instructor in the Royal Navy.
fields.bodyText: Having escaped from a submarine 300ft down during an exercise in a Scottish loch, I can perhaps imagine the situation that was faced by the Norwegian divers working on the Kursk. The water would have been bitterly cold at around 3C to 4C and even if the sun is shining on the surface it is completely dark at 400ft. This is compounded by the knowledge that even a minor accident could be fatal at that depth. The divers would not, however, have been concerned about the depth, the cold or the darkness. They spend most of their working lives in such inhospitable places. They will have spent time in a cramped saturation diving chamber on board their ship for up to 17 days. Their mother ship will keep itself positioned over the Kursk while they are diving. Even the diving bell that will lower the men to the bottom is kept at a constant height above the submarine. To combat the cold the divers wear suits that keep them dry while hot water is pumped around pipes in the suit, from the surface, to maintain their body temperature. This enables them to spend up to six hours at a time working on the submarine. They wear hard diving helmets with powerful lights and remain attached to their diving bell by an umbilical that delivers a constant supply of breathing gas. At 400ft down they will be breathing about 5% oxygen and 95% helium. If they were to breathe 20% oxygen, as on the surface, they would soon become unconscious as even oxygen is toxic at these depths. The nitrogen in the air would cause delirium and unconsciousness quickly and hence this is replaced by the inert gas helium. Usually the divers would work as a team of three with one remaining in the bell in case of emergency. All of this technology and expertise has resulted from the needs of the oil industry and thankfully enables these underwater capabilities to be available at times of need. The real fear faced by these men was what they would find in the submarine. They are used to working on oil rigs and pipelines, not salvage operations and recovering bodies. Indeed these divers share many things with the submariners lying dead inside the Kursk. Both groups of men spend their working lives under the sea facing the ever-present hazards that this environment brings. They both live in confined spaces with their colleagues for many weeks at a time - one group protecting our security, the other helping to provide the oil that powers our western lifestyle. The camaraderie and mutual respect that comes from facing adversity as a team is similar among divers and submariners. I escaped from a Royal Navy submarine in 1993 and recall the moments before my turn came to climb up into the escape tower. I was waiting with my colleagues in the escape compartment watching intently as each man was sent on his way to the surface. Despite it being an exercise I was still very anxious and sat in silence. I climbed the steel ladder that leads up into the one-man escape tower. Despite only being 5ft 7in tall I could not fit my shoulders straight through the lower hatch and had to raise my left arm to squeeze into the tower. Once in the tower the lower hatch is shut and you are on your own. Then the water thundered in and soon went over the top of my head as I struggled to clear my ears and keep my lungs full of the hot compressed air, as the pressure rose. Eventually the lid opened and I was off to the surface. The Norwegian divers would have had to squeeze themselves back down this narrow 6ft-high tower and through the tiny lower hatch with all of their bulky equipment - I was only wearing an immersion suit with a pair of overalls underneath and found it a tight squeeze. After a six-hour dive they would return to the diving bell and return to the mother ship. The diving bell would be locked onto the accommodation chamber so they could remain at the same pressure, while other divers went down. Once the diving operations are over they will spend three to four days more in the chamber, to be decompressed back to the surface pressure and will have time to reflect on what they witnessed. There may be one comforting thought to emerge from the news that the submarine rapidly flooded - any survivors caught in air pockets or breathing compressed air from the submarine's air supply would have been breathing air at the same pressure as the surrounding sea. They would have been oblivious to what was going on within a few minutes due to the effects of nitrogen narcosis that comes from breathing air (containing 80% nitrogen) at such great depths, so their suffering would have been shortlived. Dr Mark Turner is a former diving medical officer and submarine escape instructor in the Royal Navy.

webTitle: Absent patients costing NHS £18m

fields.headline: Absent patients costing NHS £18m
fields.standfirst: Special report: the future of the NHS
fields.trailText: More than 10m appointments at GP surgeries are wasted each year through patients failing to turn up for consultations with either doctors or practice nurses.
fields.body:
More than 10m appointments at GP surgeries are wasted each year through patients failing to turn up for consultations with either doctors or practice nurses.

The non-attendance is costing the NHS more than £18m a year, according to a survey published today by the Doctor Patient Partnership and Institute of Healthcare Management. The survey of more than 1,100 surgeries found the average GP lost 18 consultation slots a week because patients did not appear; the average practice nurse lost eight slots. Across the NHS, this amounted to nearly 10.5m missed appointments a year.

Since the average eight-minute consultation costs £18, the loss to the NHS is estimated at about £18.7m a year.

Simon Fradd, chairman of the DPP, an arm of the British Medical Association, said: "The message is simple, keep the appointment or cancel it. Taking responsibility in this way will help ease the strain on an over-burdened system. It's vital people are aware of the impact this has on valuable surgery time."

The government's national plan for the NHS, published last month, promised that, by 2004, all patients should be able to see a GP within 48 hours. Dr Fradd said that cutting the rate of missed appointments would help to achieve that target.

Rosey Foster, deputy chief executive of the Institute of Healthcare Management, said the figure for missed appointments was unacceptable.

Another survey, in General Practitioner newspaper, showed a growing number of GPs wanting to charge patients who missed appointments or approached doctors with problems unrelated to health. Four hundred GPs in Britain were asked if they thought charging these patients £10 for consultations was a good idea. In England, 52% of those asked supported the notion, compared with 45% asked the same question three years ago. But there was less support for charging among GPs in Scotland; only 34% of those questioned backed the idea.

Colin Francome, a professor at the department of medical sociology at Middlesex university, who carried out the survey, said: "These findings are significant... in the past doctors did not support it."

The last annual representative meeting of the BMA voted against charging for NHS consultations.

webTitle: Killer lung disease on the rise

fields.headline: Killer lung disease on the rise
fields.trailText: Rates of chronic lung disease have almost doubled over the past 10 years, mainly due to high levels of smoking among women, newly published research claims.
fields.body:
Rates of chronic lung disease have almost doubled over the past 10 years, mainly due to high levels of smoking among women, newly published research claims.

Researchers warned that if the number of teenage girls who smoked did not fall, rates of the crippling and incurable chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, which kills 3m people a year in England and Wales, would continue to rise.

Rates of the disease - the fifth most common cause of death in England and Wales - were collected from the general practice research database, which contains details of 4m patients living in England and Wales. The information was published in the journal Thorax.

Between 1990 and 1997, the proportion of women in England and Wales suffering from the disease rose from 0.8% to 1.36%. While rates for men peaked in the mid-1990s and are now steady, those for women rose every year.

Men traditionally have had much higher levels of the disease, but now more women than men under 45 suffer from it.

The study concluded: "While rates of chronic pulmonary disease seem to have peaked in men, they are continuing to rise in women. This trend, together with the ageing of the population and the long-term cumulative effect of back years of smoking in women, is likely to increase the present burden of [the disease]."

Melissa Hack, spokeswoman for the British Thoracic Society, said: "This female lung disease epidemic is the result of smoking patterns in the 1950s and 60s. Many of these women are innocent victims of the tobacco industry's sordid denials of the health effects of smoking. It is worrying that the number of teenage girls smoking is still too high. They are the lung disease patients of tomorrow. The government must redouble its efforts to reduce tobacco use in teenagers."

webTitle: Discovery of body revives pub mystery

fields.headline: Discovery of body revives pub mystery
fields.trailText: Memories of a near 30-year-old mystery resurfaced yesterday after workmen uncovered human remains in the outbuildings of a South Wales pub.
fields.body:
Memories of a near 30-year-old mystery resurfaced yesterday after workmen uncovered human remains in the outbuildings of a South Wales pub.

The Aubrey Arms inYstradgynlais, near Swansea, was closed while detectives carried out a search of the property where the discovery was made.

Locals believe the skeleton, found yesterday morning by builders converting a store room, could be that of the former landlady, Barbara Maddocks, who disappeared in October 1973.

Dyfed Powys police confirmed last night that they had launched an inquiry following the discovery but refused to comment on the find. They said forensic tests were still being carried out.

When police investigated Mrs Maddocks's disappearance 27 years ago, they dug up a roundabout opposite the pub and part of a road below a nearby bridge.

Mrs Maddocks's husband, Bill, who died of natural causes 10 years ago, insisted he knew nothing about his wife's disappearance.

Howard Evans, 75, said he remembered the landlady's disappearance well because of the commotion it caused at the time.

He said that Mrs Maddocks, whom he described as a popular, good-looking woman, had come to Wales from Australia.

"Some people thought that she might have just packed her bags and gone home. But certainly there were a lot of people who thought differently. The police were very active but didn't find anything."

webTitle: Brain-dead donors 'are not in pain'

fields.headline: Brain-dead donors 'are not in pain'
fields.trailText: Peter Hutton, president of the Royal College of Anaesthetists, yesterday issued a statement giving an assurance that brain-dead donors could not feel pain during operations to remove their organs for transplants.
fields.body:
Peter Hutton, president of the Royal College of Anaesthetists, yesterday issued a statement giving an assurance that brain-dead donors could not feel pain during operations to remove their organs for transplants.

"Anaesthetic drugs suppress unconscious physiological reflexes [such as blood pressure changes and heart rates] and can be used in this way during organ harvest procedures ... Anaesthetic drugs are not needed to supress consciousness ... the patient is already in a deep coma," he said in the joint statement with Maldwyn Morgan, president of the Association of Anaesthetists of Great Britain and Ireland.

Their declaration was triggered by consultants' fears that organ "harvesting" could be blighted by hostile public reaction to weekend reports of an argument in the profession. An editorial in the journal, Anaesthesia, called for anaesthetics to be given routinely in operations to remove the heart, lung, liver and pancreas of patients found to be brainstem-dead. Anaesthetics eliminate unconscious physical responses.

Professor Hutton said the debate should not be misinterpreted to suggest that any brain-dead person could experience pain. Some patients diagnosed as brainstem-dead might give sporadic electroencephalogram signals from the surface of the brain.

"This does not indicate their ability to appreciate pain. Indeed routine patients, anaesthetised [for surgery] have a recordable EEG, but no subsequent awareness of pain."

webTitle: Lewis Carroll letters found

fields.headline: Carroll letters found
fields.trailText: Five letters written by the author Lewis Carroll shortly before his death have been found in a locked journal and are being hailed as an important literary discovery.
fields.body:
Five letters written by the author Lewis Carroll shortly before his death have been found in a locked journal and are being hailed as an important literary discovery.

The letters, written in 1896 and 1897 were unearthed by archivists in Alnwick castle, Northumberland.

Carroll, who wrote Alice's Adventures in Wonderland, was a friend of the 7th Duke of Northumberland. One of the letters is to the duke's daughter, Muriel.

A spokesman for the 12th duke said today: "We think it is exciting as the final letter was written so close to his death and was signed Lewis Carroll as opposed to his real name, Charles Dodgson.

"We have to remember Carroll's books were the Harry Potters of their time and for the seven-year-old Muriel to have received such a letter must have been wonderful."

Mark Richards, chairman of the Lewis Carroll Society, said: "The letters will help to fill in certain gaps in the jigsaw of his life."

The letters are on display at the castle until October.

webTitle: Freak winter blast strikes Yorkshire

fields.headline: All wind and water
fields.standfirst:
Freak winter blast strikes Yorkshire
Special report: the weather
fields.trailText: Freak winter blast strikes Yorkshire.
fields.body:
The man from the met office described the great Yorkshire storm yesterday as "very exciting weather", a comment which could have caused him to have several inches of hail stuffed down his throat had he made his comment in Hedon, near Hull.

The village was reeling yesterday after it was at the centre of torrential downpours, lightning and hail which turned fields and streets white.

There has been nothing like this since snow stopped play in a cricket match in Buxton, Derbyshire, in June 1975.

The Yorkshire tempest battered an area between York and Hull. York railway station was hit by lightning four times within minutes, knocking out signalling systems and halting all trains for half an hour.

A tornado was spotted off the Humber estuary and amazed coastguards described how it created a spectacular waterspout.

Hedon yesterday was less interested in meteorological phenomena than in how to dry itself out. John Plater, who runs the village's post office, said: "There is eight inches of hail banked up by the side of the shops - the hailstones were huge.

"The water was above the road and a lot of homes and businesses have been flooded. We've had customers in their 80s saying they've never seen summer weather like this."

The Hedon HSBC bank shut its doors after water poured in, and the Nutmeg cafe was forced to shut after it was flooded.

Cafe owner Kay Bottomley said: "It started with a leak in the ceiling, then it poured through the door.

"Our back yard is four to five inches deep with hail. We're trying to mop it all up - I can't believe it."

The met office spokesman said the storm had been caused by a slow-moving trough. "These troughs let cumulonimbus clouds form at great heights and rain can persist in the places under them for some time," he said, adding that Norwich had experienced a 15mm deluge in about 40 minutes.

"Some people are calling the hail snow," he added. "But it is definitely hail and there have been hail drifts. And you can still make a snowman out of hail."

webTitle: UK news in brief

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Second arrest in abuse inquiry
fields.body:
Second arrest in abuse inquiry

Police investigating alleged physical and sexual abuse at a children's home in Rocester, Staffordshire, have charged a man with indecent assault, buggery and attempted rape. The charges relate to an inquiry into the now-closed Riverside home. One man has already been charged with sexual offences at the home.

Prince to give Lawrence talk

Prince Charles is to deliver the first Stephen Lawrence memorial lecture, it was announced yesterday. He will speak about young people from ethnic minorities getting involved in architecture in the speech on September 7. Stephen, who was killed in a racist attack in April 1993, had hoped to become an architect.

Homeless man wins lottery

A man who was sleeping rough in his car after losing his job, yesterday collected a £250,000 lottery prize.

Chris Jackson, 43, from Southend-on-Sea, Essex, won the Thunderball game in February but only realised his luck when he read about the missing winner in a local paper.

Inspiration for cave art

A cave with no electricity or running water is set to inspire an unnamed Lincolnshire artist who bought it for £30,000.

Rock House, in Wolverley, Worcestershire attracted 18 bids when it went on the market earlier this month.

Farms cleared of swine fever

Four more farms - two in Suffolk, one on Kent and one in Lincolnshire - have been by cleared by Ministry of Agriculture scientists investigating the swine fever outbreak. Seven farms have been cleared since the disease was first reported this month.

webTitle: Fury over Putin's secrets and lies

fields.headline: Fury over Putin's secrets and lies
fields.standfirst:
Russian president badly damaged by series of blunders over sunken Kursk submarine

Special report: Russia's stricken submarine
fields.trailText: As mourning shrouds Russia, the candles lit in hundreds of churches for the 118 submariners of the Kursk can only flicker in honour of their souls. For not only has all hope for the sailors' lives gone, some of the faith in a New Russia has died too.
fields.body:
As mourning shrouds Russia, the candles lit in hundreds of churches for the 118 submariners of the Kursk can only flicker in honour of their souls. For not only has all hope for the sailors' lives gone, some of the faith in a New Russia has died too.

A political inquest has begun and it was two of the youngest MPs, Boris Nemtsov, a leader of the Union of the Rightwing Forces, and Sergei Ivanenko of the centrist Yabloko party, who demanded that the Duma - Russia's lower house - holds hearings as soon as it reconvenes early next month.

As the questions pile up, the timing of when President Vladimir Putin first learned of the gravity of the accident will become more important than his inappropriate reactions.

Even yesterday, as television showed him chairing a meeting in the Kremlin, he was not in a black tie. The inquest will reveal whether the navy authorities told him the truth, and whether he can escape some blame for his insensitive behaviour by saying he was kept in the dark.

The incident which sent the Kursk to the bottom of the Barents Sea occurred at 10.31am on Saturday August 11 according to a distant boom which foreign seismic listening-devices picked up. A second loud boom followed two and a quarter minutes later. The Russian Navy says the first time it became aware of a problem was 13 hours afterwards when the Kursk failed to give a pre-arranged signal.

If this was true, it would be easy to understand how Mr Putin seemed so relaxed during a meeting with Gennady Seleznev, the Duma Speaker, at 1pm that Saturday, shortly before he set off on holiday. No one knew then that disaster had struck the pride of the navy's Northern fleet. But Mr Seleznev suggested that the navy might have known but did not see fit to tell the president. The Speaker said he too favoured a parliamentary inquiry.

The postmortem inquiry is bound to ask why it took so long for Mr Putin to accept foreign offers of help, particularly since it emerged that the navy had no deep-sea diving team and that its rescue efforts were doomed. The government failed to approach private oil companies such as Lukoil which operate drilling rigs, but in a sign that the new Russian oligarchs are still partly stuck in the past none of them offered professional help. Only a few individual divers came forward.

The lies, secrecy, and appalling insensitivity of the authorities will also merit scrutiny. It was only when the newspaper, Komsomolskaya Pravda, paid an officer under the counter to obtain the crew list that the families knew whether their loved ones were trapped in the sunken vessel. The navy itself did not tell them. Mr Putin and the government failed to come up with any offer of free transport for the relatives, let alone of organising special flights to Murmansk, until two days ago.

The navy bosses trotted out the usual Soviet-style excuse that bad weather was the reason why rescue efforts were failing. Pulling out the phoney rule "Always keep morale high", they peddled false optimism, pretending there was hope long after it was realistic.

It was only when Oleg Dobrodeyev, the chief editor of the state owned RTR television station, had the courage to insist on getting his cameramen on to the battle-cruiser leading the rescue operation that Russians began to see a little of what was going on.

Heroes

The only heroes in this sad affair have been the press. Led by the independent TV channel, NTV, and its radio stable-mate, Moscow Echo, as well as the newspapers Komsomolskaya Pravda and Novaya Gazeta they have been pointing out the contradictions in official statements, asking the searching questions, and running the blistering headlines.

For the young generation, brought up in the wild post-communism of the 1990s, the events of the past 10 days have struck an especially sharp blow. Not only were there some two dozen 19- and 20-year-old conscripts among the dead, but it is the young who most wanted to see a different, cleaner, and more accountable Russia grow out of the Yeltsin era.

"Everything I see on TV leads me to think that nothing serious is being done to save the sailors," Alexander Mramornov, a 16-year-old wrote to one Moscow paper. "In countries where the bureaucracy is not all-powerful like ours, the president takes charge."

Yesterday Mr Putin still did not seem to have embraced the country's changed mood. He allowed the cameras briefly into the cabinet room in the morning but made no formal declaration. Before being ushered out, reporters heard him say that the agenda included the tragedy in the Barents Sea as well as a report on security problems in central Asia.

"The defence minister has delivered an account of various military-technical aspects of the operations in the Barents Sea. Now we are going to talk about humanitarian aspects," the president told reporters. "The families of the sailors will get special help."

It sounded like the secretary of a provincial branch of the Communist party grudgingly running through the agenda for the benefit of a cowed and loyal press.

Shortly after he spoke, it was left - again - to the media to fill the sensitivity gap and lead the national mourning. The two main television channels, one private, the other state owned, began their evening news broadcasts with solemn music and a slow roll call of the names of every lost crew member. There was no address by the president, and no declaration of a day of mourning. Not for the first time, Russia waits for change.

Truth was the first casualty

How the navy hid the truth about the submarine's fate.

 Saturday August 12

10.31am Two explosions in forward torpedo compartment of the Kursk.

11.20pm Kursk fails to make radio contact with command. Search starts.

 Sunday August 13

3am Kursk found on seabed. Navy receives pictures showing scale of damage.

The commander of the northern fleet, Admiral Vyacheslav Popov, declares to the Russian media that the exercises were a perfect success.

 Monday August 14

10.30am Interfax and RIA Novosti, quoting sources at navy HQ in Moscow, report that a submarine is on the seabed due to "technical problems".

The navy denies that the Kursk is flooded and says there is no damage to the hull. Sonar sweeps of area report sounds, interpreted as survivors tapping hull with metal objects.

The Russian navy had neither diving bell, nor the deep-sea divers. Rescuers did nothing except film the site.

Storm begins. A spokesman for the Russian navy again claims oxygen is being supplied to the Kursk.

A hotline is established for relatives, but the navy refuses to name the crew.

The Russian mini-submarine is not as advanced as those offered by the US and Britain. The only divers Russia sent down were equipped with light diving gear, and went down at grave risk to themselves. Six almost perished in a collision with surface ship.

Storm in Barents sea abates. After a conversation with Bill Clinton, Vladimir Putin orders naval chiefs to accept foreign aid, but only offers from Norway and Britain are accepted. A navy deputy chief of staff says the crew is still signalling by tapping on the hull.

Officials later say that the last sound from the vessel came on Monday .

Russian newspaper publishes complete list of those on board, but only after paying a £440 bribe. Mr Putin says accepting foreign aid earlier would have made no difference because foul weather would have interfered with the rescue.

Western diving experts said strong underwater currents would have made little difference to their operation.

Hours before the arrival of a British submersible and its Norwegian mothership, officials say damage to the vessel is massive, and that most of the crew died within minutes of the explosions.

The deputy prime minister, Ilya Klebanov, says Norwegian divers have discovered the hatch will have to be torn off with a hauser. He also claims a man may be trapped in the escape hatch.

Norway denies the existence of the trapped man, and says its divers reached no such conclusion about opening the outer hatch. They eventually open both the outer and inner hatches relatively easily.

Even yesterday, as television showed him chairing a meeting in the Kremlin, he was not in a black tie. webTitle: Calvin Klein rises from ashes of flea market

fields.headline: Calvin Klein rises from ashes of flea market
fields.trailText: They are selling Calvin Klein knickers where the tarot card readers used to trade - such is progress in 21st century Manchester.
fields.body:
They are selling Calvin Klein knickers where the tarot card readers used to trade - such is progress in 21st century Manchester.

Mr Klein and his undies have moved into the old Corn Exchange in the city centre, which was badly damaged by the 3,300lb IRA bomb that exploded 100 metres away in 1996.

Until that big bang, the grade II listed Victorian building had been a happy flea market with a brisk trade in lava lamps, joss sticks, Oxfam-rejected clothes, medals (including the odd bit of Nazi regalia), theology books and old Beano annuals.

But the roof literally fell in on the little shops. The great glass dome, 40ft in diameter, shattered and collapsed. Some businesses never traded again, others migrated to the city's developing northern quarter.

Frogmore Investments, owners of the building, decided to go upmarket and invested £28m to create the Triangle, 100,000sq ft of trendy units including Muji, Karen Millen, Jigsaw and a Conran restaurant. It flings wide its glass doors to the public today as the remodelled city continues its inexorable march towards Strangeways jail.

"We always knew we could create something unbelieveably special at the Triangle. We have provided Manchester with a totally new trend in shopping," said Joe Malvisi, a Frogmore director. "The Triangle will add to the rich retail mix and complement the remainder of Manchester."

The building, with 800 new window frames and more than 500sq ft of new glass, faces the world's largest Marks & Spencer's and is a only a designer handbag's throw from where a Harvey Nichols store is being built.

Behind it, Manchester cathedral tries hard to fly the flag for values other than price tags. As a saxophonist wandered beneath the restored dome, staff with triangles painted on their faces handed out canapes and champagne to men and women in suits. There was not a single anorak in sight.

webTitle: Surgeon's move for would-be amputees

fields.headline: Surgeon's move for would-be amputees
fields.standfirst: Private hospital asked to allow elective surgery by banned doctor
fields.trailText: A surgeon who was forbidden by an NHS hospital to amputate the healthy limbs of patients with a rare psychological condition has applied for permission to carry out the procedure at a private hospital.
fields.body:
A surgeon who was forbidden by an NHS hospital to amputate the healthy limbs of patients with a rare psychological condition has applied for permission to carry out the procedure at a private hospital.

Robert Smith, an orthopaedic surgeon, attracted controversy internationally in February when it emerged that he had cut off the healthy limbs of two men - one from England and one from Germany - at Falkirk and district royal infirmary.

The men were suffering from an extremely rare form of body dysmorphic disorder known as apotemenophilia. Those suffering from the disease have an obsessive belief that their body is "incomplete" with four limbs and will only be complete after they have had one or more arms or legs removed.

Surgeons across Europe had turned down the men before Mr Smith agreed to treat them as private patients. However the board of the NHS trust which runs the hospital had no idea that Mr Smith was carrying out the procedures. When the news broke they banned him from doing any more amputations.

At the time, Mr Smith said he had six more patients waiting to be considered for amputation, two of whom had been fully assessed by psychiatrists as suitable candidates.

Yesterday it emerged that Mr Smith, who previously waived his fee for the operation, had applied to carry out the procedures at the Abbey King's Park hospital, near Stirling, where he carries out routine surgery.

Beth Martin, matron manager of the hospital, said: "I can confirm he has applied for permission to our medical advisory committee. It has to go before the committee. It will be treated on its own merits."

The medical world is split over the efficacy and morality of Mr Smith's actions. Although the surgeon insists there is no alternative for a small number of people but to amputate, Katharine Phillips, director of the body dysmorphic disorder programme at Butler hospital, Rhode Island, in the United States, says surgery is almost never helpful.

Mr Smith yesterday said the attitude of the medical world must change since those suffering from apotemenophilia were resorting to extreme measures - including shooting off their limbs and lying on railway tracks.

"We are talking abut absolutely desperate people, who feel incomplete with what most people might regard as a normal body, but complete once they are amputees. Because the medical community will generally not offer them the surgery they require, these people are resorting to desperate measures to achieve amputation. Many have died in the process," he said.

Only a handful of surgeons in the world - in Russia, Canada and Austria - are prepared to amputate on apotemenophiliacs, and sufferers generally hear of these surgeons via the internet. Both of Mr Smith's previous patients had below-the-knee amputations and are said to be living normal lives after the operation.

Mr Smith had a previous application to carry out the procedure at the private hospital turned down. But Ms Martin said that would not affect the new application, which is due to be considered when the hospital advisory committee next meets.

There is nothing illegal in the UK about the amputation of healthy limbs in these types of cases, and medical ethicists say it can be considered as akin to gender reassignment. But no guidelines exist on how to treat the condition. Ian Medley, of the Royal College of Psychiatrists, said amputation was generally discouraged.

webTitle: Fat wedges between success and failure

fields.headline: Fat wedges between success and failure
fields.standfirst: Best practice long way off in top pay
fields.trailText: Discussions of top pay invariably produce a split, some would say a chasm, between those who reckon the market must decide the appropriate level of remuneration and those who believe companies must be free to offer incentives, which will allow them to recruit and retain the best people, and those for whom it is simply a question of fat cats and gravy trains.
fields.body:
Discussions of top pay invariably produce a split, some would say a chasm, between those who reckon the market must decide the appropriate level of remuneration and those who believe companies must be free to offer incentives, which will allow them to recruit and retain the best people, and those for whom it is simply a question of fat cats and gravy trains.

But whichever side of the debate you stand on, three issues emerge with particular clarity from today's Guardian-Inbucon survey.

The first is what in the jargon is often referred to as "golden goodbyes" - payments to directors leaving the company.

Two points here. First, directors who choose to leave for other jobs should not be paid a golden goodbye. It may be that early leavers have accrued benefits over a period of service which have not yet fallen due and feel they need to be compensated. Forgoing such benefits, however, must be a factor for executives to take into account in deciding whether or not to move. The issue should not be settled at shareholders' expense.

Directors who are forced out are another matter. There is a powerful argument for saying there should not be rewards for failure. But life is seldom that easy. Departures can be sparked, for example, by a genuine division over the best direction for the company to take rather than any perceived incompetence or failure. It is clearly in the best interests of shareholders if such de partures are achieved with the minimum of disruption. The question is the price. Companies might consider the idea of Hollywood-style prenuptual agreements: shareholders would at least know where they stood.

Second, remuneration packages are increasingly complex. Pay, pensions, bonuses, share options can all be important parts of an overall deal. It would surely be a good idea if companies were to adopt identical methods of reporting the various ingredients - ideally with sufficient information to allow shareholders to assess easily the overall value.

Finally, the morality of the size of the rewards on offer. Among the ranks of men in suits listed in our tables this morning is just one woman. At a time when the educational establishment has gone into a worried huddle about laddish culture and underachievement the composition of Britain's boards is surely a matter which demands equal concern. Perhaps the City could start with a "gender and achievement" website of the kind being launched by the Department of Education and Employment in order to promote best practice.

EasyJet snub

EasyJet's decision not to extend its initial public offering to retail investors sits uncomfortably with its no-frills image.

Its argument that, if it opened up the offer, the subsequent scramble for shares could leave many with disappointingly small stakes might appear rather arrogant but does have some merit. EasyJet's flair for publicity means it has a high profile which could attract widespread interest in the stock.

It could try to satisfy the potential retail demand by reserving all the shares being offered for small investors, but ruling out institutional support is hardly a sensible course. That said, even if EasyJet is not overstating its attractions, it may be underestimating the sophistication of retail investors.

Many would probably be happy with a modest stake in a firm whose services they probably use and whose "small guy takes on big guy" approach they may well admire. Whatever the likelihood of disappointment to some investors if they were to receive only small allotments in an offer open to retail investors, EasyJet will disappoint more fans by restricting it to business class.

Marriage lines

Yesterday's document from the UK and German supervisory authorities on the iX merger was understandably long on principle and rather shorter on detail. It is for the exchanges to propose the arrangements they want to set in place before the authorities can decide the extent such proposals meet its criteria for properly run markets.

For the supervisors as much as the exchanges, the devil will be in the detail. Some degree of harmonisation already exists or is looming into view on a European Union-wide basis, but that will hardly suffice for an undertaking of this nature which seeks to marry two cultures as well as two sets of rules. The problems will arise when it comes, for example, to defining what constitutes on and off exchange trading, or tricky issues such as determining what constitutes normal market size - baffling to outsiders, perhaps, but vitally important to market participants.

The supervisors, just as much as the exchanges, will have to come up with solutions which not only work but which do not appear to lean more towards one of the existing regimes in London and Frankfurt than to the other.

webTitle: BT's big investors run out of patience

fields.headline: BT's big investors run out of patience
fields.trailText: The patience of BT's institutional investors is wearing thin as a wave of criticism hit the telecoms group yesterday about its perceived "foot dragging" over proposed disposals.
fields.body:
The patience of BT's institutional investors is wearing thin as a wave of criticism hit the telecoms group yesterday about its perceived "foot dragging" over proposed disposals.

A number of institutional investors called for management change if BT did not accelerate its list of possible flotations - which include BT Cellnet, its internet arm Openworld and possibly its transatlantic business alliance with AT&T, known as Concert.

"I think the management have disappointed greatly - and although they did something last week, it may not prove to be sufficient," said a senior fund manager at one of BT's top 10 British institutional investors.

"Something major needs to happen - a management change, a hastening up of a splitting-off," the fund manager said.

BT is planning a partial public sale of Yell, its directory service, before the end of the year.

The management changes called for were at the top level, with the targeted replacements being chief executive Sir Peter Bonfield and finance director Robert Brace.

Another fund manager said: "[Analysts are] looking for a managerial change. The analysts seem to have lost total confidence in the finance director, and that's a problem."

One institutional investor which holds at least 1% of the company, said: "You cannot fix the share price overnight. We have a fair amount of confidence in Bonfield, but think there's an entrenched civil service mentality in BT that takes years to shift."

webTitle: Peugeot talks: Ryton workers threaten all-out stoppage

fields.headline: Peugeot talks: Ryton workers threaten all-out stoppage
fields.standfirst: Crisis talks between unions and management to prevent an all-out strike at Peugeot's Coventry plant broke up last night without a deal,  writes Terry Macalister .
fields.trailText: Crisis talks between unions and management to prevent an all-out strike at Peugeot's Coventry plant broke up last night without a dea
fields.body:
But the two sides agreed to further discussions tomorrow, and Peugeot officials expressed confidence in a breakthrough.

A spokesman for the Transport & General Workers Union warned that the French car manufacturer would have to back down on plans to introduce Friday night working.

Peugeot said it expected the talks to go on for some time, as there were a range of issues in contention. It said it had offered to give a 17% wage increase to those on a weekend shift pattern in return for an increase in hours from 29 to 35.

Workers at the Ryton plant, pictured above, twice went out on 24-hour strike last month and threatened to escalate the action to an all-out stoppage when they came back from their summer break yesterday.

That action was post poned after Peugeot management agreed to put off the introduction of new working arrangements for three weeks.

The TGWU and the Amalgamated Engineering and Electrical Union had recommended a revised offer from Peugeot that would cut the maximum working week from 39 hours to 36 hours. But the Coventry workforce voted by 1,270 to 1,239 to reject the revised offer because it could involve compulsory overtime and Friday night shifts.

Peugeot has lost production of its top-selling 206 model estimated to be worth more than £12m because of the stoppages.

webTitle: Channel 4 crew charged with spying in Liberia

fields.headline: Channel 4 crew charged with spying in Liberia
fields.trailText: Four members of a Channel 4 independent production company who have been detained in Liberia were last night charged with espionage, their lawyer said. They were moved to the main prison in the capital Monrovia.
fields.body:
Four members of a Channel 4 independent production company who have been detained in Liberia were last night charged with espionage, their lawyer said. They were moved to the main prison in the capital Monrovia.

Legal sources in the west African country said they faced up to 10 years in prison if found guilty.

The team from Insight News, comprising two Britons, a Sierra Leonean and a South African, arrived on August 1 to shoot a documentary about Liberia. A British director, David Barrie, a Zimbabwean-born cameraman, Timothy Lambon, a South African cameraman, Gugulakhe Radebe, and a Sierra Leonean filmmaker, Samoura Sorious, have been under arrest since last Friday.

Channel 4 insists that the crew were in Liberia on legitimate journalistic business. A spokesman said the documentary was about Liberia's recovery from years of civil war, and denied that it was intended as an attack on the government.

There have been repeated allegations that Liberia is prolonging the war in Sierra Leone by arming rebels there. Both Britain and the US have linked Liberia's president, Charles Taylor, to illegal sales of diamonds from rebel-controlled mines.

Liberia's deputy information minister, Milton Teahjay, told BBC Radio on Sunday that according to documents found in the TV crew's hotel, they were using "prepackaged" information to build a case against Liberia.

"Prearranged information had been packaged to implicate the Liberian government in the issue of diamond smuggling and gun running... allegations that we have continually denied," he said.

"They affirmed these claims in their scripts, saying that they have spoken to the president and other officials of the government, when in fact they have not had any official contact with any of these officials. This is technical espionage."

"The validity of the evidence will be determined by the courts, but what we have in our possession constitutes a threat to our national security." Mr Teahjay said that the men had been accredited as journalists in Liberia, but had started filming without permission.

In the indictment read to the four men yesterday, the sheriff defined espionage as revealing "national defence installations to a foreign power with the purpose of injuring Liberia, or of benefiting a foreign power in the event of military and diplomatic confrontation with Liberia".

A Liberian solicitor retained by Channel 4 to represent the men saw them in custody yesterday and said they were well.

President Bill Clinton's special envoy to Africa Jesse Jackson, has made a personal plea to Mr Taylor for their immediate release.

A Channel 4 spokesman, Matt Baker, added yesterday that the men were making a three-part documentary series looking at African issues through the eyes of African journalists.

"They went to Liberia to look at how the country was recovering and trying to re-establish stability after a period of civil war," he said. "They did not go into Liberia with any intention or prefabricated evidence to specifically look at the issues of diamond-smuggling in relation to Sierra Leone."

The British honorary consul in Monrovia is monitoring the case. Channel 4 is also preparing to fly a British lawyer to Monrovia to assist in their defence.

webTitle: Management bid for Seagram 'lacks clout'

fields.headline: Management bid for Seagram 'lacks clout'
fields.trailText: Analysts said yesterday that either of the world's largest drinks groups were more likely to win the wines and spirits arm of Seagram, the entertainment group, than a management-led takeover.
fields.body:
Analysts said yesterday that either of the world's largest drinks groups were more likely to win the wines and spirits arm of Seagram, the entertainment group, than a management-led takeover.

A report in yesterday's Wall Street Journal indicated that the management of the spirits and wines business had discussed launching a joint offer with Charles Bronfman, the vice-chairman of the family firm, and overseas bidders.

Analysts said that it would be difficult for the management team to find backers to pay as much as Allied Domecq or Diageo.

Ian Shackleton, a drinks analyst for Donaldson, Lufkin and Jenrette, said: "Our thinking is that it's going to be very difficult for the existing management to offer anything like the same price [as the larger firms]".

Both Allied and Diageo, which has paired up with Pernod Ricard to consider a joint bid, are likely to use potential cost savings to justify a higher price. Analysts estimate the price for the drinks business, which owns brands such as Captain Morgan rum, Chivas Regal whisky and Martell cognac, at about $7bn.

The management team is understood to have approached investors in Asia and Europe about financing a bid. Another possible partner is Bacardi, the drinks company which failed to come to an agreement with Diageo about launching a joint offer.

webTitle: Today's radio

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: On The Ropes/The New World Of War
fields.body:
If anyone should know what caused the spectacular decline of Marks and Spencer you'd have thought it might be Sir Richard Greenbury, chairman and chief executive at the time. But John Humphrys fails to get a clear explanation from him in On The Ropes (9.0am, Radio 4). The firm was making a £1-billion-a-year profit until business suddenly went pear-shaped. Perhaps he had been too arrogant and overbearing? Absolutely not: nothing was done without the board's consent. All a bit of a mystery, really.

Gerry Northam's study of The New World Of War (8.0pm, Radio 4) has acquired unexpected timeliness with the disclosure of the RAF's embar rassingly patchy bombing record in Kosovo. In the first of two programmes, Northam examines how strategists think modern technology will change the nature of combat. But he also considers a new, and unforeseen, type of adversary - keyboard crazies who enjoy nothing better than hacking into the Pentagon's most sensitive systems.

webTitle: Shell collectors scan Israel

fields.headline: Shell collectors scan Israel
fields.standfirst:
Special report: e-finance
Net news
Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: The father and daughter team behind internet incubator Oxygen are planning a flotation of an investment vehicle focused on the burgeoning Israeli hi-tech sector.
fields.body:
The father and daughter team behind internet incubator Oxygen are planning a flotation of an investment vehicle focused on the burgeoning Israeli hi-tech sector.

Michael Edelson and his 26-year-old daughter Emma hope Tel Aviv-based tecc-IS will attract an initial valuation of around £10m following a £5m fundraising on AIM.

Mr Edelson, dubbed "Shellmeister" in the City after developing a speciality in bringing private companies on to the stock market, was the driving force behind high-profile flotations including Knutsford, Magic Moments and Poptones, the recently listed record company.

He has attracted a wide following among retail investors, sending the share price of companies such as Knutsford and Oxygen soaring.

However, some investors have criticised him after finding that the shares they bought at the height of the frenzy have later fallen in price, leaving them nursing paper losses.

Ms Edelson is a former employee of Mark McCormack's IMG sports marketing group and a director of Oxygen.

Tecc-IS, chaired by Joseph Riback, aims to give UK investors exposure to early stage Israeli technology companies that have not yet attracted the attention of major venture capital groups. Government support has turned the Israeli hi-tech sector into one of the most influential in the world.

"It is in my view potentially the Silicon Valley of a larger Europe," Mr Riback said.

Investment decisions will be taken by tecc-IS's board and a six strong advisory panel of Israeli and European technology experts. Their first move will be to spend £500,000 on a 30% stake in Smashing Concepts, a fledgling artificial intelligence firm.

Oxygen will take a 10% stake in tecc-IS. Netvest.com will hold 4% and its chairman ,Andrew Balcombe, will sit on the tecc-IS board. Insinger Townsley is broker to the float.

webTitle: Kirsty Jones' body 'lay unfound for 15 hours'

fields.headline: Kirsty's body 'lay unfound for 15 hours'
fields.trailText: The body of the murdered British backpacker Kirsty Jones lay undiscovered in her room at a Thai hostel for almost 15 hours, an inquest heard yesterday.
fields.body:
The body of the murdered British backpacker Kirsty Jones lay undiscovered in her room at a Thai hostel for almost 15 hours, an inquest heard yesterday.

The 23-year-old Liverpool University graduate, who was making what she had promised would be her last trip abroad before settling down, was killed shortly after returning to the Aree hostel in the northern Thai city of Chiang Mai at about midnight on August 9.

Her body was not discovered until 4.30pm, the inquest in her home town of Brecon, Powys, was told. A postmortem examination in Thailand revealed she died of asphyxia due to strangulation.

The investigation into her death has been criticised and yesterday it emerged that the chief investigator was transferred after failing to make progress. Major Panya Nirattimanont was moved from Chiang Mai and a new lead investigator has been appointed, a spokesman said.

Recording a verdict of unlawful killing, the Powys coroner, John Hollis, said: "I am satisfied that the cause of death is strangulation. There is no reason why this sad story of Kirsty's tragic death should not be brought to a close."

The coroner's officer, Michael Eckley, told the hearing that Ms Jones had left her home village, Tredomen, near Brecon, in June on a two year round the world trip. She had recently graduated with a degree in English and media studies and had told her parents this would be her last trip before starting a career.

PC Eckley said that Ms Jones died within an hour of returning to the hostel after spending the evening with a friend. According to autopsy reports the time of death was around 1am. "She lay undiscovered for almost 15 hours. It would appear according to the information we have that she was attacked almost as soon as she returned home."

Ms Jones's family, who farm 300 acres in the mid-Wales countryside, did not attend the 15 minute hearing. The inquest heard that her body was formally identified by Dyfed Powys police through fingerprints to spare the family the ordeal of having to identify her.

A family spokesman said later that Ms Jones's parents were pleased that the inquest had been concluded quickly so that they could get on with arrangements for a public funeral in their local church later this week. He said: "They want Kirsty's killer to be found and dealt with accordingly."

 Hours before her murder, Ms Jones sent a postcard to staff at a Liverpool restaurant where she worked as a barmaid.

Steven Maranto, the owner of Maranto's in Aigburth, Liverpool, said the card which arrived late last week gave no clue to her killer. It simply said Ms Jones had finished trekking in the mountains and was having a marvellous time.

webTitle: Netstore ties up European partnership

fields.headline: Netstore ties up European partnership
fields.standfirst: Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: Netstore, the recently floated application service provider which specialises in small to medium-sized businesses, said yesterday it had tied up a partnership deal with a leading European telecoms company, which it did not name. A contract was signed with BT's Ignite unit in July.
fields.body:
Netstore, the recently floated application service provider which specialises in small to medium-sized businesses, said yesterday it had tied up a partnership deal with a leading European telecoms company, which it did not name. A contract was signed with BT's Ignite unit in July.

Netstore allows companies to rent applications over the internet rather than install them on their own hardware. Shares in the company rose 4p yesterday to 136.5p following better than expected maiden full-year results. A turnover of £1.37m was reported against £800,000 last year.

Pre-tax losses widened from £1.1m to £4.9m, but broker Dresdner Kleinwort Benson said the company was on target to reach a profit by 2003.

webTitle: News from the fringe

fields.headline: Arthur Smith's daily dose
fields.standfirst:
News from the fringe

Special report: the Edinburgh festival 2000
fields.trailText: News from the fringe
fields.body:
As an assistant d'anglais in a French lycée 25 years ago, I found that an excellent way to animate a group of Parisian adolescents was to come into the classroom, stride to the blackboard and write: "English food is the best in the world". This provoked the sort of derision that only the French can manage.

Scottish food is the best in the world. Or, rather Scottish bread is. Despite my intimacy with the Edinburgh cuisine I had never, before this festival, come across "Scottish plain", a sliced white bread of such weight and substance that it ought to be invited to deliver the Reith lectures. It is much more tasteless than Scott Capurro and my arms are still aching from carrying it home. It is the only sliced bread that can properly support a decent portion of beans without degenerating into sogginess. For me it is one of the shows of the festival.

One man who, I suspect, has never eaten any food at all is John Cooper Clarke. I caught him at the book festival on Sunday night and as usual fell in love with his exquisite lightness of touch. I have met a lot of novelists, playwrights and journalists in my life but never one with such a profound respect for words. Even in our cups after his show I noted that his eloquence never waned. An emaciated, weightless man in black, he is the antithesis of Scottish plain. And they're both great.

You can contact Arthur Smith via arts@theguardian.com

webTitle: New warning on north-south divide

fields.headline: New warning on north-south divide
fields.standfirst:
Backbenchers warn prime minister to 'get his head out of the sand' as report reveals widening prosperity gap, with heartlands the losers

Special report: north-south divide
fields.trailText: Tony Blair was yesterday told by backbench MPs to "get his head out of the sand" and come to the aid of Labour's manufacturing heartlands after a new report showed that the north-south divide is widening.
fields.body:
Tony Blair was yesterday told by backbench MPs to "get his head out of the sand" and come to the aid of Labour's manufacturing heartlands after a new report showed that the north-south divide is widening.

Ronnie Campbell, who chairs the northern group of Labour MPs, urged the prime minister to stop ignoring the plight of the north-east and to do more to help England's most deprived regions.

The Blyth Valley MP's comments followed the release of a report on relative economic growth rates in the English regions, which forecast that the south-east would easily outpace other parts of the country, increasing the gap in living standards between north and south.

The figures from Oxford Economic Forecasting reignited the debate within the government over whether enough has been done to help regions hit by the slump in manufacturing.

While ministers have seized on encouraging economic figures to suggest the north-south divide is no longer an issue, backbench Labour MPs from manufacturing regions fear that voters have not seen the benefits of the good performance of the UK economy since the election.

Yesterday's report, commissioned by the Financial Times, revealed that that growth rates will be more evenly matched between regions than they were last year.

The worst performing region last year, the north-east, only just escaped recession while the east, which includes Silicon Fen, the booming hi-tech region around Cambridge, grew by nearly 4%.

This year the top performing region, the south-east, excluding London, will grow by 3.7%, while the slowest growing region, again the north-east, will expand by 2.7%.

Scotland and Wales were set to do better than the north, with Scotland to enjoy 2.9% growth, Wales 3.2%, the report said.

Although growth in the north-east is expected to improve, yesterday's figures show that the prosperity gap will once again widen this year, undermining the claim made by Mr Blair last December that the north-south divide was "over-simplistic". The prime minster insisted that the "real divide" was "between the haves and the have nots", regardless of where people lived.

Responding to the report, Mr Campbell called for a regional assembly to represent the interests of the poorer English regions. "There are regions of this country that are just being ignored," he said.

He added that Tony Blair and other senior ministers "don't seem to listen" to calls for help from the heartlands.

While acknowledging that the government had attempted to address the north-south divide, Mr Campbell said he feared that regions such as his native north-east and Cornwall were being left behind while Scotland and Wales were "marching ahead" and reaping the financial benefits of devolution.

"Those from the northern group of MPs are just whistling in the wind," he told Radio 4's Today programme. "I want a regional assembly because I think we are only going to be left behind further."

Richard Caborn, the trade minister, acknowledged that there were regional disparities and "problems inside the English regions" but he insisted that the gap was narrowing.

"There is economic under-performance, we all accept that," he told the Today programme, adding that "unemployment is falling faster in the north-east, the north-west and the west Midlands than it is in the south-east".

But John Redwood, head of the Conservative parliamentary campaigns unit, described Labour policy as a "huge betrayal" of British manufacturing, while the shadow chancellor, Michael Portillo, accused the government of exacerbating the north-south divide through taxes which were "felt most heavily in the least prosperous parts of the country".

The government has sought to head off criticism from its backbenchers over the widening north-south divide in recent months. In March, the chancellor, Gordon Brown, unveiled plans for a private sector partnership with the European Investment Bank to generate £1bn of new economic development across the UK.
