But a report by the all-party Commons select committee on education and employment concluded in April that there was still a distinctive north-south pattern, with unemployment in southern regions still substantially below the average regional level.

North: 'The pits' without industry
Martin Wainwright

The offers in Poundstretcher in Blyth are spectacular enough - babies' T-shirts for 59p, a pack of six videos for a fiver - but Northumberland's largest town has a shop called Pennystretcher too. Here in the heart of the northern side of the north-south divide, suntan cream will cost you £2.75, styling gel 65p and a four-bedroom mid-terrace house invites offers over £34,750.

Such price tags spell an economy in trouble, but one which, to those in decent jobs, offers a quality and cost of living that is unimaginably cheap to any over-mortgaged commuter down south.

A mixture of gloom and tenacious loyalty marks people sunning themselves in the Market Square or splashing in the park paddling pool on the road out to Seaton Sluice.

"Blyth is the pits - there's been no goal for anyone here since all the big industries closed down," says Sharon, a dancer who left in despair for neighbouring Cramlington eight years ago. "It's a town with a skeleton crew. They employed thousands in those days. Now the new companies take people on in ones and twos."

Her friend Wendy takes the opposite view, saying: "I wouldn't live anywhere but Blyth, and that includes Halifax where I was born." The port, with its aluminium smelting trade, nine gleaming modern windmills on the quayside and 31,800 people - who all seem to know one another - suits her just fine. It even has excitements; a neighbour, Carol Westgarth, attracted national headlines and the interest of Kew Gardens when her yucca plant spontaneously combusted last year.

Unemployment has also halved since 1996 to 5.1%, although Bill Tarbit, economic development officer for Blyth Valley council, scratches his head over where the claimants have gone. The local economy has an over-dependence on manufacturing (39% of the workforce), with subsequent damage from the strong pound, and a crushing difficulty in attracting new private companies to move in.

"We have so much going for us here," says Mr Tarbit. (He is just back from a stay in Oxford, whose congested roads vie with the "obvious buzz of prosperity everywhere down there" in his holiday memories.) "But it is very difficult attracting the private sector up here. We really need more incentives from government - business rate reductions, better infrastructure. New commuter houses are now the neighbours of the Marquis of Hastings, whose impressive Seaton Delaval Hall is Vanburgh's third masterpiece after Castle Howard and Blenheim Palace. Tourists are also arriving to see such relatively undiscovered wonders. "They come to watch our windmills too," says Mr Tarbit. "They're very calming, and we're getting the world's biggest sea-windmill on a rig off the harbour shortly."

Such cutting edge enterprise is apparent in the new Euro-Seas specialist base in Blyth dry docks, a testing centre for undersea technology.

But Jo Wells is an even more welcome arrival, as one of Blyth's metropolitan exiles who has decided to come back home.

"I left as a teenager - I couldn't wait to get out," she says. "But now I'm back, I really appreciate the beauty of the area, the friendliness, the beaches and my family - all the things I took for granted."

She has had to downshift, aged 32, from a job in book publishing to working as a women's rugby development officer for Northumberland county council. But she won't be jumping back over the divide.

South: Town on crest of new wave
Steven Morris

Monday morning, and the Buckinghamshire town of High Wycombe is full of activity. Well heeled shoppers park their cars and head for the stores with the inclination to spend.

Twenty years ago the picture was very different. Many shops were boarded up and, watching the pennies, housewives waited for the Tuesday market before venturing into town. Traditional industries were under threat, and townspeople faced an uncertain future.

Since then, High Wycombe has become typical of south-east towns that have boomed thanks to an influx of hi-tech and service industries.

The town's former prosperity was based largely on the furniture industry. The earliest factories were established in the 18th century, and by the middle of the 19th more than a million chairs a year were being produced. Later light engineering and paper mills powered by the river Wye gave work to many thousands of people.

Over the past 100 years or so, however, the nature of employment in the town changed. Though still home to a few of the most famous furniture makers, such as Ercol, the vast majority of the factories have shut down. The last paper mill closed recently, and engineering companies have struggled.

High Wycombe could have suffered the same fate as towns in the midlands and north whose traditional industries have been wrenched from them. Instead its leaders were acute - or lucky - enough to spot the changing trend and begin to attract new types of business to the area.

In the Wycombe district, 25% of jobs are now in banking, finance and insurance. World famous companies attracted by the town's superb transport links - London and Heathrow are only 30 minutes away, and motorways make the south coast ports easily accessible - include the software company SAS, the car manufacturers Saab and Volvo and the pharmaceutical company Monsanto.

Industrial estates have sprung up around the town, executives being attracted to sites on the edge of the Chiltern hills yet within striking distance of the capital.

In a survey by the business information researchers Dun and Bradstreet, also based in High Wycombe, the town was judged the sixth most profitable in Britain (Brighton was first). Only 1.4% of the 163,000 people who live in the district are unemployed and claiming benefit.

But affordable housing for young people and those who have not thrived in this boom is at a premium. A three bedroom former council semi on an ordinary estate would cost around £150,000, while a similar house nearer the centre would fetch more than £200,000.

Peter Cartwright, chairman of the Tory-run district council's housing and economic development committee, said there was a shortage of land on which to develop, as the town was hemmed in by green belt.

"There is little we can do to create new affordable housing," he said.

In July the council had to find bed and breakfast accommodation for 29 people, compared with only two the previous summer - small numbers but indicative of a trend.

And because many younger and less affluent people are being driven away, it is becoming harder to fill certain lower paid jobs. There is a desperate shortage of bus drivers, postmen and shopworkers.

The council's economic development department emphasises that pockets of deprivation remain in High Wycombe. In one ward, unemployment among Afro-Caribbean and Asian communities is above 30%.

webTitle: Builders in at Conservatives' headquarters

fields.headline: Tories take knocks from a Blair
fields.trailText: If William Hague is not already facing an uphill struggle to win the next election he has now got the nightmare that every householder dreads ... the builders are moving in.
fields.body:
If William Hague is not already facing an uphill struggle to win the next election he has now got the nightmare that every householder dreads ... the builders are moving in.

For the next six months press conferences at the Conservatives' headquarters in Smith Square, central London, are likely to be punctuated by hammer blows and drilling as a large office development takes shape next door. Central Office failed to put in soundproofing when it spent millions refitting the news conference room.

Tory thinkers planning the next 'common sense revolution' will also have to make themselves heard above the cacophony of electricians installing hi-tech computer cables, and plumbers putting in shower rooms at the back of their headquarters.

To add to Mr Hague's embarrassment the person in charge of this latest disruption for the Tories shares the same surname as the prime minister. Simon Blair, managing director of London and Country Estates, and landlord to Tory Central Office, is going ahead with the noisy office scheme in the run-up to the next general election.

The irony is that Mr Blair had offered the Tories a "noise free" deal - on their agreement to the development of 26 luxury flats behind Central Office. The deal would have involved moving out Mr Hague's top thinkers, and arrangements to limit the noise while the builders pounded.

At the last minute Conservative office managers demanded a six-figure sum in compensation, presumably to help fill the coffers for the election campaign. Simon Blair said the managers also told him they did not want the work to start this September because they feared the prime minister would call a snap October general election; they therefore used their tenancy powers to veto the deal.

But officials at Central Office were in for a shock. London and Country Estates decided to switch from luxury flats to luxury office suites. And under the tenancy agreement Central Office had no power to object and could not claim a penny in compensation.

Mr Blair is promising to be kind to them. "We are gutting the building which does share a party wall with the back of Central Office where the news conference room is. But we do intend to get the worst of the drilling over in the next two months leaving normal building noises, like putting in partition walls, for later in the year. The whole work should be finished in the spring."

Mr Hague must be hoping this is one construction deadline that will be met. Otherwise the builders could still be there if the other Mr Blair calls a May general election.

webTitle: Comment: West partially to blame for Russia's current plight

fields.headline: Russia's fall
fields.standfirst:
The west must accept its share of responsibility for Russia's current plight
Special report: Russia
Special report: Russia's stricken submarine
fields.trailText: The west must accept its share of responsibility for Russia's current plight.
fields.body:
What has the fate of the Russian submariners to do with the Siberian tiger? Mr Putin's powerlessness in the face of the trapped submariners is a symptom of a much more widespread weakness. Russia's crumbling state could do nothing to save the Kursk, and not much to prevent still worse catastrophes from happening in the future.

It is not only the country's nuclear facilities that are rusting away - at fearful risk to Russia and the world, as Gwyn Prins wrote last week. An enfeebled state cannot stop the plundering of Russia's natural resources. Illegal logging is destroying its forests. Deeply scarred by 70 years of Soviet central planning, Russia's environment is now at grave risk from the decay of the Russian state.

Mr Putin's efforts to strengthen the authority of government have been lauded in the west. Yet his policies do not bode well for the protection of nature in Russia. He is credited with seeking to rein in the mafias that are thriving in the wake of the country's failed transition to a western-style market economy. But he has chosen to abolish two of its principal environmental agencies - the State Committee for Environmental Protection and the Federal Forestry Service - that have curbed poaching in the past. As a result, the wild Siberian tiger - already reduced to a few hundred in numbers - faces extinction in the near future.

At the same time, Russia's human population has gone into free fall. Over the past decade it has dropped by around 6m. On present trends it will shrink by nearly 40m more over the next quarter-century. Poor nutrition, alcohol abuse and, to an increasing but not precisely measurable extent, intravenous drug use have produced a drastic reduction in life expectancy. Over half the teenage boys living in Russia today will not reach 60. A parallel drop in birth rates has come about owing to a ruined healthcare system, large numbers of infant deaths and the widespread use of abortion as a means of contraception. Russia is facing a population collapse unprecedented in any peacetime country.

Russia's desperate plight is unique in modern history and calls for explanation. Curiously, western governments are silent as to its causes. It is as if the conditions that prevail in Russia had nothing whatever to do with them. Rightly, the west is giving economic and humanitarian aid, but no one accepts any responsibility for the conditions that have made it necessary. None of the transnational agencies which shaped Russia's economic policies at the behest of western governments has admitted any role in bringing the country to its present pass. Nor, so far as I know, has any of the army of western advisers who trooped in and out of the country touting the virtues of the free market.

In fact, not a single person accepts responsibility for urging on Russia economic policies utterly unsuited to its history and circumstances. Apparently, no one told Russia's economic reformers to scrap price controls - a move that was bound to trigger inflation, given the strength of monopolies in the economy. Equally, it seems, no one recommended the reckless privatisations that left much of the country's resources in the hands of a few oligarchs. Presumably it is Russia's rulers who must shoulder all the blame - the west's hands are clean.

The Russian government should not be exempt from criticism. As its wooden response to the tragedy of the Kursk has shown, Soviet habits die hard. Even so, the desperate straits in which the region finds itself today are as much an indictment of the west as they are of Russia's rulers.

The country's misfortune is that the collapse of communism coincided with market triumphalism in the west. The crackpot policies that were foisted on it had little to do with the country's needs and everything to do with the neo-liberal hubris that had gripped western governments. It was clear from the start that the country's uniquely daunting problems required pragmatic solutions, not ideologically-driven programmes. It never made any sense to imagine that the Russian economy - largely a military-industrial rustbelt - could be made over into an Anglo-Saxon free market.

Predictably, the results of attempting this impossible task have been ruinous. The upshot of a decade of western-inspired reforms in Russia is that anti-western feeling is stronger than it has been for generations. Xenophobia and anti-semitism are rife. Fervently pro-western 10 years ago, Russia has now reverted to all the troubled ambiguities of its historic relationship with the west.

The credit for this remarkable turn-about must go chiefly to western policy-makers. Russia has wasted a decade following worthless western advice. As a consequence, today it has few options open to it, none of them attractive.

Before it can have a modern economy Russia must have a modern state. That is what Mr Putin seems to be trying to build up from the privatised fragments of the totalitarian apparatus he has inherited. It is too early to know whether the Russian leader's policies are the beginnings of a reassertion of government, or merely another episode in internecine conflict within the oligarchy. An authoritarian state might be an acceptable outcome if it really meant - as Mr Putin has claimed - "the dictatorship of law". If it turns out to mean the rule of the oligarchs by other means, the future is dark. Anarchy may be staved off, but at the price of despotism.

The entombed submariners and the vanishing Siberian tiger may seem worlds apart, but they are casualties in the same ongoing catastrophe. It would be pleasant to think that the loss of the Kursk might stir some new thinking on western policy towards Russia. The dismal record of the past decade suggests we should not be holding our breath.

 John Gray is professor of European thought at the LSE

webTitle: Forminster in fine form

fields.headline: Forminster in fine form
fields.trailText: Aside from Matalan, investment in clothing retailers has brought little but pain for shareholders in the last couple of years. Forminster, which owns the UK franchise for the French fashion label Kookai, has been no exception. It shares, which closed last night at 37.5p, were changing hands at 65p a year ago.
fields.body:
Aside from Matalan, investment in clothing retailers has brought little but pain for shareholders in the last couple of years. Forminster, which owns the UK franchise for the French fashion label Kookai, has been no exception. It shares, which closed last night at 37.5p, were changing hands at 65p a year ago.

But according to research from securities house Deutsche Bank, this fall may have gone to far. Deutsche reckons Forminster's put option on its 15% stake in Kookai alone is worth £10.9m, equivalent to around 88% of its market capitalisation. This leaves its UK business, which is showing real signs of recovery, trading on a prospective price to earnings ratio of just 1.6. Placing it on a conservative ratio of 5.0 - the unweighted sector average is nearer 9.3 - produces a share price of nearer 47p.

Deutsche yesterday upgraded its rating on Forminster to "buy".

webTitle: Edinburgh: Comedy: A Life In Football

fields.headline: A man of two halves
fields.standfirst:
Around Edinburgh: A dog, but not as we know it

Special report: the Edinburgh festival 2000
fields.trailText: In Edinburgh's Stand comedy club, one of the true giants of football is holding forth magnificently - if a little unsteadily - upon the game.
fields.body:
In Edinburgh's Stand comedy club, one of the true giants of football is holding forth magnificently - if a little unsteadily - upon the game.

"There's too much money in football," he splurts, struggling not to spill his Smirnoff. "In my day we were on 2s 6d a week, but we had enough for a pint of beer, 20 fags, a night with a prostitute and still buy Stirling Albion." He details his inglorious career, playing for "Tottenham, and Spurs" and his panic at being told "Wolves" were after him ("I started howling"). Then there were his six disastrous marriages, one to Petula Clark ("sadly dead now"), another to Sir Cliff Richard ("sadly dead at the time").

This is Bob "the Gob" Doolally, spoof football pundit par excellence. The character - just as well-observed as Al Murray's the Pub Landlord, last year's Perrier winner - is attracting capacity audiences night after night at the Stand. You do not have to know football to appreciate the Gob. Football is simply his excuse for needle-sharp observations on the British psyche.

Doolally is the creation of 43- year-old Scotsman Paul Sneddon, whose background in theatre informs his alter ego's occasionally almost Shakespearean bearing. After three fruitless years doing stand up on the fringe, Sneddon decided to reinvent himself. He considered doing a show called 101 Great Moments in Scottish Sport ("a joke in itself") and out of this came Bob. He toured with Al Murray; a bigger influence was a Sean Cullen character called Dame Sybil, an ageing actress.

One of the reasons that Doolally is such a success is that he is only a mild exaggeration of real life. He is a "rabid mongrel", says Sneddon, of managers such as Bill Shankly, Tommy Docherty, Brian Clough and "a recognisable Scottish archetype, the old geezer in a pub".

Sneddon has honed the character with remarkable attention to detail. He remembers a TV programme where the likes of Docherty and Denis Law always referred to their own teams as "Manchester United football claaaab" but others as simply "Huddersfield", or whatever. This became a catchphrase along with "sadly dead now", "great plarrrrrr" and "close paahsonal friend of mine".

Most of Doolally's preposterous spoofs are rooted in the nostalgia-obsessed, name-dropping after- dinner-speech circuit ("I get invited to speak myself now. Isn't that bizarre?") but his more dangerous flights of fancy expose the underbelly of professional football. Even in interview, he casually recounts mind-boggling, slanderous tales about a former English manager who apparently encouraged his team to drink before matches and had a fondness for transvestite prostitutes. George Best's latest alcohol-induced health scare gave him acres of material. He could do an entire show on "Bestie".

There are tentative plans for a TV series; Sneddon is in negotiations with BBC Scotland. But he seems genuinely unaware of the potentially money-spinning phenomenon he has on his hands, a cult anti-hero who could easily become bigger than Murray. "It's out of my control," he says, before lapsing back into character to tell an outrageous joke involving Stanley Matthews's preparation for matches. The only thing that can stop him, it seems, is a Football Association inquiry. "FA?" slurps the Gob. "F-all! Freeloading blazered idiot bastid gits who know nothing about the game. Of course," he says, composing himself, "they are all close paahsonal friends of mine."

Bob Doolally: A Life In Football is at The Stand comedy club (0131-558 7272) till Sunday.

webTitle: Leader: Belfast's turf wars don't have to threaten the peace

fields.headline: Belfast's turf wars
fields.standfirst:
They don't have to threaten the peace
Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: The last few days of violent feuding in Belfast between the two main loyalist groupings, the Ulster Defence Association and the Ulster Volunteer Force, has been depressing. It culminated yesterday in a double shooting outside a betting shop that left two dead. The UDA blamed the UVF.
fields.body:
The last few days of violent feuding in Belfast between the two main loyalist groupings, the Ulster Defence Association and the Ulster Volunteer Force, has been depressing. It culminated yesterday in a double shooting outside a betting shop that left two dead. The UDA blamed the UVF.

Such in-fighting is alarming, raising doubts about whether the loyalist ceasefire will hold; at the same time, troops are returning to the streets of Belfast. To the naked eye these developments look like the early signs of a return to the Troubles - as if the achievements of the peace process are beginning to unravel. But such panic may be premature. For the latest violence comes with a context.

The current hostilities are within communities, not between them. That is little comfort for those grieving their dead, but it means there is not the same threat to Northern Ireland that would exist if loyalists and republicans were murdering each other. Of course, that could change if loyalist infighting began to spill over into attacks on the Catholic population. But there is nothing so far to suggest that is about to happen.

The Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Mandelson, is justified in asking the Royal Ulster Constabulary for a report on the weekend's events. While it is difficult for the RUC to deal with isolated gunmen, it is reasonable to ask why it was unable to tackle what was essentially a mob running amok in Belfast's Shankill Road on Saturday.

It was politically mischievous, as well as dangerous, for the Conservative spokesman on Northern Ireland, Andrew Mackay, to suggest yesterday that events justified his party's opposition to prisoner release and decommissioning. He has been holidaying abroad during key events in Northern Ireland over the past few years and he again demonstrated his lack of feel for the province yesterday. Early releases were a bitter pill to swallow, as was the lack of immediate decommissioning: but both were necessary for the wider peace process.

Of course, some of those involved in the current violence are only free because of those releases. But Mr Mackay should not be so quick to link to the peace process what is, essentially, a turf war between rival, criminal gangs. As such it is ugly and it is brutal - but it is does not have to be a mortal threat to the Good Friday agreement nor to the peace which that accord continues to promise.

webTitle: Dutch to auction Williams de Broe

fields.headline: Dutch to auction Williams de Broe
fields.trailText: Williams de Broe, the 131-year-old stockbroking firm, has been put up for auction by its Dutch parent, the bank ING, but local management is expected to a have a say in deciding the new owner.
fields.body:
Williams de Broe, the 131-year-old stockbroking firm, has been put up for auction by its Dutch parent, the bank ING, but local management is expected to a have a say in deciding the new owner.

Sources close to ING and Williams de Broe confirmed the sale yesterday. Williams de Broe management members are unlikely to exercise their right of first option to buy ING's 77.46% shareholding.

The firm has been owned by ING since 1986. In July, however, ING paid £127m for Charterhouse Securities, which immediately put a for-sale sign on Williams de Broe, according to insiders.

"They couldn't find what they were looking for with Williams De Broe, otherwise they wouldn't have made another acquisition," one said.

ING is said to be keen to develop Charterhouse Securities, a rapidly growing medium-sized broker.

A likely buyer of Williams de Broe, which has operations in Britain, Switzerland and France, is Belgium's KBC Banking and Insurance Holding Company.

"If this should come on to the market we will look into it in the same way that we would look into any other opportunity that comes on to the market," a KBC spokesman said.

KBC bid against ING for Charterhouse. Other potential buyers of Williams de Broe include France's Paribas, Banco Santanda Central Hispano of Spain and Bank of America.

ING owns its stake in Williams de Broke through its subsidiary, Banque Bruxelles de Lambert.

Both BBL and John Millar, chairman of Williams de Broke, declined to comment.

Williams de Broe has 300 staff, and in 1999 reported net profit up 50% to £6m. Its turnover increased from £34.1m to £47.1m, while shareholder equity rose from £4.5m to £8.8m.

ING did not attempt to fold Williams de Broe into its own banking and broking operations because both companies regarded their independence as important.

webTitle: Innogy devises power cut solution

fields.headline: Innogy devises power cut solution
fields.standfirst: Fuel cell storage plants to be built on both sides of Atlantic
fields.trailText: Innogy, the UK arm of National Power, yesterday confirmed plans to build plants on both sides of the Atlantic using its revolutionary fuel cell storage technology.
fields.body:
Innogy, the UK arm of National Power, yesterday confirmed plans to build plants on both sides of the Atlantic using its revolutionary fuel cell storage technology.

Each plant will use an environmentally friendly process to store enough electricity to meet the needs of 15,000 people during a power cut.

At present, the industry lacks the capacity to store large quantities of electricity. If a power station has to shut down, customers frequently experience power cuts while supplies from another generator are arranged.

Innogy's Regenesys technology, developed by an international team led by British scientists and engineers, is an electrochemical process which operates like a giant rechargable battery.

The first Regenesys plant is to be built alongside Innogy's combined cycle gas-fired power station in Little Barford, Cambridgeshire. A similar show plant is likely to be built for the Tennessee Valley authority, the US's largest public power provider.

The Regenesys system has been tested at Innogy's Aberthaw power station, south Wales, since 1996. The company believes the technology can be used to provide alternative sources of supply during peak periods and to avoid using less efficient plants when demand is heavy.

Confirmation of the Regenesys projects came as National Power published the listing requirements for its planned demerger into Innogy, an integrated British energy group, and International Power, which will develop power projects overseas.

International Power's new chief executive, Peter Giller, could be paid up to £9m in shares over the next six years. Mr Giller, the former head of ABB Energy Ventures, has elected to be paid in IP shares and not cash.

Under his three-year contract he will initially be allocated £2m of shares and become entitled to a further £1m worth for every 20% rise in the IP share price.

If the price doubled during the first three years he would be given an extra £5m worth of shares. However, he will not receive the extra shares until years four, five and six.

The base share price for Mr Giller's arrangements will be the average of the first 20 days of trading in IP shares, which is due to start on October 2.

Mr Giller will not have a company car or be a member of any company pension or health care plan. A spokesman said: "He will not be receiving any fringe benefits.

"If the share price falls, he will have only the initial £2m allocation of shares and the value of those will be less."

webTitle: Investors start to see how top teams measure up

fields.headline: Investors start to see how top teams measure up
fields.standfirst: Analysis:  John Rogers
fields.trailText: Once again, the year has seen intense interest in the remuneration arrangements for many of the UK's highest-paid executive directors.
fields.body:
Once again, the year has seen intense interest in the remuneration arrangements for many of the UK's highest-paid executive directors.

Some remuneration committees have been criticised for recommending awards for their executive colleagues which are felt by many to be over-generous and not sufficiently related to improved performance.

It seems to me that there has been relatively little criticism recently concerning the quality of executive performance - informed opinion does seem to agree, however, that top performers should be adequately compensated.

Institutional investors have traditionally been cautious about interfering too much in executive reward.

Their prime responsibility is to ensure their investments are successful in creating good long-term returns to help protect pensions and insurance policies.

Institutions, more than any other group of observers, understand that the absence of a well-paid and motivated team of executive directors can be disastrous for an enterprise. Even so, major shareholders have increasingly indicated concern where payments are seen as excessive or have been made not for the delivery of increased shareholder return but, for example, on securing a takeover.

Because many present day proposals for top directors' pay are so complex, the National Association of Pension Funds has a team of experts which prepares simplified fact sheets for agreement by the company concerned and digestion by the 110 major investing institutions.

Just as British executive reward is moving towards a US model, so the UK is set shortly to see the introduction of US-style reward assessment. A model-based approach that measures the impact of executive reward on shareholder funds could be another useful point of reference for British institutions and is an option we are investigating.

Institutional assessment of reward proposals could also be helped by clarification of relevant guidance. This is a matter the NAPF is discussing with others in the light of globalisation trends.

Institutions perceive that the government also has a role to play in relation to executive reward. In its submission to the Hampel committee on corporate governance in 1997, the NAPF called for shareholders to be allowed an annual vote on the policy of the remuneration committee.

In August 1999, the Department of Trade and Industry began an urgent consultation exercise - the aim of which was to strengthen the hand of shareholders in this area. Nothing has since been heard from government, which is faced with an awkward decision.

Should ministers further alienate boards of directors by concentrating on this particular issue, or investors, trade unions and the media by not so doing?

John Rogers is director of the NAPF's voting issues service

webTitle: £1m eases the pain of parting

fields.headline: £1m eases the pain of parting
fields.trailText: Nine of the 10 largest "golden goodbyes" last year were worth more than £1m in cash alone to the departing executive, the Guardian-Inbucon pay survey shows.
fields.body:
Nine of the 10 largest "golden goodbyes" last year were worth more than £1m in cash alone to the departing executive, the Guardian-Inbucon pay survey shows.

Final payments to senior directors are difficult to calculate because many include shares and options which inflate the value of the payouts stated in cash terms in annual reports and accounts.

Even "resigning" can prompt payments under the terms of top executives' contracts.

The payments often provoke controversy because they can be regarded as reward for failure rather than success. Last year they reflected shake-outs in some of the biggest boardrooms after long-running rows or takeovers.

None of the cash pay-offs could match the £4.9m received by Steven Kotler, an investment banker for 25 years who ran the American operations of Schroders.

Among the high-profile cases was Bob Ayling, ousted as chief executive of BA after he took the blame for the "world's favourite airline" losing its ranking in the popularity stakes.

There were large payments to senior executives at BOC, the gas group which agreed to be taken over by Air Products of the US and Air Liquid of France. These managers resigned and received pay-offs, only to see the talks collapse 10 months later because of regulatory hurdles in the US.

Danny Rosenkranz, the former chief executive and an engineer with the group since the 1970s, scraped into the Guardian-Inbucon top 10 by receiving just under £1m.

Ian Strachan, who forged the creation of engineering company Invensys through the merger of Siebe and BTR, received £1.5m on leaving the company last year.

Nigel Stapleton and Herman Bruggink received their £1m handouts after deciding not to compete for the role of chief executive at Reed - a job they had done jointly at the Anglo-Dutch publisher.

Peter White, ousted chief executive of Alliance & Leicester, the former building society, fought hard for his £1m goodbye after he left last year, threatening to go to an employment tribunal.

BSkyB made payments to two former chief executives - Sam Chisholm and his successor, Mark Booth.

British Biotech's former development director, Peder Jensen, received £400,000 compensation for loss of office when he quit last year, according to the drugs company's annual report.

webTitle: International news in brief

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Five arrested in Eta crackdown
fields.body:
Five arrested in Eta crackdown

Police in Spain's Basque region arrested five people yesterday in a crackdown on Eta after an upsurge in separatist violence.

The Basque regional government said two men and three women were arrested. That followed the arrest of three people on Saturday, when grenades and explosives were seized. On Sunday a bomb attack killed two civil guards.

Reuters, Madrid

Israel finds missing soldier

Israeli police said yesterday they had found an American intelligence officer who went absent without leave to join his girlfriend, also an intelligence officer, in Israel. webTitle: Possible solution for sovereignty of Jerusalem

fields.headline: Rivals for holy city may have to turn to God
fields.standfirst:
A plan to remove the disputed sovereignty of Jerusalem from mere mortals could overcome the biggest hurdle to peace in the Middle East

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: A plan to remove the disputed sovereignty of Jerusalem from mere mortals could overcome the biggest hurdle to peace in the Middle East
fields.body:
Today it is the turn of King Abdullah of Jordan to meet Yasser Arafat. Yesterday it was President Mubarak of Egypt's. In the seemingly endless round of meetings, the only thing everyone agrees on is that Jerusalem has become the main stumbling block in the Middle East peace process.

Jerusalem is a mediator's nightmare and, at first sight, totally intractable. The Israelis claim it as their "eternal, undivided capital". The Palestinians regard it as their capital too and claim sovereignty over the eastern part which Israel took by force in 1967.

Both sides have nailed their colours so firmly to the mast that to accept anything less would be courting political disaster.

Given these mutually incompatible demands, it is surprising how many people now believe that the city's future can be settled peacefully by negotiation. Following the collapse of the Camp David talks last month, efforts to find a solution, far from fizzling out, have intensified.

Sovereignty is the problem, and may also be the key to a solution. Sovereignty brings ultimate ownership. Nobody doubts its psychological importance, but sovereignty is rarely absolute: in an inter-dependent world sovereign states are not totally free to behave as they wish within their own borders.

This is the area of manoeuvre that negotiators have been trying to exploit. President Bill Clinton's plan at Camp David attempted to satisfy Israeli demands for an undivided capital by giving sovereignty to Israel, while allowing the Palestinians "control" or "autonomy" in some areas.

It envisaged full Israeli sovereignty over West Jerusalem, while East Jerusalem, occupied by the Israelis since 1967, would be divided into autonomous boroughs but still under Israeli sovereignty.

The boundaries of Jerusalem would also be redrawn. The effect of this would be to give the Palestinians sovereignty over some parts of East Jerusalem - Shu'afat, Beit Hanina and part of Qalandia camp - by transferring them from the city to the West Bank, where they would be incorporated in a Palestinian state.

At the same time, some Israeli West Bank settlements, such as Givat Ze'ev and Ma'ale Adumim, would be incorporated into Jerusalem.

The demand of both sides to have Jerusalem as their capital was addressed by proposing to establish a Palestinian capital outside, but close to, the city boundary, probably at Abu Dis. This would be known as "al-Quds" - the Arabic name for Jerusalem.

The plan also envisaged a special regime for the walled Old City, occupied by the Israelis in 1967. It would be under overall Israeli sovereignty but with Palestinian control over the Muslim and Christian quarters, with Israel having control over the Jewish and Armenian quarters (much to the Armenians' annoyance).

Within the Old City, Palestinians would have unrestricted access to the area known to Jews as the Temple Mount and to Muslims as al-Haram al-Sharif, and a bridge or tunnel might be constructed for this purpose. Jews would also be allowed the right to pray on the Temple Mount, possibly in a designated section.

Although this was presented as Clinton's bridging proposal at Camp David, there was nothing particularly new or American about it. Most of the ideas had been around since at least 1995, and the plan was very similar to one proposed by the Israelis in Stockholm last May.

The plan was clearly intended to help Ehud Barak through his domestic political difficulties and it is easy to see how he might have sold the package to the Israeli public: Israeli sovereignty would keep the city undivided; the boundary changes would tilt the demographic balance heavily in Israel's favour by introducing more Jews and excluding many Palestinians; religious Jews would get the right to pray on the site of the Temple.

On the other hand, it is difficult to see how Mr Arafat could have persuaded the Palestinians, or the Arab-Islamic world in general, that it was anything less than capitulation.

Describing the plan as "virtual sovereignty" and allowing Palestinian flags to fly in symbolic places could not disguise the fact that Israel would have ultimate authority.

In relation to East Jerusalem, the Old City (where less than 10% of the inhabitants are Jewish) and particularly the Haram (the third holiest site in Islam), the vast majority of Arabs regard Israeli sovereignty as unjustified.

The degree of the control to be conceded by Israel has aroused suspicion. During the Stockholm talks, the plan for Arab boroughs granted most aspects of civil control to the Palestinians but excluded planning and housing - an area where Israelis have acted aggressively in the past to create facts on the ground.

The proposal to allow Jews to pray in the Haram/Temple Mount area also caused alarm. The ancient Temple is believed to lie beneath the Islamic shrines but, up to now, the Israeli authorities have forbidden Jews to pray there, for fear that clashes would break out or that Jewish extremists might try to blow up the mosque or turn it into a synagogue.

Although, in the eyes of Arabs, the Camp David plan was heavily weighted in Israel's favour, it did illustrate the scope for creative approaches.

Since Camp David, attention has focused on the Old City, which covers an area of less than one square mile but carries the emotional burden of three turbulent millennia.

Unlike the rest of the city, its future is not primarily an Israeli-Palestinian issue. There are wider Jewish, Muslim, and Christian interests at stake. Under the 1994 Jordanian-Israeli peace treaty, King Abdullah also has a legal role in looking after the Muslim shrines.

Jordan and Egypt - the two Arab countries which have formally made peace with Israel - are playing a central role in the ongoing discussions.

Last week King Abdullah told Mr Barak of his "rejection of Israeli sovereignty over holy shrines in Jerusalem, which is considered as part of Arab lands occupied [in 1967]". Egyptian officials take a similar firm line over the Haram/Temple Mount area, saying there is "no way sovereignty over this area could be a joint one".

However, both countries have avoided committing themselves to an alternative solution, in order to facilitate discussions.

One proposal is to internationalise the Old City - something originally mooted by the 1947 UN partition plan. President Abdurrahman Wahid of Indonesia urged this on Mr Arafat last week, suggesting that sovereignty be put in the hands of six neighbouring countries (including Israel and Palestine), together with the UN. But there seems to be little enthusiasm for the idea.

Another proposal, from the Roman Catholic Patriarch, Michel Sabbah, is to hand over sovereignty to God. Although this initially caused some amusement, it has the advantage that religious elements on both sides find it difficult to reject, while secular elements see it as a possible way to sidestep the rival political claims.

Jordan has not publicly endorsed the idea but some senior officials are enthusiastic about its possibilities. An Egyptian diplomat also said that it might be worth exploring. The Egyptians are working with the Palestinians on a draft proposal which is said to include a concept called "spiritual sovereignty".

So far, nobody is sure how this would operate in practice, or who would represent God on earth. But a Jordanian official was confident that a way could be found if people wanted to make it work.

Additional reporting by Khaled Dawoud in Cairo

webTitle: Corrections and clarifications

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: A comment piece about the propaganda war during last year's Kosovo conflict erred yesterday, page 20, in linking Nato to claims that 100,000 ethnic Albanians had been killed (the latest estimate is fewer than 3,000). As a story made clear on August 18, this figure was never issued as a death toll. Rather, officials referred to 100,000 "missing" or "unaccounted for".
fields.body:
A comment piece about the propaganda war during last year's Kosovo conflict erred yesterday, page 20, in linking Nato to claims that 100,000 ethnic Albanians had been killed (the latest estimate is fewer than 3,000). As a story made clear on August 18, this figure was never issued as a death toll. Rather, officials referred to 100,000 "missing" or "unaccounted for".

A news story yesterday, page 10, was wrong in stating that the former Israeli nuclear technician Mordechai Vanunu sold nuclear secrets to the Sunday Times. Vanunu was never paid for his 1986 leak, which he always held to be an act of conscience.

A TV review of an Inspector Morse repeat was unthinking in wondering aloud yesterday whether the lead actor has a wooden leg (page 22, G2). A long-standing tendon injury gives John Thaw intermittent trouble in one leg.

An article yesterday headed Footing the bill, page 8, G2, made play of parallels between modern footballers and the acts listed on music-hall bills. Among the latter it mentioned Dan Leno as "the Prime Minister of Mirth". That title fell to George Robey.

Wheels, G2, page 16 yesterday (on Chrysler's retro PT Cruiser) harked back to the Ford Poplar. That was Popular.

In Real Lives, page 4, G2, August 17, the weather broadcaster John Kettley was homophonically envisaged walking into the sunset "as the credits role", and the BBC was said to have suggested that a song about him be recorded at "Maid Avale studios". Roll and Maida Vale would have been preferable. Mr Kettley's home town was given as Halifax. To clarify: that is where he was born. Todmorden is where he went to school.

It is the policy of the Guardian to correct significant errors as soon as possible. Please quote the date and page number. webTitle: Mbeki faces union anger at threat to jobs of poor

fields.headline: Mbeki faces union anger at threat to jobs of poor
fields.trailText: With one eye on the political crisis in neighbouring Zimbabwe, South Africa's president, Thabo Mbeki, has launched unprecedented attacks on corruption within his own party's ranks, greed among the new black elite and the alleged racism of white political opponents.
fields.body:
With one eye on the political crisis in neighbouring Zimbabwe, South Africa's president, Thabo Mbeki, has launched unprecedented attacks on corruption within his own party's ranks, greed among the new black elite and the alleged racism of white political opponents.

The recent denunciations have come as Mr Mbeki confronts growing dissent within the African National Congress (ANC) ahead of important local elections later this year, and amid warnings from the party's critical trade union ally that his conservative policies risk creating "a major political crisis".

Although there is no immediate prospect of a split between the ANC and its key backer, the party's leadership is well aware that Zimbabwe's newly blossoming opposition arose from the ranks of trade unions once fiercely loyal to Robert Mugabe, the country's president.

Mr Mbeki's challenge is to hold together the alliance with the unions and the Communist party while not compromising South Africa's march towards globalisation and a free-market economy.

The ANC's membership has more than halved since a high of more than a million when Nelson Mandela was elected president in 1994. In recent weeks, thousands of members have defected to opposition parties.

Prominent among the causes of discontent are corruption and a belief that too many of the new black elite - inside and outside the ANC - are primarily motivated by personal gain at the expense of poor black people.

The ANC's immediate concern is the fear of a backlash in November's local government elections for the administration of sprawling new "megacities", which will draw municipalities such as Johannesburg into single councils with Soweto and surrounding black townships.

In an attempt to maintain the party's fortunes in its core constituency without giving ground on key policies, Mr Mbeki has turned on those he believes bring the ANC into disrepute; a primary target is graft and "careerism" in the government and his party's ranks, from the top to its 5,000 councillors.

"Our experience in the last six years tells us that there is absolutely no reason why we should assume that we ourselves stand no danger of becoming victim to the widespread corruption we have seen in other countries, in Africa and elsewhere in the world," he warned at a key party conference last month. "It is the masses of the people who get robbed and condemned to perpetual poverty, while a small elite flourishes on ill-gotten gains."

Mr Mbeki has also warned against allowing the ANC leadership to become a "self-centred ruling elite" which, in other African countries, has triggered military coups or permitted "reactionary forces" to seize power.

He poured scorn on "a value system based on the pursuit of personal wealth at all costs" and those newly enriched black citizens whose idea of equality is to emulate the lifestyle of the white elite, or those who have become the public face of white-owned companies in order to win government contracts.

The top 20% of black wage-earners take home nearly two-thirds of all the income brought in by black workers. Where once there was a struggle for rights, now there is as often the pursuit of luxury cars and ever-bigger houses.

The sceptics argue that the government's economic policies, with their emphasis on business and the free market, encourage precisely the behaviour the president criticises.

It has added to the growing strains in the traditional ANC alliance with the party's union and Communist party allies. The Communists need the ANC for their survival as a party. The unions do not. Most recently, that relationship has been shaken by government plans to amend labour laws to ease restrictions on overtime and weekend work, and to make it easier to dismiss workers.

The government argues that existing labour laws are too restrictive and deter foreign investment. The unions say the government is putting business interests before poorly paid workers and is facing a showdown "on a scale never seen before".

Zwelinzima Vavi, the secretary general of the union federation Cosatu, said the new labour laws will result in "the mass destruction of jobs".

"These proposals ... threaten to plunge the country into a major political crisis," he said. "If these amendments are pushed down our throats, blood will be on the floor. This represents a major crisis ... it's a crisis of integrity."

The crisis of integrity is the unions' belief that the ANC wants their support at the ballot box but otherwise ignores them in favour of keeping the business sector happy.

"We must avoid a chicken and pig partnership. The chicken makes a partial contribution while the pig sacrifices its life in order to make bacon and eggs," said Mr Vavi.

The ANC's secretary general, Kgalema Motlanthe, conceded that the alliance is "failing" to improve the lives of ordinary people when he admitted that its principal effectiveness lies in fighting elections.

Useful links:

www.anc.org.za/ African National Congress homepage
www.cosatu.org.za/ Congress of South African Trade Unions

webTitle: Country Diary: Somerset

fields.headline: To mow a meadow
fields.standfirst: Somerset
fields.trailText: Somerset
fields.body:
We found the little hamlet of Hardington Moor and asked the way to a special hay-meadow. "You're too late for the flowers," they told us. "The meadow was mown a few weeks back." But they showed us how to find it, high up on a ridge at Coker Hill. We took in the long views, north and south.

An English Nature notice explained that our meadow, on the southern flank, was one of very few examples of the traditional, unimproved grassland of which only a tiny proportion survived the post-war intensification of agriculture. It is home to the rare oat grass and green-winged orchid and is mown in July after most of the wild flowers have seeded.

When we arrived, the cows were munching grass speckled yellow with nothing rarer than dandelions. Cattle keep down the tougher grasses and allow rarer plants to thrive in season. Looking down into the valley, we saw West Coker immediately below us, a labyrinth of narrow lanes threading between ancient stone buildings. The right-angled pattern of the 16th-century manor house stood out. Travellers who pass through the village by the overcrowded funnel of the old A30 gain no impression of the place's shape or character, but once you have looked down on its intricate plan spread out like a map, you want to explore.

We followed a steep track cut deep in the sandy hillside down into the village. Off Dibbles Lane were the schoolhouse and the old dairyhouse. The lanes were empty and silent until we turned a corner towards the manor house and heard cheerful sounds. Cream teas were being served in a cottage garden in aid of the Women's Institute.

People know about nearby East Coker because TS Eliot found his ancestors' birthplace there and wrote about it. Of West Coker, some may have read that it was the home of Coker canvas, prized by seafarers when hemp and flax were local products. Our good fortune was to hear its story direct from people who live there, sitting in a garden overshadowed by the manor, enjoying home-made cream teas.

The lanes were empty and silent until we turned a corner towards the manor house and heard cheerful sounds. Cream teas were being served in a cottage garden in aid of the Women's Institute. People know about nearby East Coker because TS Eliot found his ancestors' birthplace there and wrote about it. Of West Coker, some may have read that it was the home of Coker canvas, prized by seafarers when hemp and flax were local products. Our good fortune was to hear its story direct from people who live there, sitting in a garden overshadowed by the manor, enjoying home-made cream teas.

webTitle: Ireland's wandering sons

fields.headline: Ireland's wandering sons
fields.trailText: John O'Mahony is evidently disappointed to have discovered on his return to Ireland that its current economic boom has not turned it into the "modern", "egalitarian" and "inclusive" society he would like to see (A tiger by the tail, August 19). What he neglects to explain, however, is why he ever thought it might in the first place.
fields.body:
John O'Mahony is evidently disappointed to have discovered on his return to Ireland that its current economic boom has not turned it into the "modern", "egalitarian" and "inclusive" society he would like to see (A tiger by the tail, August 19). What he neglects to explain, however, is why he ever thought it might in the first place.

Perhaps, like Eamon de Valera, he believes that Ireland constitutes an exception to the rest of humanity. But where Dev saw an unworldly tribe of poor-but-happy folk dancing at the crossroads, O'Mahony imagines that material prosperity should automatically rid us of our faults. Can he point to a precedent?

Economic growth in Ireland may have sharpened, but is not responsible for, the racism, hypocrisy, corruption and greed he rightly condemns. And economic success gives the country a chance to shape its future in a way it never had before.

The boom in Ireland is part of a much bigger process, which has already seen us abandon 19th-century nationalism and transformed our relationship with the Roman Catholic church and the civil war political parties.

Ireland has changed. It must now face up to its problems and build the kind of society that its wandering sons would be proud to come home to.

Liam Hayes
Brussels, Belgium

webTitle: Italian murders spark calls to name paedophiles

fields.headline: Italian murders spark calls to name paedophiles
fields.standfirst: Special report: child protection
fields.trailText: Italian parents demanded that their newspapers follow Britain's News of the World yesterday by identifying paedophiles after two girls were murdered in sex attacks.
fields.body:
Italian parents demanded that their newspapers follow Britain's News of the World yesterday by identifying paedophiles after two girls were murdered in sex attacks.

Politicians and victim associations joined the clamour for published lists of convicted paedophiles as the horror of the killings emerged.

Graziella Mansi, 8, was burned alive in woodland near Bari on Saturday after being kidnapped and assaulted. Pasquale Tortora, 18, who was arrested and has confessed to the crime, told police he wanted to make her disappear.

On Friday, Hagere Kilani, 5, was abducted from her home in Imperia, near Genoa, and stabbed seven times in a neighbour's bedroom. Police are hunting for a 20-year-old man, Vasile Donciu.

Gesu Bambino, an association which campaigns against child abuse, said that, on request, it will hand out lists of paedophiles convicted in the past 20 years. Giancarlo Piergentili, its founder, said he would vet all requests to ensure that only responsible people obtained the information.

However, Livia Turco, a cabinet minister, cited the suicides of two men in Britain after the News of the World's campaign, and told Corriere della Sera that public lists would be useless and harmful. "The experience in England should tell us a lot of things."

However, others called for instant access to the names and addresses of sex offenders and those considered to have paedophile tendencies.

Echoing callers who besieged radio stations, Luciano Paoloucci, the father of a murdered child, said a cultural shift was necessary to protect the children.

"People are exasperated. Do-gooders should know that they are the accomplices of these assassins, to whom they give some kind of alibi even before they commit a crime. We must publish their [identities]."

Alessandra Mussolini, an MP representing the rightwing National Alliance, said parents needed the information to fight preying monsters. She called on the police to open their archives on all those convicted of paedophilia, or suspected of having such tendencies.

Civil rights groups and psychologists condemned the outcry as dangerous rabble-rousing which risked driving dangerous men further underground and spreading the vigilante violence of Portsmouth's Paulsgrove estate to Italy.

Graziella, the daughter of a street vendor, disappeared on Saturday evening from her home near the town of Andria, near the Adriatic, north-west of Italy's heel.

At 4am on Sunday a Carabinieri helicopter detected a small fire four miles away. A post mortem established that she was sexually assaulted and burned alive. Her assailant said he wanted to rape her but she kept screaming.

The Tunisian girl, Hagere, was led into a flat just metres from her home in Imperia, in the north-west, assaulted, and stabbed in the chest and throat with a kitchen knife. The only suspect, Vasile Donciu, is believed to have fled to France. A convicted car thief and illegal immigrant, his alleged guilt has sparked renewed calls for mass deportations.

webTitle: Turkish president defies government

fields.headline: Turkish president defies government
fields.trailText: Turkey's president, Ahmet Necdet Sezer, was on a collision course with his government last night after he vetoed for the second time a controversial decree which would allow the dismissal of civil servants suspected of sympathising with radical Islamist or Kurdish groups.
fields.body:
Turkey's president, Ahmet Necdet Sezer, was on a collision course with his government last night after he vetoed for the second time a controversial decree which would allow the dismissal of civil servants suspected of sympathising with radical Islamist or Kurdish groups.

The prime minister, Bulent Ecevit, said the president had "no right" to use his veto, and accused him of hindering Turkey's fight against radical Islam.

President Sezer insists he is not opposed to the aim of the decree, but he is convinced that it is unconstitutional. A former judge, who took office in May, he argues that the proposed change in the law has to be legislated in parliament, not by cabinet decree.

The cabinet had already warned that if the president refused to sign the decree again, it could trigger a constitutional crisis. Pro-establishment media have speculated that there could even be a move to impeach Mr Sezer.

President Sezer is known for his advocacy of democratic reform in Turkey, and for urging parliament to rewrite the constitution which was introduced after a military coup in 1980.

Many observers believe the three-party coalition could struggle to win a parliamentary majority for the measure which has been criticised as undemocratic by opposition politicians and trade unions.

The decree aims to set up a system in which any civil servant - including police officers, judges, or Islamic preachers - could be fired if at least two inspectors accuse them of supporting radical groups. Union leaders say it would herald a witch-hunt.

However, Turkey's influential generals are thought to be pushing hard for the decree to be adopted as soon as possible.

They see themselves as the guardians of the secular state, and they have been the driving force behind a three-year campaign against Islamic activism.

Many observers in Turkey see the current political conflict as part of the wider debate about the type of reforms which should be implemented as the country prepares for future negotiations with the EU.

webTitle: Lost men

fields.headline: Lost men
fields.trailText: The young Russian sailor's last letter home is heartbreaking, because it is so familiar. (Last words from a lost son, August 21). The world over, men are routinely sacrificed to the military. In peacetime or at the front line, countless young men have written home, never sure if they would see it again.
fields.body:
The young Russian sailor's last letter home is heartbreaking, because it is so familiar. (Last words from a lost son, August 21). The world over, men are routinely sacrificed to the military. In peacetime or at the front line, countless young men have written home, never sure if they would see it again.

Russia is being accused of secrecy, heartlessness or incompetence. But would it be different anywhere else? It is not so long ago that the British army shot its own traumatised men for "cowardice", and there is still a battle for survivors of the Gulf war to be taken seriously.

Mike Spring
Edinburgh

webTitle: Who needs A-levels?

fields.headline: Who needs A-levels?
fields.trailText: The assumption that boys' intelligence and ability is to be judged by GCSE or A-level results begs the question (Single-sex lessons to counter lad culture, August 21).
fields.body:
The assumption that boys' intelligence and ability is to be judged by GCSE or A-level results begs the question (Single-sex lessons to counter lad culture, August 21).

How on earth can a clutch of academic qualifications measure success in the age of Who Wants to be a Millionaire? and Big Brother? What on earth is so bright about committing yourself to a university course, from which you will emerge £12,000 in debt, when in three years you could have made and lost several dot.com fortunes? Moreover, what example is set by that poor sap at the front of the room with a string of letters after his or her name who for the past 20 years has been humiliated, bullied and underpaid by batteries of ministers and regulators?

The notion that academic achievement is something to be aimed at and be proud of is strictly for the birds.

DE Musselwhite
Department of literature, University of Essex
muss@essex.ac.uk

 So, to "counter lad culture", we put all the "lads" together in a laddish single-sex lesson ghetto - which, experience suggests, will only affirm and reinforce their laddishness.

By excluding those who are achieving (girls), where are the positive role models? As one of my students said to me after an unfortunate timetable reorganisation left him in a class of mostly underachieving boys: "Well, how do you expect me to do better when you put me with all the others who are worse than me?"

Educational apartheid is as dangerous and undesirable as any other kind of "separateness" and should be resisted as strongly.

Simon Midgley
Bacup, Lancs
simon@smidgley.co.uk

 I have been waiting for more than 10 years to hear about single-sex lessons in co-ed schools. In the 1980s I was head of maths in a social priority area school. One year, a male colleague and I had particularly difficult low-ability sets. Having heard of a co-ed school in Shenfield, Essex, which was teaching single-sex lessons, I suggested to my colleague that he take all the boys from both sets and I take all the girls.

The problems disappeared overnight. The pupils no longer had any members of the opposite sex to perform for, and we were better able to tailor the topics taught to their interests. Had I not left teaching the next year I would definitely have proposed expanding the practice. Does anybody know the outcome of the Shenfield experiment?

Cherry Waters
South Milford, N Yorks
cherryw@supanet.com

webTitle: Reclaiming the roads

fields.headline: Reclaiming the roads
fields.trailText: Since motorists don't own the roads, they can't be stolen from them. Taxes give Joe Page a limited right to use them, no more (Letters, August 21).
fields.body:
Since motorists don't own the roads, they can't be stolen from them. Taxes give Joe Page a limited right to use them, no more (Letters, August 21).

Residents of "home zones" also have rights: to a safe environment, clean air, noise reduction and minimal risk to their children's lives. Their creation redresses the balance lost during 50 years of pro-car road-building policies. Those 50 years have seen ever-encroaching noise and pollution and a reduction in choice for those not using, or not having access to, a car.

If 70 people in a double-decker have their journey time increased by 70 people in cars, whose rights are being attacked? If people say, as many do, "I'd love to ride my bike but I'm scared of the traffic", why should Joe Page's right to drive his car where he wants, take precedence? If children would like to be able to walk or cycle safely to school, why should the needs of adults in cars be considered a higher priority?

I use both a car (reluctantly) and a bike (confidently), according to the purpose of the journey and I have an equal right to choose which. Most people lack the confidence for the latter and traffic management should be aimed at making such a choice both safe and easy.

Mike Healey
Bradford
mike@atbman.freeserve.co.uk

 I suspect that Joe Page is a member of that fanatically pro-car body, the Association of British Drivers, since his diatribe about home zones is almost identical to that on the ABD's website. Mr Page complains about motorists "paying for roads they can't use" and road space being "stolen" from motorists. Local roads are paid for, not by motoring taxes, but by council taxes. Therefore councils have a duty to ensure that their road network benefits all local residents, not just car users.

After many years in which non-drivers were treated as second-class citizens, pedestrian schemes, bus priority measures and cycle paths are helping to ensure that roads benefit the whole community and reduce social exclusion. Home zones are not intended to banish cars but to give pedestrians and children priority on quiet residential streets which were never designed to cater for large volumes of through traffic.

Most sensible drivers welcome such measures and, of course, many residents of home zones are motorists themselves. It is only extreme bodies like the ABD, who think the roads should be the private fiefdom of motorists, that take offence.

John Bourn
Gateshead
john@bournagain.freeserve.co.uk

 Please tell me Joe Page's diatribe against home zones was a spoof. I am astounded that community-led initiatives to make minor residential streets safer for the residents can provoke such ill-informed antipathy. Home zones are not constructed on major through routes - it wouldn't work, there would be too much traffic. They may be created on "rat-runs", since they are intended not to block through traffic, but to ensure that motorists drive with less speed and more care.

In his outrage at the theft of "his" road space, has he considered the wishes of local residents to reclaim the street they inhabit from him?

Tony Jones
London

 So "more and more road space is being stolen from motorists". Well, that settles the old jibe of " 'Ere! Do you think you own the road, then?" doesn't it?

Colin Attenborough
Ely, Cambs
colin.attenborough@camcon.co.uk

webTitle: The power of the purchaser and the purchased

fields.headline: The power of the purchaser and the purchased
fields.trailText: I must take issue with the phrase, attributed to Stanley Baldwin, quoted in Bernard Crick's otherwise excellent article (Big Brother Belittled, August 19): "Power without responsibility; the prerogative of the harlot throughout the ages." This phrase seems to me precisely wrong; that in fact the exact opposite is true. Who holds the power, and who the responsibility, in a relationship where one human being pays another human being for sex?
fields.body:
I must take issue with the phrase, attributed to Stanley Baldwin, quoted in Bernard Crick's otherwise excellent article (Big Brother Belittled, August 19): "Power without responsibility; the prerogative of the harlot throughout the ages." This phrase seems to me precisely wrong; that in fact the exact opposite is true. Who holds the power, and who the responsibility, in a relationship where one human being pays another human being for sex?

It seems to me that it is the punter who holds the power. The only power that a "harlot" wields is sexual attraction and this is not power, it is influence. However strong the siren call of lust, it is still something that someone has to make a choice to submit to; it is not the case that the man (because usually it is a man) must have sex with this woman. But it is frequently the case that the woman (because usually it is a woman) must persuade the man to have sex with her, because she needs the money.

This is not to say that neither of them has choices; only that the choices of the purchased are more often more circumscribed than those of the purchaser.

How can anyone believe that the one who sells sex has more power than the one who buys? This would only hold good if access to what is sold was infinitely rarer than those who wish to buy, and this does not appear to be the case (and never has done).

The phrase is redolent of an earlier age, absolutely indicative of a certain type of establishment thinking that held that women were always to blame for tempting men into sexual liaisons. Mr Crick's use of the phrase in relation to Rupert Murdoch is thus absurd; Murdoch is patently in the purchaser class, not the purchased.

Kim Blake
Sheffield
kim_blake2000@hotmail.com

 When I read 1984 and Animal Farm some 50 years ago I also took their messages as a warning rather than prophecy. How wrong I was! How about "the year 2000 is the first year of the 21st century" as a supreme "prolefeed"? Invented, according to the casual observer of proceedings in the House of Commons, somewhere between November 1993 and the afternoon of January 13 1999. The people in the media who are solely responsible for the dissemination of "prolefeed" should be able to give an accurate date for its origin.

David Thomas
Bridgend, Mid Glamorgan
dthcym@tesco.net

 Bernard Crick's interpretation of the ideological concept that forms the basis of Orwell's picture of Big Brother and his role in capitalist development is timely, but I think that his claim that Orwell was the first to draw these conclusions is not entirely true. Surely the first to draw attention to the method of cultural debasement being used by capitalism to stabilise its hegemony was Jack London in his (only) political novel, The Iron Heel

RF Jameson
Dundee
RJdundee@aol.com

webTitle: We want more

fields.headline: We want more

fields.body:

webTitle: Leader: Boardroom pay inflation has gone too far

fields.headline: The rate for the job
fields.standfirst: Boardroom pay inflation has gone too far
fields.trailText: Britain's top boardrooms are beginning to look like the Premiership in English football: escalating salaries irrespective of performance, a disregard for public opinion, an increasing number of foreign players and no women.
fields.body:
Britain's top boardrooms are beginning to look like the Premiership in English football: escalating salaries irrespective of performance, a disregard for public opinion, an increasing number of foreign players and no women.

Our latest survey shows that basic boardroom salaries - excluding stock options - rose by 16% last year, or three and a half times the rate of growth of average earnings. This is not a one-off correction of an anomaly. It has been going on for years. Nor is it a reward for exceptional individual performance, since the vast majority of board members share in the annual harvest. There are no women in the top 20 (though Marjorie Scardino, chief executive of Pearson, has this year managed to creep into the top 30 at 26th). Four of the top six highest earning directors are from overseas.

It is right and proper that managers with outstanding talent should be properly rewarded. What is unacceptable is the way that top executive remuneration has become a self-perpetuating gravy train. Committees of non-executive directors (themselves the future beneficiaries of the climate they help to nourish) recommend increases linked to a going rate in the outside world. It is a recipe for a rising spiral of inflation that would never be tolerated by the same directors when they fix their employees' pay.

Directors are supposed to lead from the front. It is time they took the lead on pay - or else the divide between the highest and the lowest paid in the country will widen to socially unacceptable proportions. If they don't do it, then shareholders, who are starting to understand the untapped power they possess as owners of companies, must take the lead instead. And what about the government? Last year ministers promised to change legislation to make it easier for shareholders to act on unacceptable increases. We are still waiting for a statement. Meanwhile, the gravy train is one of the few that doesn't run late.

webTitle: Last night's TV: Gareth McLean

fields.headline: When the boat comes in
fields.standfirst: Last night's TV: Gareth McLean
fields.trailText: Secrets Of The Dead/East/Gravity Games/Animal Hospital/ Paul O'Grady's Orient/You Only Live Once
fields.body:
The Mary Rose will forever be connected in my mind to one thing - not Henry VIII but Blue Peter. If I shut my eyes and concentrate, I can still picture the ancient wooden skeleton slowly rising out of the sea like the remains of some bizarre sea monster, cradled in a bright yellow bassinet. Invulnerable hydraulics and steel met gnarled, slippery wood which threatened to evanesce into splinters at any moment.

I can't quite remember which Blue Peter presenter shouted explanations as the lumbering cradle inched out of the water (the lovely Janet Ellis maybe), but I can recall being completely in awe of the whole miraculous, brine-defying feat. Here was a ship from hundreds of years ago being reclaimed from its watery grave; it was a marvel of modern science, engineering and determination.

An autopsy was inevitable, one supposes, but the years have made me sceptical, my Blue Peter awe tarnished, and I didn't want to see this old friend's bones pored over, speculation made about her fate. Some Secrets Of The Dead (C4) should stay secrets and the past should be left to itself. Instead of wondering what sank the Mary Rose, our attentions should be - but probably aren't - focused on contemporary problems. While we are no ones without our histories, an obsession with the past can hold you back.

The excellent East (BBC2) took a long hard look at a contemporary problem, that of racism within the prison system, particularly towards Asians. Hardly enjoyable viewing, Cell Block Hate was an urgent necessity, which showed how Asian prisoners suffer everything from verbal abuse - from fellow inmates and officers - to physical assault. Zahid Mubarak was 19 when he died after being beaten up in prison. That was earlier this year. Unsurprisingly, two of the Asian interviewees had to be moved after speaking about the appalling treatment they endured.

Things were pretty wicked at the Gravity Games (BBC2) where bodacious dudes and delicious babes hung out watching extreme sports - and for extreme, read thought-up-while-under-the-influence-of-really-good-weed - and fulfilled every stereotype you may have had about such people. All baggy shorts, identikit tattoos and kooky outlooks, never has having one's prejudices confirmed been so much fun. Whoa. Man. With all the buff young men competing in events such as the Street Luge, Badger Sliding and Downhill Space Hopping (yes, really), Gravity Games was a bit of a riot, but one thing niggled: is Kate Thornton actually the prototype of a Perfect Presenter Robot?

What was on telly before lifestyle and leisure programmes and shows about animals took over? There must have been something other than Wogan, but whatever it was has disappeared into the white noise of TV history, eradicated by the unstoppable juggernaut of docusoaps, cooking and decorating shows, the ever-expanding brand that is Watchdog and the likes of Animal Hospital (BBC1). While no one wants to see animals suffer or make light of their plight, there would be something very amusing about Rolf Harris, on the blanket-clad arrival of some bloody animal at the RSPCA's Harmsworth Hospital, asking a vet "Can you tell what it is yet?"

There were more animals over in Paul O'Grady's Orient (ITV) as he continued his Oriental meanderings, this week touching down in Bangkok. After much hilarity over beavers and pussies, O'Grady's righteous indignation flared up at the Bangkok zoo where a tragic tiger cub was all covered in sores and had the most forlorn look in its eyes when O'Grady reached through the bars to touch the drawn animal. It would, as my mother would say, bring a tear to a glass eye.

It's an annoying man who encourages one to feel sympathy for Keith Floyd, but Nick Hancock fits that description admirably. In the last You Only Live Once (BBC1), Hancock was face to face with Floyd but, as in the preceding shows, no one seems to have told Hancock the programme isn't about him, it's about the guest. His producer really needs to sit him down and explain the whole guest-host dynamic. You know: host is supposed to ask questions of guest, elicit interesting stories and listen and not desperately seek attention, interrupt and use guest as springboard for cheap laughs. Less of Nick Hancock on television would be a good thing. None would be perfect.
