webTitle: Wenger defends 'target' man

fields.headline: Wenger defends 'target' man
fields.trailText: Arsène Wenger last night accused Premiership rivals of deliberately targeting Patrick Vieira after the French midfielder was shown two yellow cards by Graham Poll, England's only referee at Euro 2000, and dismissed for the second time in three days.
fields.body:
Arsène Wenger last night accused Premiership rivals of deliberately targeting Patrick Vieira after the French midfielder was shown two yellow cards by Graham Poll, England's only referee at Euro 2000, and dismissed for the second time in three days.

"It's a very sad night for us," said the Arsenal manager. "They will say I'm whinging but I believe he played the ball both times, maybe I am wrong - that's how I see football. It was an extension of the situation he faced at Sunderland where a player was on the pitch just to upset him.

"Sometimes there are players who try to get out of the game by just coming on the pitch to upset players who can play football. He is a world champion and a European champion but some people are on the field just to upset him. I feel really sorry for him."

Wenger admitted Vieira's volatile nature probably meant he was more likely to attract trouble, but he added: "I have been manager in teams with less potential but I never asked my players to kick anybody or try to stop the teams who were better than us. There is some bad feeling among some players."

Liverpool's manager Gérard Houllier sympathised with Vieira, before voicing his anger over Gary McAllister's sending-off.

"I think he (Vieira) tackled the ball, our boys said that. He was very unfortunate to be sent off." He said of McAllister: "It's not as if he had thrown his two legs for the tackle, in which case I would have understood him being sent off. That was not the case. I think he (the referee) just made a fuss of it.

"If you talk more about the referee than the football, then something is wrong. I felt sorry for all three sendings-off.

"I think Mr Poll had a bad game today. Maybe it is the start of the season. We are very unlucky with Mr Poll, I have never won with him - that is clear. As soon as we know we have got Mr Poll, the players know what is going to happen. It happened again today."

webTitle: Solanki sets pulses racing again

fields.headline: Solanki sets pulses racing again
fields.standfirst:
Worcestershire 231-5 v Warwickshire
County Championship Second Division points table
fields.trailText: Worcestershire 231-5 v Warwickshire
fields.body:
Vikram Solanki. Now that was a name once deemed worthy of all kinds of excitement. All England had to do was lose a wicket in South Africa last winter and Ian Botham would come over all bumptious on Sky TV. "Solanki's scoring runs," he would thunder. "Get him out here. Bring him in."

England did just that, and the reputation that had burgeoned on an England A tour in Bangladesh shrunk back again. The frustration of that limited-overs series has remained throughout a generally unproductive summer. Solanki's has been a name to utter with a sigh, a lavish talent refusing to ripen.

Solanki's second championship hundred of the season yesterday, an unbeaten 113 after Worcestershire's first three wickets had disappeared for eight runs, offered plenty of enchantment. But it is difficult to see, another A tour apart, where England can accommodate him this winter.

It was a cultured and slightly chancy affair, and he should have been caught in the gully off Dougie Brown when 81. Typical Solanki, you might surmise. Typical Worcester would be more to the point; this was another unreliable pitch to bat on and Solanki's frailties cannot be blamed entirely on his own shortcomings.

The Second Division could hardly be tighter. Back-to-back derbies between these two sides in the next fortnight will heavily influence whether they will be in the shake-up. Neither of the current top two, Northamptonshire and Essex, smack of invincibility, while only eight points separate third-placed Sussex and bottom side Gloucestershire.

In such a competitive atmosphere, it is a surprise to discover Warwickshire carrying a host of traditional pre-final injuries. Nick Knight's knee is the biggest concern ahead of Saturday's NatWest Trophy final, but anyone worried about whether Dominic Ostler, Ashley Giles and Allan Donald will make it would be better advised to fret about more pressing matters, such as whether they have put the milk bottles out.

Ed Giddins hustled out both Worcestershire openers, Alan Richardson removed Graeme Hick for nought, and Graeme Welch had David Leatherdale lbw just before lunch to add a third championship wicket to a dismal season.

That paved the way for a maiden championship innings for David Pipe, earmarked as the eventual wicketkeeping successor to Steve Rhodes, a fellow Yorkie. Pipe hails from Queensbury, a windswept summit west of Bradford, and his Queensbury rules involved a marvellous counter-punching 54, with 10 fours and a six, which made Solanki look comparatively ponderous.

 Justin Langer's unbeaten 76 put him on target for three centuries in as many matches as Middlesex struggled to 151 for five before rain interrupted their Second Division bottom-of-the-table dogfight against Gloucestershire at Bristol.
